Suddenly they find themselves fighting against time, to save the humanity from a nuclear war. John and Sarah's objective is to shut down 'Sky Net' which is a high-tech computer system in charge of the worlds Nuclear weapons before time is up.

This film is made to look exceptionally futuristic; I think it links in quite a few ways to I.T firstly by having the country's defense system running through artificial intelligence, how T-X was able to hack into the five police cars CPU and control them all simultaneously, and how T-X reprogrammed Terminator to kill John Connor and Kate Brewster.

All in all, T3 is a benchmark for 21st century action movies.

I'll be back.

title: The Judgement Day has come
review:
Talk to the hand and Arnie will listen.....

SPOILERS HEREIN:

Not unlike other Terminator movies this third, and seemingly last Terminator flick rocks! When the end of the world becomes inevitable the T-101 (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is sent back to the past to protect John Connor (Nick Stahl) and his bride to be Kate Brewster (Claire Danes) who happens to be the daughter of the head of the nation's computer defense system which system is trying to get rid of a malicious computer virus with its flawed Skynet program. Before things can go awry with Skynet Connor must warn Brewster's father to not activate Skynet. The couple is chased by T-X (Kristanna Loken) - an extremly beautiful lady who was sent from the future to ignite judgement day. Since there is zero chance of slighting a worldwide attack by machines Arnie chooses to bust jokes and shop wisely at am-pm for Waner Wafers (an austrian speciality) while he is fulfilling his command to protect future leader of the warfare against the machines. Disappointingly to say, but Arnie's fighting scenes with the T-X are for nothing. Eyecatching, but useless for the plot. This time the Terminator does not really have a mission. He is not trying to save the world but trying to extend its existence. Whereas T-X, by the way her real name is Terminatrix, is trying to speed things up.

Oh well, the cast is stunning, especially Kristanna Loken, the special effect awesome, the plot ok, the ending sad, and another Trilogy made in Hollywood is complete.

Grade: B+

title: great movie
review: T# is a good way to "finish" the Terminator trilogy. I hope that they never make a fourth because then it will totally kill it but it is one of the few that have made it in the so called "good trilogies". Even though there is a different director is stays true to the story and doesn't through too many people off. John Connor is now played by a different character but the actor does a decent job of portraying john. The special effects in this movie were really great and even though you know they are computer animated at times you can't tell because you are so pulled into the movie. This is incredibly action packed as well!(hello, arnold is in it) Anyways, if you are one of the few who has not went and seen this movie please do. You are missing out on an action packed movie.

title: Great blood & guts movie in the true terminator style!
review:
For all the guys out there that want adrenaline pumping blood and guts movie with Arnie doing his thing, this movie is for you. I really enjoyed the movie and loved the effort put into the action scenes. The car chase in particular was awesome.

I hope this is not the last terminator movie. I would like to see the story move on from the Rise of the machines to the Terminator 4 The war against the machines. I'm sure there is a lot that can be put into such a movie as this story unlike many think is definitely not dead!

Anyway, if you like action movies, this is a must see...very entertaining. Go Arnie!

title: Arnold still has it
review: Wow I was sitting on my sofa and T3 was coming on HBO. I am not a big Terminator fan but Arnold totally rocks. So I watched it and was blowned away with the action scenes and the great storyline. Its starts with John Connor in his 20s he is talking about how he is destined to help mankind in the future and all this stuff. He is a burnout and he lives on the streets. Then the TX comes from the future to kill Johns comrades in the future cause they cannot find John. After she comes Arnold comes from the future ready to kick some butt. The TX finds John from a blood sample. And chaos and action uncoils. I was loving the fights and all the blowned up cars. So if you have a chance go out and rent this. Its worth it.

title: The first and second times were the charm.
review:
Third movies, eh? Not all of them are doomed to be letdowns; "Escape from the Planet of the Apes" was the best of the series after the original, "A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors" was the best of the sequels (and, probably not coincidentally, one of the few that Wes Craven had any creative input on), and for the ultimate example of there being exceptions to the rule, look no further than "The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King." And then there's "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines."

The first two "Terminator" movies had James Cameron behind them; this one has Jonathan Mostow. Now there's nothing wrong with the boy Mostow  "Breakdown" proved he can pull off cracking thrillers, and he certainly delivers on the action front here, but the "Terminator" series was always about more than knock-em-dead action. While he and writers John Brancato and Michael Ferris obey that manifesto here, it's in a different and not necessarily better way for two main reasons; one is that the focus of this movie is more on John Connor here than on John Connor and the Terminator. In the first movie the Terminator and Sarah Connor were equals (sorry, Kyle Reese fans); in the second movie saw them almost as a family unit. This time, it's more about the troubled and older John than the machines, which sounds good in a way, but it just helps add to the general grim, defeatist air throughout the movie. Given that this movie is essentially the "Battle for the Planet of the Apes" of the series, bringing everything full circle, it couldn't really be any other way  but it would make the movie almost a deadening experience were it not for the reason most people choose to see this movie, i.e. the action scenes.

Which brings us to reason numero two-o; the writers spend a lot of time playing riffs on the first two movies, with the big chase scene featuring the Terminator on a motorbike chasing a big rig commandeered by the evil Terminator that's chasing our human hero in a smaller vehicle especially amped up here (and with the nice addition of the evil Terminator remote-controlling several other cars to help out in pursuit), and it would work a lot better if it wasn't just a bigger, brawnier relative of a similar moment in "Terminator 2: Judgment Day." (And we don't get "I'll be back"  but we do get "She'll be back" and "I'm back.") Arnold  no last name needed  is still fine when not required to act too much, and as T-X, the cutest cybernetic killing machine you ever did see, Kristanna Loken is effective and much easier on the eyes than Robert Patrick (though not quite as creepy); good effects help, but Marco Beltrami's score doesn't go with the mayhem as well as Brad Fiedel's did for the first two movies, even though it's more listenable away from the visuals than Fiedel's is. (The best track in the movie is Jerry Goldsmith's music for the C2 Pictures logo.)

But Nick Stahl as John Connor is no match for Edward Furlong last time out, or the rest of the cast here; his performance underlines the movie's unbalanced priorities  when the obsolete Terminator and the super-advanced T-X face off, it's hard not to think this should be the real climax of the movie rather than the finale we actually get. "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines" is the "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" of the series; some good ideas, nice fidelity to the rest of the series - especially in a moment when John realises that this Terminator isn't the same model that visited him in 1991 - and certainly not a bad movie, but ultimately something of a weak little sister. (And is it really asking so much for a movie in which Claire Danes isn't a misery magnet?)

title: Not the same without James Cameron
review:
I'm surprised that Arnold even bothered to participate in another sequel without James Cameron as director. It was James Cameron wrote and directed both the first and second Terminator movies. Both movies were classics.

The main problem is that Jonathan Mostow, director of this movie, fails miserably to imitate the genius style of James Cameron. T3 is littered with bad music, cliché dialog, and terrible editing and cinematography. Mostow is about as mediocre of a director as one can be.

Honestly, this movie should have never been made. The Terminator series has been spoiled. The only positive thing I can say about this movie is that the special effects were good and that Kristanna Loken looked absolutely gorgeous.

But that's the problem. The main focus of attention was the special effects and Loken. This movie doesn't have any rememberable dialog like the previous one, nor does it capture the audience's emotions during scenes of drama.

Do yourself a favor and pretend that this one never existed at all.

title: Should have left it to Cameron!!
review:
Well, i am a faithful Terminator fan i i was disappointed. I was waiting for an amazing film and presented with an OK film.

For a start, Terminator 2: Judgement Day could not have been topped, with a kick-ass baddie (the T-1000) and the under-dog T-101 (Arnie) and a pretty hot female lead, it rocked.

The third installment is OK, Nick Stahl isn't amazing in it but is made up for in Claire Danes and Kristanna Lokens fine ass.

In all if you are expecting something better than T2 don't.

It's a good attempt but nothing more than that.

Thanks for reading.

title: Good movie.
review:
Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines cashes in on the expectations. This movie could have been a lot worse. Actually the only big difference to it's two predecessors is that the film's not even nearly as dark as Cameron's movies. It is a bit of a problem, since T1 and T2 were perfect borderline horror movies. Especially the original. T3 doesn't take itself as seriously which maybe would've been nice. That said, I must also state that this movie is not bad as a lighthearter Terminator film. It does play with the same serious issues as the originals and the suspense is very well build this time around too. If I'd be asked weather I would recommend this film, the answer would certainly be yes. Arnold is back to doing what he does best, Stahl and Danes are good in the supporting roles and Loken kicks a** as the T-X. Plus there's that groovy chase sequence which is every bit as admirable as the truck chase in T2.

**** ½ / *****

title: Here we go again.
review: It is not the same without Cameron. He knows his characters better than anyone, no doubt about it. In T3 you will be find no suspense, lots of plot holes, weak -more of the same- script... lots of car wrecks and crazy robots. Original? No.! Exciting? No. But still the terminator. I didn't mind seeing this movie but it was a huge disappointment when comparing it to the first two terminator movies. Arnold was OK and had a bunch of good one liners But it was obvious that there was just no script to this one. Where was Edward Furlong? He's the best, the one and only John Connor as Arnold is the one and only terminator, coming back again and again. If you are a terminator fan go and let your brain rest while watching this one.If you are not, just wait until it's on any TV channel at home.

title: It has the Action and entertainment, but lacks the originality and intelligence
review:
To follow up a great film like "Terminator 2 - Judgment Day" (1991), which is probably the best Action-film I've ever seen, is not easy. To be honest...it's nearly impossible. Especially if your name is Jonathan Mostow and not James Cameron. Cameron is one of the best Action-directors ever, with high quality, brilliant and intelligent Action/Science Fiction-films like "The Abyss" (1989), "Aliens" (1986), "The Terminator" (1984) and the mentioned "Terminator 2" under his belt. When I first heard that James Cameron was not going to be involved in "Terminator 3 - The Rise Of The Machines", I knew that it wasn't going to be a film at the level of it's prequels. And after I saw the first trailers, I prepared myself for an almost mindless Action-film, yet an entertaining one (I'm a huge fan of the whole Terminator concept, so that's enough to satisfy me) that was going to do it's best to overwhelm the fantastic Action-sequences of the two other films. Last summer, when I went to the cinema and watched it for the first time, that's almost what i got....

John Connor has erased his identity and tries to hide his existence, in fear of being find by another terminator, after the death of his mother Sarah Connor. One day he runs into Kate Brewster who is also going to play an important role in the future of the human beings. After a little while, they're being chased by two terminators. A T-X (played by Kristanna Loken) and a T-800 (the Terminator himself, Arnold Schwarzenegger). The T-X is sent to kill a number of people, including Connor and Brewster, and the T-800 is sent to protect the two of them. Suddenly they find themselves fighting against time, to save the humanity from a nuclear war.

That's the story of the film...simple as that. But this story definitely provides almost two hours of good entertainment and "non-stop" Action. Because this is the kind of film you can really describe with the mark Non-Stop Action. I've heard that this movie is the most expensive ever made. And after watching the breathtaking Action and Special Effects of this film, I won't doubt that. The ones who loved the first Terminator-films only for the Action-scenes, shouldn't be disappointed. But the ones who also loved the fascinating and originality of the characters and the whole story and concept, is surely to be (at least) a bit disappointed.

This is a much more simple movie, compared to it's prequels, and the Action and the Special Effects has to carry the film on it's own. The prequels had some good character-development and good dialogs to put us deep into the brilliance of the story. This film lacks both. Character-development is almost completely absent. And poor performances by Clair Danes and Nick Stahl doesn't make it any better. They should have gotten Edward Furlong to play John Connor, just like he did in the last film. And the dialogs are minimal too. Much of the dialogs are just silly and doesn't grab me the same way as they did especially in "Terminator 2". Even though it has the most simple story of the three films, there's no doubt that this film could have been as good as the two others, only if they would have done it in a better way. I can see the potential just from watching the beginning and the end of the film.

But the film is definitely not going downhill all the way. Kristanna Loken is not only a EXTREEEMLY beautiful and sexy woman, but she sure is doing a good job playing the T-X. She really have that robot-look all over her face and body when she moves and talks, and she's almost as frightening as Robert Patrick's T-1000 in "Terminator 2". And Mr. Schwarzenegger...what can I say? He IS the Terminator. He was born to play a machine from the future, and he is just as good as he was in the other films. As mentioned before, this film has the impressive Action from it's prequels, so it's really giving me the right Terminator-feeling. It also has the humor we saw in "Terminator 2", and this time it's even more of it. So people are guaranteed to be entertained.

Over all....I pretty much got what I expected from this film. "Terminator 3 - The Rise Of The Machines" has the trademark Terminator-Action and entertainment, but it lacks the originality and the fascinating intelligence of the other Terminator-films. I know there's a "Terminator 4" on the way, which I doubt would be any better than this one. But one can always keep a little hope that the film will be a worthy conclusion to(in my opinion) the best series of Action-movies in film-history. Until then...just grab a bucket of popcorn and enjoy these two hours of wild, high tech Robot-Action.

7.5 out of 10

title: The Terminator is back and better than ever
review: I thought that it would be very hard to follow on from T2 , but somehow they managed it and I think that although u can guess whats gonna happen in a couple of the scenes, the plot is still cleverly engineered in that it offers superb action scenes that are enjoyable and there is a nice level of tension torwards the end when u see the machines beginning to rise, I particularly liked one scene where there is a giant machine rolling down a hallway and Arnold suddenly bursts through the ceiling, rips it head almost completely off and uses it's gun's to blast at another machine just yards away, I would recommend this  to any Terminator fans as it is a powerful chapter in a thrilling saga

title: Why?
review:
Terminator 3 tries to be what the first 2 are and fails miserably. The casting is wrong, the story is bad, and they're are some things that just make you laugh in disgust. James Cameron was right not to continue with this. Mostow shouldn't have bothered with this, it should have been left alone after the excellent Terminator 2. It should have been different like a giant war in the future with the machines, not a poor re-make.

3/10 Because some of the action isn't that bad.

title: Terminator 3
review: I like action movies very much so I watched Terminator 3. I watched all Terminator series. I watched all series in Movie Theater. Now you know how am I Terminator series fun. I thought Terminator 3 was not exciting and not interesting. I think Terminator 2 is better then that films because, action, friend ship, clear picture, music, and every thing are good. A good point of Terminator 3 is that the woman became an enemy's terminator. I think the terminator is popular of action. But an overture is too long and the story of the second half is not interesting. When I watched that I felt this movie was finishes being halfway. Therefore, I thought this movie was not interesting.

title: Probably better than Robocop3...
review:
T3, "Rise of the Machines" is for me that rarest of films - one that I like less with each viewing. That's not to say that it is without redeeming features - it has for example one of the most breathtaking vehicle sequences I can remember seeing - but the writing is generally more like poor fan fiction than a genuine third installment in the series.

MAJOR SPOILERS FOLLOW

On the whole I don't obsess over details between franchise movies, but the abandonment of "no fate but what we make" in favour of an inevitable Judgement Day counts as something more than a detail. John Connor's newfound fatalism is neither particularly believable in view of his history - after all, he *knows* that JD can at least be successfully postponed - nor is it necessary to the plot, since the core of that was lifted straight from its predecessor anyway. This isn't a new movie, so much as a bad case of "well if *I'd* written T2, *I'd* have done it this way". The relentless series of joky back references don't help either, in a film that seems unable to decide whether it wants to be homage, parody or a new perspective on the Terminator story.

Once you start to dislike a movie, the plot holes start to annoy you out of all proportion. How does the T-X's ability to manipulate other computers translate to an ability to remotely control vehicles' steering and transmission? Why was the facility that Kate Brewster's father worked out of on such secure military projects, completely unguarded? Why did he have a private plane there? What happened to the laws of motion (particularly the bit about "equal and opposite reaction") during the cartoonish battle of the Terminators in the washroom? What inspired Connor to fire up the 'particle accelerator' and above all, how the hell did he know how to? How come the T-X, which was so badly affected by the (rather disturbing) external magnetic field from the accelerator that her metal was being stripped from her frame was able to wrench an arm away, form an apparently motorised (i.e. magnetic field dependent) saw with a small blade and damage the accelerator enough to escape? Why was an emergency bunker, apparently designed to protect the most senior members of government in the event of war, fully powered up but completely unmanned? How does Arnie manage to restrain the more powerful T-X with both his fuel cells removed? Eventually you start to ask "why did I just spend the last 100 minutes of my life watching this stuff?"

The answer is, just so long as you can disengage your brain and watch it for the spectacle, it's a pretty slick show. There's chases and explosions and a cute, blonde and decidedly female villain and just occasionally those back references are amusing. And at least it avoids the problems of franchises like Robocop, where the main character went from virtually indestructible supercyborg in the first movie to spending more time being repaired than fighting crime in the third. These terminators are still determinedly solid killing machines, even if the film does seem to think it has more to say than is really the case.

title: Not Cameron
review:
The one line summary says it all. I think a sequel should be more than a continuation of the plot. That is, not only should it be faithful to the previous film(s) in story, but in style, theme, innovation, intelligence, etc.

*spoilers ahead*

Terminator 3 seems to miss these points and comes out as basically a dumbed-down remake of Terminator 2. The plot is virtually the same: a shape-shifting robot comes through time to kill John Connor and "The Arnold" model is sent back to protect him. Can you say "seen this before"?

I don't know who was responsible for the design of the T-X, Mostow or Winston, but I gotta ask: why? Who in their right mind would think that if you stick a glowing endoskeleton inside a T-1000, you'd get a more efficient killing machine? What, pray tell, does the endoskeleton contribute? The T-X can't do half the stuff the T-1K did: melt into floors, walk through barred gates, fly into a million pieces and then reassemble. But man, oh man, how are we to destroy this "deadlier" model? Oh, wait, it was as simple as blowing it up! Kudos on the creativity there. So in the end, the T-X met a death that would only delay the T-1K.

It's things like this that insult the true fans of the Terminator films. Whereas T1 and T2 were fact-based science fiction, T3 steps over into live acton comic book world. The T-X can change her robotic arm to become a plasma cannon, a flamethrower, a pizza cutter for god's sake! What is this, Transformers? Or the 60's Batman where he's got a convenient tool for every occasion?

In another brilliant scene, the T-X transforms her finger into a long needle, injecting several police cars with some kind of electronic signal (or magic potion) that makes the cars obey her every whim. I know Mostow's not a complete idiot and knows that to control a normal car you need to turn the steering wheel, push the pedals, shift the gears MANUALLY (it's a mechanical process). So the only conclusion I can make is that he considers the average audience too dumb to actually know that. Sadly, maybe he's right. But many fans of the Terminator movies are drawn to it because of the films' intelligence. And that intelligence has always come from Jim Cameron. His design for the Terminator endoskeleton was credible: the joints, the muscles, the eyes; you could sit there and actually believe that such a machine could move, climb, simulate a human. Moreover, you could believe that when covered with flesh, such a machine could techincally exist.

But in T3, this same Terminator can get its head chopped off, left connected only by wires and then somehow stick it back onto its body like Frankenstein and move it around in subsequent scenes as if nothing happened. In T3, the T-X can remotely control a car. (But if she can do that, she might as well be able to remotely control a pair of scissors, a bike, or a pistol.)

Moreover, if Mostow really was as great of a Terminator fan as he claimed to be, he would not have screwed up such details that an Arnold is a T-800 model 101 (not a T-850, not a T-101). Moreover, he would have studied what it really was that made the first two films great, and that was intelligence and ingenuity, not just explosions, chases scenes, and comic book robots with superpowers.

title: Good action, horrible story
review:
When I first heard T3 would hit screens, I was expecting it to be of same quality as previous ones, cause I really liked the first two Terminators. Then I heard Cameron wasn't signed to do it. And when I arrived to the cinema and the movie started, I realised my worst fears were true.

SPOILERS AHEAD

Movie started off with horrible voice-over, which explained the situation, so instead of revealing the story bit by bit with mystery factor (like previous ones), it was spat on our face, ready for mindless action. I actually regret paying so much money for seeing this movie. Action was well done, but that doesn't excuse the lack of story, which seemed to be there only to connect all the pointless actionscenes. It seemed like a spoof of first two installments. Although I liked Arnies performance, Nick Stahl and Claire Danes were pretty bad. They didn't connect at all and the part where Kate finds out her fiancee has been killed is really really bad. But don't worry - she'll laugh at it with John in a couple of minutes.

NO MORE SPOILERS

Only pleasant surprise was the ending (which I'm not gonna spoil for you). Oh yeah... and T-X is pretty hot ;) Rent it and watch it with friends after a couple of beers. Don't expect it to be as good as previous ones. Good sci-fi has been sucked out of it.

My rating - 3/10 (only for seeing Kristanna Loken nude from behind).

title: Typical sequel rip-off, but a GREAT COMEDY!
review:
*** MAY INCLUDE SPOILERS ***

I was utterly disappointed with T3. Ok, I'm not a fan of Hollywood, and I pity those who are. But T2 was still special, and Arnold is more than just an actor to me, he's more like a god. But this flick.. If I were Arnold, I would break down and cry upon such a disappointing sequel to his T2, which happens to be one of the best sci-fi flicks of all times.

I think IMDB should add "comedy" to the list of genres for this movie. There are some scenes that are typicals of a successful comedy, and there are such amateur, impaired, and purely f***ed up scenes that try to be serious, but just make you laugh your ass off. Maybe a sci-fi flick cannot and moreover shouldn't explain everything in a logical way, but even that wouldn't make me forgive the huge error in this movie: Robots give humanly reactions and face gestures! WTF?!?! And the story is getting weaker and weaker.. I think if they try to make a T4, it'll be pure comedy. So I hope they don't try that, for the sake of not insulting the first 2 movies anymore.

Other than that, the things humans say, and the way Terminator answers them is simply hillarious! The dialogues, the questions and answers.. Everything!

Claire Danes: Go to hell you asshole! - Terminator : Unable to comply.

Terminator appears out of the void and saves the heroes' lives among all the explosions and stuff, and says: I'm back. (Oh really? Are you? I thought you were front.. Blah!)

How Terminator catches bullets with his teeth, how Kristianna enlarges her boobs (which I'd like to see in another setting *evil grin*) Give me a break! Those are too cheap even for a Hollywood flick!

Briefly, I couldn't stop laughing from the first minute of this movie until the last. And it doesn't offer much other than making you laugh in tears, so it qualifies as a perfect comedy. I had the feeling it would be disappointing like this, so I hesitated to watch it. But I couldn't bear the push, and rented the DVD. Do yourself a favour, and DO BEAR that push! Especially if you've seen T2 and liked it, avoid this one. Everything about this movie is just an insult to T1 and T2.

A generous 6/10 for T3, and that's for the comedy part ;-)

title: Not so much an Epic!
review:
Just to think what Terminator 3 could have been. It's a good film but it's not the epic that I wanted and not the epic we expected. When looking back at the first two Terminator's the story for The Rise of the Machines is there for the taking and could have been the best 3rd film of a trilogy ever to be made. What was the first problem was Jonathan Mostow. He has made good films in the past and is a good director but to put the helm in his hands to make a film that had to be better than one of the greatest sequels ever made was very risky and extremely stupid. Only one man could have made T3 the epic it deserved to be and that's James Cameron.

I was really surprised he even let the movie go ahead because he must have some say over it as he created the characters in the first place. As far as Arnie goes he was as good as ever in his return as The Terminator. I thought the TX played by Kristanna Loken was alright but she didn't put the fear in you like Arnie did with the original and Robert Patrick did with T2. I think they now know that putting a girl in as the new terminator was a different and interesting idea but when watching it back now it looks all a bit silly really and stupid from the word off. I am not being sexist saying that no girl could be a bad ass TX or something, just not her. The most positive thing to come out of the film is Nick Stahl as John Connor. He is brilliant as Connor and makes you thank Mostow for not keeping with Edward Furlong in the first place.

What I didn't like was how long it was on for. For a film about a war between the machines and man you have to lengthen the story and it's characters. If this was a warm up film to what is about to come then that is fair enough but I can't see how another Terminator will get made now Arnie is the Governor of California and his run will go well into his early sixties. It all depends on whether he is feeling like Harrison Ford and ready to jump into any film whether it will be action or drama. If T3 is the closure of the story then it ends on a sour point. I thought of many other ways they can carry it on without him but whether that would work remains to be seen.

Would they continue the story without Arnie and the more important thing would it be any good? Even though Arnie is not the best of actors anyway his presence in the trilogy is one of the most important in any film ever made and that is important. The way T3 ends is one of the most original and emotional endings I have ever seen and the more I think about the more it makes you look at how different Mostow and Cameron are as directors because I don't think Cameron would have ended it that way. That's where I love what Mostow did with the end of T3 but I still think it should be James Cameron behind the camera. If they both written the film and Cameron directed then we would have had the best of both worlds but it's not like that and future is still not written as far as The Terminator goes and neither is anything else.

title: Another classic series is tarnished...
review:
T3's plot is basically T2's without Linda Hamilton as Sarah Connor, Edward Furlong as John Connor and in place of Robert Patrick's T-1000 is the new female Terminator played by the beautiful blond, blue eyed Kristanna Loken.

John Connor is now a young adult played by Nick Stahl (the little kid from "Man Without A Face" all grown up and now resembling a young Paul Newman). Sarah's dead and John's a drifter who just wanders around because he's still afraid that a Terminator might come knocking on his door if he sets down roots anywhere. That's when the lady Terminator shows up stark naked, kills a woman and steals her clothes and goes around killing a few of John's future 2nd in commands and then tries to kill both John and his future wife Kate Brewster (Claire Danes), who was a mild associate of his when they were kids. That's when Arnold's Terminator shows up to save the day. Did I mention Kate's dad is a general continuing the Skynet project? Well, basically the whole "you can change your destiny" moral from T2 is smashed into the ground in favor of the "destiny is set" moral because Skynet takes over and destroys the world anyway, thanks to the Internet. But John & Kate survive to lead the resistance.

Now this isn't a bad film necessarily, but then again, neither was "Indiana Jones & The Temple of Doom". Like that 2nd Indiana Jones feature, T3 doesn't even come close to being the classic that the first two entries were. Arnold's still fun to watch as the Terminator, Nick Stahl is a more sympathetic John Connor than Edward Furlong could ever have hoped to be, Claire Danes is alright but no Linda Hamilton and Kristanna Loken does the stoic female Terminator bit as well as any other actress can, but ultimately the film is hollow, cheesy and pointless. Despite Loken's efforts, she's never as creepy as the T-1000, and not just because she's a beautiful woman who leads the men in the audience to fantasizing about her (and I've seen some pretty creepy women in cinema in my time). The action scenes are executed competently enough but they lack the slickness of T2 and the raw power of the T1.

Ultimately, the only reasons for this film being made were to work the Internet into the Terminator mythology and to get a tall, beautiful blond woman Terminator naked to satisfy all the fan boys who wanted a naked Terminator woman. Well, those fantasies are fulfilled early in the film, when Kristanna makes the classic entrance and starts walking around completely naked, but most annoyingly her magnificent 5'11" figure is kept in the shadows for the most, which isn't fair considering that the original film and this film throw Arnold's butt right in our faces, something no one ever wanted to see except maybe his own wife, Maria. You'll have to look closely to see her derriere just before she kills her first victim. And like all women, Kristanna looks better with her hair down.

You know what a more interesting film would have been? Setting the film in the actual future and focusing on the beginning of the Terminators then. Arnold could have played a soldier who is killed by the machines and later his body is used as a model for the other Terminators to follow in as the mold.

title: A disappointing sequel to a popular story
review:
The first Terminator film to be made without the guidance and vision of James Cameron, and it certainly suffers as a result. Novice director Jonathan Mostow is way out of his depth and makes the classic mistake of all forgettable sci-fi films, he focuses on the special effects and action sequences and completely ignores the story.

Don't get me wrong, the special effects and action sequences are awesome to watch, but hardly compensate for a very sparse story line. As a result, the film is unbalanced and lacks the emotional core of T1 and T2. The heart of those films were the characters. You wanted them to survive, you wanted them to triumph and you cared about what happened to them. And that brings me to the other big problem with T3, Nick Stahl is appallingly miscast. His John Connor is a small, weedy looking guy with no on-screen presence, no charisma and a very limited acting ability. He was irritating to watch and only served to highlight the superficial nature of the story.

Such a pity, because there were some genuinely good ideas that with a skilled director and better writers could have made for a truly memorable film.

title: Popcorn Fodder
review:
First off the positives this film has some of the most over the top action sequences ever. Like or loathe this movie it will make you sit back and go wow!! every once in a while. Also despite some of the negative comments i've seen Arnie doesn't do a bad job of reprising his role as the Terminator.

The main problems I found with this film is that you never really care weather the main protagonists get killed or not. The whole movie feels like a re-hash of Terminator 2, the movie never stops moving and what interaction there is between the characters is normally conducted during a car chase.

If they had added maybe 10mins to the runtime and introduced a couple of slower scenes I feel it would have helped the movie and made the wow! moments more effective. There are some glaring plot inconsistancies between this Terminator 1 and T2 which have been discussed in detail elsewhere. But to be honest this film is not trying to be Citizen Caine, it's trying to be a big dumb action movie and in that respect it succeeds.

Overall it's not a bad movie, but it's not great either. It's perfect cinema or DVD rental popcorn fodder. Sit back enjoy the action and don't think too hard and you'll get an enjoyable evenings entertainment, does what it set out to do and no more 6/10.

title: Lack of Ooompf!
review:
I feel that had James Cameron been involved in this film, it would have been a different story altogether. I have always loved Mr. Cameron's work and I know that himself and Arnold Schwarzenegger make a good team. When I found out Mr. Cameron was not working on T3 I knew it wouldn't have the same 'feel' to it as T1 and T2 had. T1 had a scary / fearful-like sensation. T2 was the same, where by Sarah Connor, John Connor and the T-101 were running away from the T1000. Good storyline and plenty of plot and action. T3 as soon as it started u could feel it was not going to be the same. The past two Terminator movies started with a future image, the began showing the Terminator arriving. Then seeing the enemy. In this case we saw John Connor's life, the TX arrive cause a stir. The see the Terminator arrive, to then take part in a humorous plot.

I loved every minute of the movie because I was excited to see it. But in comparison to the last two, I was disappointed in the storyline / plot.

I sure hope there is a T4 or that James Cameron does a remake of T3. His way!

title: Terminator 3: Viewer Judgement Day
review:
Terminator Three could have been way, way worse than it was. Considering the James Cameron had nothing to do with it, it was a reasonable effort. Not brilliant, but reasonable. It would take someone to really get into the mind of James Cameron to have a chance of continuing his efforts in his place, and as this wasn't done the universe of Mostow's film isn't too synchronous with the universe of Cameron's films.

Mostow isn't what could be called an all-round director, he's strong on action but weak on everything else especially comedy, although perhaps the writers need to shoulder some of the blame. The new Terminator wasn't too bad, it seemed like an advanced model over the T-1000, if nothing else. The only real question I have to ask is what was Arnie's obsession with sunglasses? (I did have a laugh when he put on the first pair of sunglasses though, about the only joke that didn't make me groan).

T3 didn't tarnish the name of Terminator films as much as Alien Resurrection tarnished the Alien films in my opinion. I hope a fourth Terminator isn't being planned as one extra one is enough, anything extra they make will end up being distributed in large numbers as part of future box sets.

title: "I'll be cack."
review:
WARNING: REVIEW CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS

Nah, I'm only kidding, this second Terminator sequel isn't actually that bad to be honest. That said, I have only seen it the once, and can't imagine its thin-even-by-Terminator-standards plot really holding my attention a second time.

The original still holds its place as a quite impressive arthouse SF thriller in my opinion. Judgement Day? Well, it depends on how I view it - sometimes it's an overlong moronfest, others it's an exciting FX extravaganza and others it's a soulless, noisy popcorn machine. Certainly the day I posted my review of it to the IMDb I wasn't looking on favourably, though it's clearly superior to this pedestrian follow-up.

What plot T3 does have (and with its subtitle "Rise of the Machines" it could arguably be taken to court under the Trading Standards Agreement) seems to be dividing into two unequal halves. Remember those really corny episodes of Knight Rider (okay, all episodes of Knight Rider were really corny, but roll with me) where an evil KITT known as KARR would control Michael Knight's vehicle and turn it against him? Michael would have to stand there arguing with KITT's sense of reason? Even back in the days of David Hasselhoff's 80s perm that was dated, but here we have similar shenanigans with Arnie's battered T-101 under the control of the TX. The other, much larger, half comes directly from a straight rehash of Judgement Day.

Unfortunately, this does get rather silly as it means that while the film delivers a reasonable twist, it does yet again contradict itself. The nuclear war will come... no it won't... yes it does. Though this development makes the phrase "I am" possibly the most predictable in cinema history, the nuclear explosions are made to look quite beautiful. Whether this is a good thing or not is open to debate, and maybe with a bit of post 9/11 angst this would have made the film feel relevant, rather than just an old relic trying to relive glory days.

Of course, the biggest problem making this an okay sequel instead of one you actually give a toss about is the TX. When a character is so rigidly defined by their sexuality as Kristanna Loken is, then it removes all tension. It's just not possible to be scared when your libido is being forced to work, and even by T2's standards there's an enormous amount of obvious humour, pushing it beyond parody at times. Okay, I did shame myself by laughing at the gay gag, but when it gets to the stage of the TX checking her reflection and squeezing Arnie's balls it's just gone too far. And with her superpowers there to attempt to top Robert Patrick's superb T-1000, we get silliness like her power over other machines and inflatable breasts. If the inevitable fourth film continues to build on this we'll soon have flying Terminators that can assume the form of small rodents.

An okayish script is often dumb, allowing for back-slapping cameos by Dr. Silberman, and a nauseating plane scene where Clare Danes contrivedly explains how she used to test fly her brother's. Generally though, while there's the traditional reams of exposition in between pointless explosions, this isn't so contrived, and even offers up intriguing possibilities with the foretold death of John Connor. Commendably, even the paradoxes inherent in the concept are addressed, with Connor (Nick Stahl, quite good) reasoning that their actions may make the T-101 cease to exist.

If I really wanted to be nit-picky I could cite the incredibly crude uses of product placement, but instead I'll just ask the question of what new does this sequel bring to the party? The answer is nothing. There is no real reason for this sequel to exist, though it is nice to see Arnie having another hit, when his lower-key successes of late have all been worthwhile (though The 6th Day was a stinker).

The lack of usage of the theme and that eerie android sound effect surprise, yet the FX are, naturally, technically the most proficient. However, Jonathan Mostow's leaden direction fails to work them in any innovative way (and why do the Terminators now arrive in a disco mirrorball?), meaning they fail to impress. Combine this with the fact that such effects are no longer groundbreaking, as they were for T2, and it's something of a let-down. Forward to 2004 and we now have Governor Schwarzenegger of California. Was this his half-hearted farewell?

title: The Machines Rise Indeed
review:
Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines was a project that had nothing going for it. Without James Cameron behind the camera (or involved in any way at all), many thought the project was doomed from day one. With a new director, Jonathan Mostow (U-571), a new John Connor, Nick Stahl (Bully), and a story that seemed like a rehash of Terminator 2: Judgment Day it seemed that the naysayers would be right. I am pleased to say that they were only half correct about this film.

Ten years after John and Sarah Connor, with the help of a friendlier T-800, were able to stop the T-1000 and Judgment Day, John is in hiding. His fears prove to be well-founded as another, later model terminator, the T-X (the smashingly gorgeous Kristanna Loken), travels back to 2003 with a new mission. In the midst of the chaos, John meets Kate Brewster (Claire Danes of My So-Called Life fame), and it seems that their meeting at this time is not so much coincidence. A T-800 (Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger) leads John and Kate on a journey to learn the truth behind Judgement Day and to stop the T-X.

Terminator 3 is not the bomb that many thought it was going to be. Mostow is wise enough to keep the tone and the look of the movie close enough to Cameron's style as to not alienate this film from the rest of the series. He does, however, throw enough of his own flair into the mix that we do not feel we are watching an exact replica of Judgment Day. There are scenes of action in this film that are simply breathtaking to behold. Not thirty minutes into the movie one of the greatest scenes of vehicular mass destruction takes places and the movie rarely lets up until the end. The film begins to border ridiculousness in the action arena when you begin to notice that something blows up every ten to fifteen minutes. Fortunately, however, each and every action scene is a joy to watch.

The actors here are all very strong. Schwarzenegger and Loken are both excellent in their parts. Arnold would have had no excuse to not play a perfect terminator; the real worry lay with the ability of Loken, a virtual unknown, to carry such a heavy role. Loken is a real delight as the T-X with her ability to create small moments with only her head and face movements. Nick Stahl is believable as John Connor and does a good job throughout. Claire Danes is decent in her role though she would qualify as the weakest link amongst the cast.

The real problem with the movie is the script. As hard as it tries, the story here is nothing we haven't seen from a Terminator film. Its good terminator versus bad terminator premise was carried out to much greater effect ten years ago with Judgment Day. The time-travel aspect and inherent paradoxes therein reach a new level of confusion in this film as both terminators have unnatural knowledge of each other's movements from the very beginning and the audience is left to wonder why this movie needed to be created after the finality of the last film. Also, there is far too much goofiness involving Arnold's terminator. Where Terminator 2 used carefully placed and crafted bits of humor to showcase the small bit of humanity contained within the machine, Terminator 3 uses the terminator as ludicrous comic relief when none is needed. Finally, the much talked about ending is admittedly a little weak and underwhelming in light of the rest of the film.

There is no escaping comparison to the two films that came before Rise of the Machines. The first two in the trilogy are true examples of modern classics. While Terminator 3 tries its best, it is by far the weakest of the series. The admirable job done by the cast and crew to ensure this films place in the series, however, is to be commended. With less brains and more popcorn value, this film should satisfy most fans of the action filled saga.

title: Great ending to a mediocre film
review:
NO SPOILERS

If you want to learn about the ending of this film, go ahead and read some of the other reviews here that contain spoilers. I'll just add my agreement that it was both well-done and fit perfectly with the overall tone of the three movies.

OVERALL REVIEW

There are so many plot holes and silly devices that are wholly unnecessary. It seems the director had a certain artistic vision and was going to make a movie to fit that vision, come hell or high water. Some obvious items of stupidity:

* If the female terminator (terminatrix?) is such an efficient killing machine, why does she choose to wear high heels which are totally impractical to the business of chasing people down?

* If she has such incredible powers to remotely control basic machines, why doesn't she use these powers to stop the very vehicles the good guys are using to get away?

* If the magnet is so powerful that it can hold back the super-strength of the terminatrix, how is John Connor able to keep carrying his guns?

* Why does Connor seem surprised that the terminator (Arnold) doesn't recognize him from ten years ago? After all, Connor helped destroy the terminator from T2, so he knows this one can't be the same machine, right?

Anyway, the movie as a whole doesn't really make much sense. The plot is basically identical to T2, with a few twists to make it interesting. The special FX are good as expected, but really don't have any of the "wow" above and beyond the type of stuff we have already seen elsewhere.

RECOMMENDATION

Rent it for a rainy Saturday, and definitely watch all the way through to the very-worthwhile ending.

title: Arnie's back but the movie is a bit of a mess. Camerons presence is missed.
review:
Movie Ratings: ***** Unmissable **** Excellent *** Good ** OK * Bad

Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines. (2003)

Stars: Arnold Schwarzenegger, Nick Stahl, Claire Danes and Kristanna Loken.

The Plot:

Ten years after John Connor was targeted by the T-1000, He has been on the run, No Identity, No Phone, Nothing. The machines from the future have sent a deadlier Terminator, the TX back through time to terminate Johns soldiers in the future. The TX stumbles acroos John and he is targeted for termination once more only the resistance has sent back Arnie's re-programmed terminator to protect him and try to prevent Judgement Day from breaking loose again.

Plot Ends.

A bit disapointing without director James Cameron, Arnie tries to carry the whole film but fails.

The script is rubbish as Arnie is made to look like a fool as to the bad ass harley riding terminator in T2. Linda Hamilton (Sarah Connor) is also missed but is given a mention.

Other than to see Arnie put on the leather clothes and wield shotgun again... Give this a miss.

**

4/10

The Reviewer.

Fact: Arnies famous line 'Ill Be Back' isnt featured here instead it is replaced with She'll Be Back (A reference to the TX) and when he turns up at the films finale he says 'Im Back!'.

title: Ingenious ending, but overall disappointing
review:
WARNING: ENDING SPOILERS!!!

If ever there was a project doomed from the very start, it had to be T3. The making of a terminator film without either James Cameron or Linda Hamilton was a recipe for disaster, and even mighty Arnold isn't what he once was. On top of that, the new director is Jonathan Mostow, a man whose only credits thus far have both been mediocre action flicks. And we end up with...

A mediocre action flick. Well, that's better than I'd expected.

Actually, this whole movie plays like a big piece of self-parody. It is undisputed fact the heyday of Schwarzenegger-style action is over, yet they still keep trying here. Nick Stahl, who has inexplicably been cast in the role of John Connor despite being the least heroic, least imposing, and least edgy actor working today, is a waste of space, and the moment at the beginning that shows him made up to look like his future self is the purest agony. Please Mostow! Cameron picked Edward Furlong and Michael Richards, BOTH of whom were perfect! Is this really the best you can do?

When compared to Robert Patrick's cold menace as the T-1000, Kristanna Loken is a waste of space as the T-X. She generates any menace only in the single shot used ubiquitously in the trailers, so it's one long letdown in the theatre. The new terminator's abilities are incredibly badly explained, and they also look stupid. And Claire Danes. I have nothing against Claire Danes. I like Clair Danes. She was great as Juliet, I loved her in The Hours, and she did a great voice for San in Princess Mononoke. But she is not Sarah Connor, nor will she ever be any substitute Sarah Connor awkwardly shoehorned as John's future wife to cover the fact that Linda Hamilton was smart enough to skip this project.

The action, as stated earlier, is mediocre at best. Cameron's gift for pushing the envelope is sorely missed. A fetish for big trucks, so subtly worked into the first two, sticks out Arnold's ridiculous new "nuclear cell" here. Mostow tries, and fails, to spice things up with some pointless gore and exposition, but neither works.

Now, finally, the good news. When we get to the titular event, which comprises the last act, things improve considerably. With a host of early-model HKs to play with, for the first time, we actually get some action scenes that not only get the adrenaline pumping, but do so an almost Cameron scale. We also see some actual Terminator-style production design for the first time in the film.

And then, there's the ending. Total nuclear annihilation. That's a courageous enough act of narrative to make me forgive a lot, and plus, its handling is sublime. Though that's largely because it's done in narration and we don't have to see Nick Stahl.

title: unexpectedly fun and decent sequel
review:
I've read a lot of negative things about 'Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines' so far, here on IMDb as well as in newspapers and magazines. A lot of (professional) reviewers meant that the film had clearly only been made to cash in some extra money by milking a familiar concept and that it did not live up to the expectations.

Although we are all entitled to our own opinions, I must say that I find most of this rather unfair. There aren't many third installments in a series that actually live up to their expectations (there aren't many first-sequels that do either, but T2 - although not as good as the original in my opinion - pulled that one off as well). The main reason for this is that most follow-ups simply try too hard; most producers think that what the audience wants is simply more action, bigger explosions and tougher opposition for the good guys. Therefor this is what we have come to expect and I think it speaks in T3's favour that it was not what we got. Mind you, it's not that the audience is getting less action than in the first two films, the makers just decided not to add to the abundance already there.

One of the best things about this film is that it does not take itself too seriously. A lot of the one-liners (inevitable in films of this sort) are puns on the ones from the previous two films, and in some small scenes T3 actually makes fun of the entire franchise thus creating a parody of itself. In a way this puts things back into perspective, saying: "look, we know it's corny, implausible and an exhausted formula, but it's good fun so what the heck."

And good fun is exactly what this film is trying to be, nothing more and nothing less, and in that it has succeeded. To the filmmakers' credit the film didn't turn out to be pretentious, they didn't blow it by going over the top and they nicely wrapped up the trilogy plot-wise in the end thus avoiding all the pitfalls you might encounter when completing a series. It seems that the entire crew had a lot of fun making this film and it clearly shows.

The only thing I can say to those who have already seen the film and found it 'not living up to their expectations' is that it 'would' have if the studios were truly trying to milk the concept, but that they would probably have found it an even worse film as well. Those who are still planning on seeing this film I would advise to simply not expect anything at all and judge the film on its own merits; as you should with any film you watch.

title: Thank God
review:
Let me first start by saying, Thank god this movie did not ruin the Terminator saga. For years I've been waiting for this film to arrive, and ever since it was first announced I never had negative thoughts on this movie. After those 3 years of waiting, I must say that I'm impressed by Mostows final product. No, it's not a Masterpiece like James Cameron's first two installments, buts its a worthy sequel. Alot of people have complained that there are too many plot holes, but there are no fewer plot holes than that of its 2 predecessors. The screenwriters and Mostow handled the continuation of T2 well. Don't get me wrong, this movie has its flaws, and YES James Camerons touch is missing, but does that make it a bad movie? No. 12 years is a long time to make a sequel, and based off of how poor some sequels are, I'm glad this one ended up a winner, box-office wise and critic wise. So on that note, congrats Arnold, Nick, Kristana, Clair etc...We now have another worthy entry into the collection of Sci-Fi trilogies. Hell, even bring on a Terminator 4.

Rating: 7.5/10

title: Edward Furlong...
review:
I was disappointed that Edward Furlong was not playing John Connor. That might be my major gripe with the movie. And this "John Conner" did not really show himself to be resourceful at all---meaning he didn't seem "special" enough to carry on this lopsided fight between humans and machines. Whereas the young Furlong in T2 was maybe the most impressive kid I've seen in the movies--while managing to be utterly real!

The twist at the end was indeed pretty cool though. Nice. In any case T3 << T2.

title: Not worthy of the heritage
review:
This film should never have been made; James Cameron knew this, so did Linda Hamilton, unfortunately for the movie-going public Jonathan Mostow did not. The plot is referential to the vastly superior T2, to the point that the premise is almost exactly the same, aside from the gender of the villain. Arnie saves John Connor, check. Morphing bad guy, check. And so on. The major problem with this approach, apart from the fact that it makes for an unoriginal movie, is that Mostow does not have the justification to do it. He had no active involvement in the production of T2, therefore never earned the right to exploit the ideas of those who were involved.

Another problem with Mostow's approach to T3 is his unwitting insistence that more must mean better; a perspective undoubtedly conduced by the $170m budget. Witness the over-exuberant time machine bubbles that the Terminators arrive in - retaining similar effect to the first two films would have enhanced continuity and proved less of an irritating visual distraction. Obviously Mostow has not learnt when it is right to borrow.

All the blame for the flaws of this film cannot be lumped on Mostow's shoulders - the scriptwriter should take his weight. Admittedly, there were sporadic witty one-liners, but the major fault was a lack of attempt to capture audience involvement. The whole beauty of T2 was the subtext of the father-son relationship between the robot and the boy; executed so well that what could easily have been a tacky ending really worked. All that the death of Arnie elicited in T3 was a sigh of relief that the film must be reaching the end.

A do not consider this film a sequel. Period. 1 out of 4

title: Not as sharp as the original two films - SPOILERS!
review: Terminator 3 was probably set to not reach the same heights as the two previous entries.  James Cameron, Eddie Furlong and Linda Hamilton were not involved with it - a shame :(.  Also - I thought that they rapped the series up nicely at the end of the second film (destroying the last remnants of the Terminators to prevent Judgment Day from happening)....  However in Hollywood - when anyone is on a good thing - they will milk it to get a few bucks out of it.  Thus a few plot holes were exploited and... surprise-surprise - the machines live on. Terminator 3 opens up with John Conner (now 20-something) who is a drifter - not wanting to be connected to the system.  We learn that Judgment Day was only delayed from T2 - not preventing.  Of course - they send two terminators from the future to hunt and kill all the future leaders of the human resistance. This film isn't all that bad - I just don't think it reaches the high heights of the first two.  Cameron (when making sequels) - tends to follow the same rules of the first movie - while giving it a whole new fresh appeal.  Sadly - T3 doesn't feel as fresh as the first two and it tends to bend the rules a bit for its own devices.  Nor does the movie follow the basic plot lines of the original two films.  The Terminatrix is a good idea (to be female) - but doesn't reach the same levels of brutality as Arnie in the first movie and the T-1000 in the second.  Plus - it doesn't feel that radically different from the T-1000 (which was just a pleasure in T2)... all the shape shifting aspects are still there - but she just seems to have a few bells and whistles attached for fun (eg: controlling other machines / can fire off weapons).  I don't think they play off the Terminatrix's powers off to full potential - which was a shame. Overall - I don't think it is a bad movie - its just that it tries to be a different movie from the first two - without succeeding.

title: Terminator 3 is good......
review:
but no Cameron's touch.

It is a dramatic and explosive end for Arnold's run as T-101, and they've chose great casts for the characters. Claire Danes is perfect as Kate Brewster, but unfortunately, Ed Furlong was in drug rehab so Nick Stahl as the guy who replaced him as John Connor.

I first watched Nick Stahl's performance on "Disturbing Behavior" and his character from T3 was similar to his role from that movie, because both of his characters suffered paranoia of something dangerous.

title: Not quite up to scratch with the first two, but still entertaining(spoilers)
review:
After the superlative first two "Terminator" films, there seems to be little need for a third movie about the eponymous cybernetic assassin. Yet this is what director Jonathan Mostow has produced, to surprisingly positive acclaim. While this effort is certainly not a classic in the same league as its predecessors, "Terminator 3" is still an entertaining and inventive sci-fi thriller.

John Connor (Nick Stahl), once set to be mankind's future saviour, is now a computer hacker in his early twenties who lives on the road by his wits. His mother Sarah (the Linda Hamilton character from the first two films) has died of leukaemia since the events of the last film. Unbeknownst to him, the apocalypse he thought he'd averted several years ago is nearly upon him. And once again he finds himself the target of two Terminators: one out to protect him, the other to destroy him. The nightmare begins again...

The film's main strength is its excellent array of action sequences and effects. Highlights include an inventive truck/car/bike chase sequence, a showdown in a weapons factory, a chaotic but oddly eerie shootout in a mortuary/graveyard, and the final confrontation in a desert retreat.

The acting is a quite mixed ranging from good to merely adequate. Nick Stahl is good as John Connor, but does not bring enough depth or pathos to the role. Claire Danes is on fine form as his romantic interest, and has a good relationship with her tragic father (David Andrews). Sadly there is a lack of romantic chemistry between her and Connor that leadens too many dramatic scenes.

As for Arnie, well, he said he'd be back and he is. Not once looking self-conscious or uncomfortable, Schwarznegger slips very easily back into the role that made him a star. With the actor's recent foray into US politics, this is likely to be his last role for some time. He handles all action and dramatic scenes very well. It is both surprising and endearing that an actor of limited range like Schwarznegger can add depth and substance to what is mostly a one-note part. Kristinna Loken is his new opponent, a T-X who simulates radio signals and whose arms can turn into rapid-firing machine guns. With a lithe figure and menacing stare, Loken has a sinister screen presence.

The script here is OK, but nothing special and could have done without the pointless self-referentialism. The story is very good, though, and presents us with an unexpectedly gloomy ending that sets the stage for further films.

"Terminator 3: Rise of Machines is not perfect but possesses enough action and just enough substance to make it a worthwhile flick.

title: Talk to my hand
review:
I have just finished seing it, and... Man, how I am disapointed. It has just recycled the T2 script in a very badly way, and much of the "different" stuff just make it worse.

But the real thing that made me hate it wat the comic touches, what the hell was that ? Already in the beginning when the california's leader wears that pink glasses I think to myself: this is going to me a disaster - and yes, it was !

I dont care if people make movies only to get cash, but this one was really ridiculous, and it even left that classical blank space to another sequel, which obviously will be another "put cash in my pockets" movie.

3 out of 10... it is already too much!

title: Ho-hum
review: The Terminator series went one film too far and this was that film. This film lacks the cohesion that it's older brethren had. The acting is so-so, the plot boringly similar to the other two. The film has plenty of action, as all the Terminators do, but other than that, it's just not a keeper. Hopefully no one will resurrect this series when Gov. Arnold is finished saving California. This series should be TERMINATED!

title: Terminator three or two and a half?
review:
I was like many of you who waited, longed and prayed for the third instalment of was, a simply remarkable story exceptionally transferred to the screen by James Cameron. The Terminator (1984) and T2: Judgement Day (1991) will forever be referred to as landmark movies; the first, a dark, graphic, cult horror and the latter, six years later - a visually stunning action sequel which further developed the complex narrative bringing us to a mouth watering conclusion which left those of us, rather sad hardcore fan's, still emotionally attached to our Terminator and begging for a third to be created someway... somehow... We all sat and thought about it didn't we? Countless times after re-watching the T2 we envisaged the third... Somehow, after clearing up the mess in the Steel Factory, some fat, hard hat wearing extra, would find Arnie's Arm and hand it to the Police... a twist and a turn later, and Skynet is a reality once more... Then... What would T3 be like? A war in the future surely? That's what we were all craving for... we had the past...(T1) we had the present (T2) and as Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines lands before our drooling tongues... we have... the present again... (strange though, how 1991 seems to reflect reality as we know it, a whole more 'realistically' than our 2003 version.) So the narrative moves absolutely nowhere. A more credible title may have been, 'Terminator 2, and a half' and lets face it, the casting director may as well have brought in the likes of Lesley Neilson as the TX, for all the humour that Mostow thought would lure the sceptical audience members into giving the movie a chance. But I guess with a duo of disillusionment in Nick Stahl - a weak, unconvincing development from Edward Furlong's portrayal of the rebellious John Conner and Claire Danes, a pretty but in no-way, shape or form a replacement for Linda Hamilton's hard, masculine heroine, the audience can do nothing but accept this a parody of the first two.

In my opinion, there is no need for such blatant humour in a movie narrative that was originally motivated from a deep conscious paranoia of nuclear war and technological change. T3 should have brought into contention themes that are still relevant and scare us today. We know too much about computer technology to be taken in by idea of 'Software in Cyberspace'.

In conclusion I will say that 'Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines' needed to strike a cord with our fears to really polish off the trilogy and those fears breed within the anxiety of 'an unknown FUTURE'.

This was, without doubt a terrible, terrible movie whose profits only have the first two instalments to thank.

title: This is an action film, thanks, not a terminator sequel: money back please, your obviously confused...
review:
I'm quite partial to the terminator series, and having been on the ''T2 - Battle Across Time'' experience at universal studios Florida, I was quite confused as why the film makers would wish to under whelm us with this run of the mill action film.

It represents a very miniscule step forward in plot. In fact an obvious, boring, idea. Which is think Cameron avoided telling us for a reason. Its blatant that the machines rise. What could have been a great trilogy in cinematic history has been reduced (as with star wars) to a money making get rich quick scheme for the producers.

I can't wait to see ''Terminator 15: liquid metal elephant across time to approximately yesterday to pick up the paper because they never got it and it had some coupons that they wanted to get 5 dollars off at the sizzler, I know its a boring story and we used the same one for all the other movies but we have a terminator elephant! come on, you have to come and see this movie'' very interesting.

title: Not That Bad.
review: Which "T" film do I think is the best? I, II & III, in that order. The first one was made on a very low budget, but I think that helped focus on the characters and the action. The second broke new ground with it's CGI but once the "ooh, aah factor" wore off it seems like an above average action movie. The third fall into the same camp as the second without the "ooh, aah factor". While Cameron's touch and Hamilton's & Furlong presence were missed I found Mostow's direction was tight and very fasted paced for what it was (I'd only seen one of his previous films BREAKDOWN, which I really liked). All in all, not as bad as I was lead to believe.

title: It almost has it.
review:
The follow up, to the movie that had already ended. it reminds me about the follow ups to the Matrix trilogy, but never mind.

I had no expectations, what so ever, to this film. Comments i've heard was'nt on the supporting side of it.

*** Spoilers everywhere! ***

It starts out with the same lines that T2 ended with. "There are no fate/destiny but the ones we make for ourself"

(or something like it)

John Connor is alone, he has no mother anymore, no father. he is on the edge of life... until he gets caught in a dog cage, trying to get awat from a kennel. At the time a female terminator is coming to that kennel to terminate both him, and a woman he knew for a long time ago. Still there is no suspension , there is no meaning of this film you think.

Then Arnold comes and saves the day, and they (John, Â´T-101 , and she.. that i couldnt remember the name to ) goes on a trip to stop judgment ay from happening. They come to about 5 places, which arent intresting at all, it feels like you've seen everyplace before (Pheraps the trailer?)

The time it changes, is when John and the Woman is flying to prevent judgment day, and Arnie's shutting down himself to "save" them. About then you start getting that old T2 "love between human and robot" feeling again. and it continues, when they accept judment day and that a war is coming. Man! its like some energy the movies builded up when it sucks, just been released.

But still, it didnt be as dark, exciting as the other ones.

So i'll give it a 7/10.

See it, its important, if you like T2

title: T3: This was a terrible, terrible movie...
review:
I was like many of you who waited, longed and prayed for the third instalment of was a simply remarkable story and exceptionally transferred to the screen by James Cameron. The Terminator (1984) and T2: Judgement Day (1991) will forever be referred to as landmark movies; the first, a dark, graphic, cult horror and the latter six years later - a visually stunning action sequel which further developed the complex narrative tale, bringing us to a mouth watering conclusion which left those of us, rather sad hardcore fan's still emotionally attached to our Terminator and begging for a third to be created someway... somehow... We all sat and thought about it didn't we? Countless times after re-watching the T2 we envisaged the third... Somehow, after clearing up the mess in the Steel Factory, some fat, hard hat wearing extra, would find Arnie's Arm and hand it to the Police... a twist and a turn later, and Skynet is a reality once more... Then... What would T3 be like? A war in the future surely? That's what we were all craving for... we had the past... we had the present, and as Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines lands before our drooling tongues... we have... the present again... (strange though, how 1991 seems to reflect reality as we know it, a whole more 'realistically' than our 2003 version.) So the narrative moves absolutely nowhere. A more credible title may have been, 'Terminator 2, and a half' and lets face it, the casting director may as well have brought in the likes of Lesley Neilson as the TX, for all the 'humour' that Mostow thought would lure the sceptical audience into 'giving the movie a chance'. But I guess with a duo of disillusionment in Nick Stahl - a weak, unconvincing development from Edward Furlong's portrayal of the rebellious John Conner and Claire Danes, a pretty but in no-way, shape or form a replacement for Linda Hamilton's hard, masculine heroine, the audience can do nothing but accept this a parody of the first two.

In my opinion, there is no need for humour in a movie narrative that was originally motivated from a deep conscious paranoia of nuclear war and technological change. T3 should have brought into contention themes that are still relevant and scare us today. We know too much about computer technology to be taken in by idea of 'Software in Cyberspace'.

This was, without doubt a terrible, terrible movie whose profits only have the first two instalments to thank.

title: Let down
review:
I remember being at school in about 1994 or thereabouts and saying to some friends that Terminator 3 was coming soon. We all looked forward to what would surely be the most amazing, extreme effects-packed film we had ever seen. Ten years later, I have seen the film and I was just embarrassed that I had made such a fuss about it all that time ago. When I heard the film was finally coming out, I couldn't wait to see it. I was totally let down and what could have been one of the best trilogies of all time has turned out to be 2 great films with a crap sequel. At what point was it decided that Terminator films were comedies? I will not be going to see Terminator 4 and will not be purchasing any T3 merchandise or DVDs.

Utter plop.

title: Very entertaining film
review: The Gov does a nice job as do the other actors.  Special effects and stunts were good.  Her-minator wasn't as menacing as Robert Patrick's T2 version, but the ending was quite good... not a typical Hollywood ending.

title: the last scene just shocked me
review:
the final scene just shocked me. The whole movie is - as I expected - just the same "great action stuff" with all the booms and chases, blow-ups and the all-important "Are you X.Z.?" "Yes?" - Bang-bang-bang scenes.

A bit unnatural is the link between John Connor and the haven't-seen-her-for-a-long-time-schoolmate C. Brewster. Making jokes in a "serious" movie is always a tough stuff (when the T101 puts on those 70's-funky sunglasses) - that's why I hate the character of JarJarbigns in SW.

btw why does the T101 need the glasses?

unfortunate the repeating of several action sequences from the previous T-movies.

good film, enjoyable - until the last scene when this film really turns into a GREAT movie. the climax is just shocking. I feel like someone just played a trick on my mind. Both the previous T-movies and the 95% of T3 is about "no fate - you can avoid the nuclear holocaust..." and at the end you see.....

title: Deja Vu
review:
This Terminator movie lacked tension.

The plot of time travel, chase, bang bang, death capped off with some introspective narration at the end is getting a little stayed in the terminator world.

Terminators travel back to the past . Terminators seek out targets. Terminators fight each other. Terminators die.

Familier ? ... yes ... Terminator 2 all over again, albeit with a twist.

I was really hoping that this film would be set in the future wars as the first two movies were essentially a chase plot, now we have a third chase plot.

The fan part of me enjoyed parts of the film though, such as the t101's battery exploding in the desert, very funny.

The story seemed to have a very sudden end to it as well, kinda like a 'don't miss the next part' feeling. Roll on T4 ! but please, no more time travel.

title: does not stand up to its predecessors.......
review:
Terminator 3 is different to its predecessors in both look and story and while it does not stand up to the first two, I think Jonathan Mostow has done a commendable job. Considering he had to follow up such highly regarded sci-fi films, the outcome is more than acceptable and does not ruin the Terminator name.

Much like his previous film Breakdown, Mostow is more concerned with keeping a breakneck pace and the level of tension high at all times. This often comes at the expense of character development and logic, but it hardly matters, as this movie is great fun from start to finish.

(Possible Spoilers)

Nick Stahl gives a reasonable performance as John Connor, who has now isolated himself from people and lives in fear. We learn that Judgement Day never occurred and was only postponed due to the events in Terminator 2. Now this time a female terminator, the TX (Kristanna Loken), has been sent back in time to stop John Connor from leading the revolution against the machines and another terminator (Arnold Schwarzenegger) has been sent to protect him. T3 principally follows the same plotline as T2 with an increased emphasis on action. The introduction of Clare Danes, as Kate Brewster, adds a strong female presence to the film and it just so happens that the writers found an inventive way to implement her into the story.

The action scenes in T3 are the highlight. What is great to see in this time of overblown CG effects is a film that is heavy on real stunts and practical special effects. The crane chase is certainly up there as one the great movie chases even surpassing the CG reliant freeway chase in The Matrix Reloaded.

T3 delivers some memorable action scenes, special effects and adequate story. Just as long as you don't expect something that will top its god-like predecessors, you will have an enjoyable ride.

7 out of 10

title: Pretty good, but it can't hold a candle to T2.
review:
POSSIBLE SPOILERS

This is a very well done action film that's really fun to watch. Acting and special effects are excellent, and Arnold is funny as usual. But it actually does disappoint somewhat, because of course Sarah is gone and John is played by a different actor. The guy who plays John does a good job, but he just doesn't seem like the same person.
