They had me cringing, noticably (putting my hands over my head in disgrace), not to mention Arnie comming out of the stipping club with his "new shades" (youve been warned) it pained me to see what this film was doing to the other 2

Obviously some people will be total suckers for it and think it's funny, but at the end of the day they have turned it into a cheesy kids version of T2, its disgusting. Right lets get this straight, T1, and T2 were serious films, thats what made them so great, T1 was a daaark film, its a masterpiece, T2 was just as good but managed to do it being a blockbuster aswell (and was also dark and serious), T3 aboloshes all of this with appaling acting, lame story, terrible one liners trying to be deliberatly funny, since when were they meant to be deliberatly funny??? Is Arnie trying to win the audience over? "Please like me again, pretty please" Argh its painfull

And since when was Arnie worth $30 million for this? That has to be the easiest money in history, he did hardly anything in here to desrve it, it wasnt even acting he just muttered some lines in a terminator voice,

Also, I did give a monkeys about Arnie and John Conner in T2, but why didnt I give a damn about em in this film? Bad acting, bad script? i dunno

It certainly lacked a biiiiig something, James Cameron, thats what

On the plus side, there was some good action, if thats what u want, but all in all I was very dissapointed, and I will laugh at people who say they like this cos they obviously dont know what a good film is, they obviously wont know what good acting is, or a good script,

I am now mentally scarred.

5/10

title: Why, why, why?
review: I am writing this review fresh from visiting my local multiplex, viewing the latest installment of the Terminator series "T3: Rise of the Machines". I am a huge fan of the first two films directed by James Cameron and can only feel sympathy for Jonothan Mostow in trying to fill those boots. But then I just ask why did he bother? Cameron wrapped the whole story up very well in the sad conclusion of T2, and I can see why he baulked at the opportunity of helming a second sequel. I can see it even more when he read the script for T3. You can only imagine the meeting. 'Hi Mr. Cameron we would like to look at our script for T3'. 'A script for T3. But that was my idea. I thought up the whole thing. Why are you making a sequel to something I ended so brilliantly the first time around?'. 'Yes Mr. Cameron, but there's going to be lots of special effects...and a big car chase...and, er'. This was the biggest problem, although The Terminator and T2 by genre are a horror and a action film respectively, Cameron did convey a convincing moral message about the future of humanity, in his storyline through the relationships of his central characters to one another. This was shown through Reece's love for Sarah Conner (which even transends time) and the most human trait of all being a mother's love for her son, between Sarah and her son John. Apposed to these very human relationships is the cold, destructive, emotionless machine, the Terminator. Unfortunatly these elements had been threwn out in the script for this film, and therefore nothing for the viewer to attach themselves too. As for the cast Arnie was dependably wooden as ever for the role of the T-101 (how he kept a straight face for some of the one liners IS amazing). I haven't seen much of Nick Stahl (played John Conner)before but he seemed wrong for the role (didn't seem to have the street smarts Ed Furlong had in T2) and Care Danes seemed to be confused as to what her role was supposed to be. The one saving grace of this film was Kristanna Loken as the T-X. She stole the film (don't the bad guys always do this?) and looked like she really relished the role, I thought she was a real jewel. Hats of again to ILM, who although not superceding anything the Matrix sequels have done (I'm assuming Matrix Revolutions will blow our socks off), they continue to impress. So overall, I thought T:3 was a bit of a waste of time, and Mr. Cameron will probably be sat smugly thinking 'I knew I was right all along!'

title: A great second sequel
review:
After watching T3 for the first time I thought I would write up my review.

T3 kicks off with an introduction by John Conner describing the way he has lived his life since the last installment, this sets up the story without having to reintroduce his character. This allows the action to flow, and boy does it come at you non-stop, watch out for the street chase, unlike another film that I will not mention, the stunts were actually done for real. T1 was an awe-inspiring concept of a story and held no punches with the violence. T2 was an epical science fiction special/visual effects extravaganza. T3 tends to fall in between in terms of violence and visual/special effects with a hint more humour than T3, most of it blatant.

The length of the film is shorter than its predecessor to ensure the film never lets up. The storyline is similar to T2 but has other elements added in to ensure that is also interesting.

Overall it's a fantastic film in my opinion, it does differ to the other two installments, but this helps to ensure that things don't become stale, although it does fall slightly short of T2 but not much.

title: Excellent!
review:
I went into this not expecting much - it's been 12 years since T2, Arny's now 56 and James Cameron's not directing.

Well, I have to admit I was pleasantly surprised. Kristanna Loken as the T-X was perfect; menacing and unstoppable throughout the film. Arny looks as impressive as he did in T2 and must have worked hard to get back into that kind of shape; it's incredible to think he's almost 60! Claire Danes was very good as the love interest and bewildered heroine of the story and Nick Stahl was excellent as the young John Connor.

The story was very good - it leads up to an exciting climax which surely paves the way for yet another Terminator sequel and the action set pieces were superb! Well done to Jonathan Mostow for pulling this off, a very enjoyable and logical addition to this important franchise.

title: Good, but not as good as T2
review:
Firstly let me start by saying "its about time they made a sequel to 1991's T2, which broke box office records for that year."

In my heart, I always knew that nothing would compare to T2. T2 gives me goosebumps when I watch it, it makes me cry. Considering its extremley far fetched, it still has meaning and looks cool.

Now T3, I'm not complaining. It was a good movie, enjoyable and the special effects were spectacular. HOwever, it didnt really feel as special as T2. It just seemed like a "movie" nothing extrodinary. In my view this kind of thing had been done before. Back in 1991, it was new fresh and exciting. Although its still exciting, its not new and fresh anymore and I was somewhat dissapointed.

ON the other hand, it was good to see Arnie back again. And yes I really enjoyed the fact that the TX was a woman. A very attractive woman, i heard yelps and howls in the cinema when we saw her behind in the begining of the film.

Nick Stahl and Claire Daines also do a good job and are believable in the characters that they play. But in my view they could have put them in better surroundings, instead of a small vet shop.

The action started off tooo quick and didnt really give the chance for the audience to get to know some of the characters or how arnie exactly found thier location in the first place, he just sort of showed up.

Furthermore, there isnt any emotion like there was in T2. Its just like the terminator was there and they didnt really develop any kind of relationship. All in all, i didnt really know what to expect when I went to see T3. I did know however, that it wouldnt have been as good as T2.

I do recomend that you go and see it, you wont be dissapointed. But chances are you might enjoy the second sequel better than the third.

title: Surprisingly enjoyable.
review:
The Terminator and Terminator 2:Judgment Day are, respectively, a science fiction classic, and a worthy sequel to a science fiction classic. They are both brilliantly written and directed by James Cameron, the finest action director in the world. As well as being excellent action-packed stories, they have great emotional impact and contain an interesting message about the value of human life. They also manage to be simultaneously pessimistic and optimistic as the heroes of the story struggle to prevent a future apocalypse. Whether or not they succeed is left brilliantly ambiguous.

The close of Terminator 2 seemed like a fantastic ending. Continuing it, I always thought would be a truly terrible idea, especially with James Cameron not at the helm. Therefore, Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines sounded like a cynical exercise in revitalising Arnold Schwarzenegger's flagging career. Unlike the first two films, it has not been made for any artistic or creative reason.

It comes as a great surprise then, that Terminator 3 is actually rather enjoyable. It's nowhere near as good as its illustrious predecessors, but its certainly more entertaining than, say, The Matrix Reloaded. Although director Jonathan Mostow lack's Cameron's flair, he's always solid and delivers some fine action set pieces. Unfortunately, that's all he does deliver. Terminator 3 is full of action, but it has precious little character development and lacks the emotional core of the earlier films. That is, until the last five minutes of the film which I won't spoil here.

The plot is the same as ever, with Arnold Schwarzenegger's T-800 terminator once more sent back in time to protect John Conner (Nick Stahl) from yet another terminator upgrade, the female T-X (Kristanna Loken). The T-X is a kind of cross between the liquid metal terminator of Terminator 2 and Arnie's mechanical version. However, this time it has other targets beside Conner, including his wife-to-be Kathryn Brewster (Claire Danes). It transpires the nuclear war Conner thought had been prevented in Terminator 2 has only been `postponed' (completely destroying the logic of previous instalments). This leads to a race against time, which fails to be anywhere near as suspenseful as it should be.

The cast are all good, if unremarkable. However, the script has an annoying habit of delivering the signature dialogue with a nod and a wink. Lines like `Come with me if you want to live' and `I'll be back' no longer have the resonance they had in the earlier films, and simply become irritating. As for Arnie, he's good, but no longer has the edge he had in the earlier films. I doubt this film will resurrect his career.

title: Has a lot to live up to...
review:
Right I'll say it now - the best was the first, the second best was Judgement day and this new installment finishes in last place. It lacks the dramatic impact, the cool, sophisticated direction or the "feel" of the last two movies. This doesn't however make this film bad, as it was rather entertaining, a lot better than The Matrix Reloaded, or any other films this year(except Whale Rider and Pirates of the ...). The action is pretty relentless, and well done, with great camera work, some pretty violent scenes (for a 12A) and great set pieces - the toilet scene between Arnie and Loken is great, perfect action scene - much better than the overblown rubbish seen in Matrix Reloaded. All of the action is tied together with great special effects, which, while not as stunning as T2 in its day, is great work. Highlights are Arnies face being smashed in, and Loken's character having all her metal come off.

Acting is good, especially from Nick Stahl, who did well to carry on the role of Furlongs John Conner. He plays it with great style and makes us feel that this character has a burden to carry. Claire Danes is okay as Conners girl, yet she lacks depth, and just seems to be shouting and screaming. Oh well. Arnie is really good, he plays the terminator role with ease, yet some scenes he seems to playing a parody of his formr roles as the machine. Also he isn't quite as well equipped in the one liners department, and seems to just get stuff from the prequels. Still overall, he is good, and really doesn't look his age! Lastly, Loken plays the bad guy in this movie, and although she is the worst "baddie" the series has seen (I'll say Arnies first role was the most menacing, T2 had the most cool), she still had lots of impressive tricks up her sleeve. Or cleveage. Her acting was good, menacing and brooding, just like a killing machine should be like. So far so good, good action scenes, consistent acting - whats missing? Other than James Cameron, whose flair is obviously lacking, it's the music. The great theme tune from the prequels is gone, which left me cold in some scenes, and the action scenes lacked some oomph because of this. The music, if included, would have made this movie a little better - more tense. Overall, a good action flick, not as good as the first two masterpieces, but a worthy addition to the series nonetheless. It seems to have been catered for the spoilt brats of the cinema going audience, as it's only a 12A, yet it still had some gruesome moments, and overall is very entertaining.

8 out of 10

PS Much better than Reloaded!

title: Derivative action movie but perfectly entertaining...
review:
Well, I have to say that I enjoyed T3. It was not a taught B-movie thriller like T1, or a faultless big budget sci-fi classic like T2, but it certainly entertained for 2 hours without getting boring. (I couldn't say the same of the other summer blockbuster I saw recently, "Hulk". I had to see that twice to check I wasn't imagining how BAD it was the first time.)

***** contains mild SPOILERS ******

T3 doesn't really bother trying to explain why Terminators even continue to exist post the seemingly "final" events of T2, instead it attempts to capture the audience's attention, with the promise of some impressive stunts, action sequences and effects (right from the opening shot of a nuclear detonation), and a large helping of "more of the same".

It certainly delivers on more of the same, with some great action sequences (T-X driving the crane was particularly good), nice effects, and constant pursuit of John Connor by a particularly mean, seeming unstoppable (and this time not unattractive) machine (apologies to Robert Patrick!), which again is defeated in an ingenious manner.

Where it fell down for me was:

1) it lacked the originality of either of it's predecessors, both in terms of plot, and in terms of set pieces (I guess there are only so many ways a machine can bash another machine into a wall repeatedly, but Arnie shooting up loads of cops then do a "000" count of human victims? Surely we've seen that before!) 2) it had a few too many attempts at humour (that is how we spell "humor" it in England BTW), which I think robbed it of the tension of the earlier movies. For ever slice of "talk to the hand" genius, there was a dog line ("I'm back!" was easily the worst).

But overall, it was more fun to watch than a lot of blockbusters I've seen recently. I'm not likely to hold my breath for the DVD, but i'd recommend seeing it, just don't expect to be blown away the way T2 would have done.

title: As I expected-James Cameron and the others did best to avoid
review:
Arnie should self terminate..and if he can't, someone else should write the program for him..as this sequel is truly abysmal..and those who think it is good are very easily pleased.

The previous director James Cameron and the actors who gave this a wide berth were wise in their decision not to be associated with this.

The fact that the music of the first 2 films was all but missing, bar a hint of it here and there, was a major let down in itself as it was a major contribution to the success of the first two films..the composer probably had no desire to be associated with it either!

Nothing new in the action....ya de ya de ya...need I go on...save your money!!

I give it a 3/10.

title: MUCH better than was expected
review:
The key to T3 is not to go in with high expectations; think of it as it's going to be like "The Matrix Reloaded". The outcome, at least for me, was that I wasn't disappointed. It is a decent summer popcorn flick that lives up to its predecessors. It's definitely ten times better than the second Matrix in all aspects: storyline, special effects, acting. Yes, sure it could have been better; nevertheless T3 is probably the best action movie of this kind since the first Matrix.

Arny was good in his role as hi was in the previous two installments. He was born for this role no doubt about it. The only thing that annoyed me was that he was "programmed" to talk too much. The creators of the movie should've found another way to explain what was happening. Maybe I'm wrong but it just felt a little bit more than was needed. Even the self-parodying lines were too many and not so cool. Moving on to Kristanna Loken (T-X) I'd say she tried her best to fill in the shoes of Robert Patrick who's gonna be remembered forever (whether he likes it or not) with his role in T2 as T-1000. The idea of a sexy terminatrices was a very good indeed, however due to writing limitations the character wasn't explored well enough which brings me to the second problem with this movie. T-X being much more sophisticated and tough to deal with after all was destroyed by our man so much easier than he did T-1000. And what was all this dismantling and screaming at the end. Anyway, I think the best acting came from Claire Danes probably the most convincing one. As I think again Nick Stahl performance was not bad at all. Actually the whole casting was pretty good as were the special effects. The CGI were kept to minimum which was good, very good ... sorry I am having again some flash backs from the CGI in the second Matrix - terrible. Let me get back to T3. I think I can't. I am too upset now.

While T3 is not as original and memorable as T1 and T2 classics, it still manages to deliver what is set out to do- a high-budget, cold metal entertainment for the hot summer days. For all the fans of the "Terminator" franchise and for all those disappointed with the second Matrix and just for all of you out there I recommend this movie. The first group won't be disappointed, the second will be relieved and the third, well I just hope you like it.

title: Crash, bang, wallop, BOOM, but somethings missing.
review:
After a gap of over 10 years I was a bit hesitant about watching the third part of the story, and left the theatre with mixed emotions, as although good with a stunning main chase sequence something was missing in T3, and it was the darkness and hard edge of T1 and T2 that Cameron produced.

It was strange not seeing Linda Hamilton, and her character dieing of leukaemia and then cremation tangent to remove her character just somehow didn't sound right considering what a strong character she'd developed into in T2.

Big Arnie was as awesome on screen as only he can be, but he's starting to look his age, and at times I got the feeling he was playing his character for laughs, and with clinches going back to T1 and T2. But, why didn't he kill anyone besides the TX, he is after all a terminator? I hope it isn't due to south California PC attitudes getting into the movies. Plus with a possible nuclear war coming the story wasn't as stressful and dark as it should have been.

Beautiful Kristanna Loken was very efficient as the unfeeling TX, but she's not as cold as Robert Patrick was in T2, but she was one ice maiden as emotionless and as ruthless given that T3 has a different feel to T2.

Nick Stahl although a bit whiney at the start, and Claire Danes in a very ballsey role grew into their respective characters, and if T4 to finish the story off gets made before Arnie gets to old they can develop and mature their characters.

On a lighter note it was nice to see Earl Boen again although like Arnie he's now showing his age, but it was a case of blink and you'd miss his small part.

As for 'Skynet' I hope more of how it works is explained in T4, as we only got a taste of the nature of the chief villain.

In conclusion, I personally think to long has passed between T2 and T3, and if Cameron isn't going to direct T4, I hope Jonathan Mostow gives T4 the cold dark edge of T1 and T2 to get back some lost ground.

I give T3 8 out of 10 for the great stunts and a good foundation for the final movie.

title: It is time for more action
review:
I had heard rumours that this movie wasn't that good so I was getting nervous when I sat down to watch it. I came out extremely satisfied that the movie was VERY good. I won't spoil the storyline but it is so open for a Terminator 4 at the end that I wouldn't be surprised if we see another addition to the series soon. Only problem with that is if they don't shoot the movie soon then Arnie would be too old. Back to the film. Although not as dark as the first Terminator movie, this brings alot of realism to the fact that we are in a nuclear age and the graphic reality of a possible nuclear war. I left the movie feeling happy with the special effects (but Arnie still can't act) but a bit depressed with the ever possible threat of, apart from Terminators running around, the severe threat of our own real life nuclear war. Let's face it the amount of computers that do control our defence systems in this country could always malfunction and any backup system to prevent this from happening could also go wrong as well. Depressed you yet????? Think about it........

(Slight spoiler) The budget of this movie was amazing (I have forgotten the actual figure but I think it's around 170 million US dollars) and one can see where they blew alot of their cash, like the first chase scene with a fire truck and a large crane truck through the streets pursing John Connor. Wow that was good. I was expecting more T800's running around in an extended futuristic scene at the beginning and one can only hope that in T4 there will be. I had heard that there was about 10 minutes of T800's shooting at the beginning but T2 had more of that than this one so I was disappointed. I also feel that the UK cinema rating (BBFC) organization must of had a back hand deal from the movie studios to reduce the certification as it's "R" in the states and over here it's 12a. For non UK citizens this means that children under the age of 12 can attend to view but must be accompanied by an adult. (Spoiler) Well for those who have watched it, would you really want a 7 year old to see the scene in the cop car where the TX is controlling the steering wheel through the cops stomach that it just punched through??? Gross!!! This movie should have been a 15 in the UK and shame on the BBFC for not doing so. Watch this movie for serious Hollywood big budget special effect action and see just how depressing they leave the ending - T4 must be round the corner, hopefully Arnie won't be drawing his pension when they get around to shooting it. Make sure the cinema you view this film in has a great sound system as you will love all the explosions and bullets flying around you.

title: T3 is rubbish
review: Well, this may be the most over rated film of the year,  The trailers are rubbish and the film isn't really any better.  The script is rubbish, the action scenes are rubbish, the script is rubbish, the acting is poor, the female terminator is woeful.  The film is just unbelievably bad.  The only good things in the film are Arnie, looking a lot better than I thought he would and the ending, which is interesting and can make up for much but not enough.

title: Wow! Here's a sequel that delivers the goods
review: Incredible. Who could have guess that a Terminator film without James Cameron can be this good? Seeing the trailers, this seemed like another stupid action flick trying to make money out of the Terminator name. Well, how far from the truth I was!!!! There's actually a script that develops the story and characters we all love and takes us into new and exciting ways. You just have to see the end to see what I mean. Arnie....Oh my god!!! Just when I thought his career was over here comes the proof that given the proper material he kicks booty!!!! Kudos to Jonathan Mostow. I loved his first outing (Breakdown) and didn't care much for U-571, but Rise of the machines is one exception to the rule big summer blockbusters are just mindless s***. I never thought a third film could be that good.

title: Disappointing
review: Sure, Terminatrix is Hot, but it is not utilized in any manner Sure sure, the action parts are ok, but nothing new or exceptional - I mean a car chasing scene using heavy vehicles has been seen before (where was it now - oh that's right in T2) No new cool gimmicks or robot-abilities - reuse of the melting robot adding weaponry does not make it up for something new - Terminatrix is more of a T2 meets Robocop. The cast is playing like wet cardboard in a recycling dumpster The lines must have been picked up in a box labelled "Corny" - "My Fathers plane - I have been training in that"... Though Arnold's referring to some of his older lines are funny, but...

title: Don't Terminate this!!!
review:
One of the most awaited fills of the year... you cannot afford to miss this brilliantly done film. The acting, directing and special effect (oh my gawd!!! the special effects)... all add together to give you one hell of a film!

The car chase... well... it outs The Matrix to shame! The TX has been designed to really scare the living heck outta you, while at the same time (towards the end), showing you true fear.

Seriously though, if you want to see a flick that everyone else is going to see, and at the same time... enjoy it with them... then GO AND SEE THIS.

For its action, tension and supremely good looking cast... I am going to have to give this one 10 flaps out of 10.

title: What a way to go...
review: Having not seen either of the first two movies at the cinema, I had to see this one, to make up for lost time. I don't think it is as good as the others, but it is as good as can be expected, considering the fact that the storyline had seemingly reached its end in 1991. There are some flat scenes, but these are far outnumbered by the terrific action sequences which make you just sit there in awe at the apparent real-life mayhem caused, particularly in the first set-piece, which must be one of the all-time great carnage spectacles, although I thought the crash in 'Final Destination 2' was pretty magnificent, too. Arnie is back with a vengeance, and somehow his acting, although still very much tongue in cheek, is quite good here. The grown-up John Connor is OK, and Claire Danes is adequately effective, if in the Ist Division to Linda Hamilton's Premier one. However, the main attraction here is the beautifully evil and totally believable Katrianna Loken. Her screen presence is enormous, and she acts with such confidence that it all seems perfectly plausible that the next high-tech generation of Terminators would be women...after all, they are taking over the world, aren't they? The film is worth seeing for the amazing stunts, and to marvel at KL's beauty, which, literally, knocks you out. As I said, if she's the Terminator, what a way to go...

title: T3 Death of the franchise
review:
I saw this turkey whit an open and virgin mind. I had managed to avoid all trailers and spoilers and had no preconceptions about the movie. This WAS an important movie and deserved my full first time reaction to it. Sadly this movie is Episode I&II, Alien 4 and Robocop 3 all over again. Atypical Hollywood third act in a brilliant series UNTIL NOW! As you can read from the goofs page and see in the movie some one didn't do their home work and didn't pay attention on the set, reading the script and in editing! Mr. Mostow what have you got to say for your self? This is a pitiful sequel! The plot AND action are SO full of holes that you can use this as a fishing net. The future will agree whit the people who think this is scum. T3 will end up being the almost unmentioned third movie in the DVD box set. Most people will newer even take it out of the box. Why would you want to? Who wants to invite the guy that spoils the party? The premise promises a watch able movie, but the execution fall flat on its face. It manages to fly for about 45 minutes if you excuse the constant "action" bloopers that you are used to seeing in 80's action but this is T3 not Commando 2. All I can hope is that T4 is newer made and they release a dir.cut DVD whit 60 min of new footage (please omit 30 min from the end!) and 20 min of added length. There are only 2 good thins in T3 the new terminator, she is sexy and a nice "robot" and the nasty action in the beginning in the T1 style of "are you Sarah Connor? BANG!" They should have gotten Paul Verhoeven to direct...

Please don't buy this DVD.

title: Worthwhile and exciting third entry in the Terminator trilogy
review:
While it's not as gripping and wickedly entertaining as the original, Terminator 3 is still well worth the wait and is an exhilarating experience from start to finish.

The action never lets up and there is no sugarcoating the nonstop brutal violence of the film. Kristanna Loken as the T-X is very hot and stone cold in her role as her emotionless killer robot. Arnie is great once again, proving that no-one does the terminator better than him. Apart from that he is also in amazing shape for his age and his physical presence is still very intimidating and overwhelming in the film. Whereas T2 deals with preventing judgement day and the end of the world for humans, T3 deals with preparing for it and the rise of the machines.

My only criticisms are that Edward Furlong should have kept his role as John Connor. Also Sarah Connor just being abandoned in the story is wrong in my opinion and the casting of Claire Danes seems to have been thrown in just for grins. But the movie does have some very funny moments, which are a blessing. The special effects are the most mind-blowing in the series so far, and the action scenes are never less than spectacular. So if you are an Arnie or Terminator fan, or just a moviegoer in my opinion, T3 is without a doubt a must-see. Along with The Matrix Reloaded, T3 is definitely my fav film of the year.

I give Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines an 8/10.

title: 'We'll meet again'
review:
Like a good Terminator fan-boy, I reacted with child-like excitement when I first heard that there would be a T3. That excitement soon turned to disappointment and eventually despair when I learned that James Cameron would not return to direct, and Linda Hamilton and Edward Furlong would not reprise their roles as the Connors.

But then the reviews started to come in, and I was given hope... but then I remembered feeling the same way about The Phantom Menace and coming out of the cinema feeling like a part of my life had just been stolen. So, I promised myself I would not give in to the hype. I would be prepared for a bad Terminator movie.

I needn't have bothered! This film rocks!

Okay, so it doesn't top the mind-bogglingly epic all round perfection of T2, but it's still a helluva film, and a worthy addition to the series. The story is a good one, and it fleshes out the Terminator universe in ways you might not expect. It also raises interesting questions about fate vs. determinism that my brain still hasn't fully digested (hey, I just got back from the cinema five minutes ago!), and which provide the perfect excuse to watch the old films just one more time...

Nick Stahl is excellent as John Connor. In T2 we saw how Sarah had transformed from a fluffy pink girl into the action queen, hardened by the knowledge that she had to prepare John for Judgement Day. Well, time has had a different effect on her son. Haunted by nightmares of Judgement Day, living in denial about the events of T2, he is forever paranoid that one day the machines will come back for him. His fear has made him weak, and when Judgment Day comes, he doesn't feel ready. Stahl portrays this self-doubt brilliantly, while never leaving the audience in doubt that he really is the one who will lead the resistance.

Claire Danes is also good as the woman who finds her life drawn into chaos, trying to make sense of the fact that this unfamiliar path is in fact her destiny. She has just the right balance of human frailty and future-heroine-badassness.

Earl Boen makes a welcome cameo, though his role is really nothing more than an easter egg for Terminator geeks. The other supporting actors are good enough in their respective roles, but very little screen time is given to any minor characters.

Kristianna Loken isn't nearly as menacing as Robert Patrick was, but then the film isn't really about the heroes vs. the T-X in the way that T1 and T2 were about the protagonists vs. Arnie and Robert Patrick respectively. Certainly, the film needed a Terminator that was different to the original two, and sequel logic dictates that she had to be more dangerous than either of them. She was, but she didn't scare the s**t out of me the way the other two did.

Last, but certainly not least, the man himself. He said he'd be back, and he wasn't lying. Arnie's part is well written  he is not the Terminator that was incinerated at the end of T2, and neither does he follow that Terminator's character arc. I was hoping for more to be made of the 'is he good or bad' plot device that was promised to us, but I guess there wasn't really room. Of course, it was great to have Arnie  it wouldn't have been a Terminator movie without him  but at times I felt he was playing the part for laughs, which felt wrong. Even though some of his lines were genuinely funny, I thought that Mostow should have resisted the temptation and kept the tone darker.

Naturally, there will be die-hards who will refuse to accept that a new Terminator movie could possibly be anything other than sacrilege, but I would suggest they go see it anyway. The sooner they see it, the sooner the nostalgia will set in and they can feel about T3 the same as they feel about T2 and T1. (Let's face it, T2 was a completely different movie to T1, but we still love it, so give T3 a chance.) Jonathon Mostow has brought the series to a point that if T4 were made, it wouldn't even need a leading role for Arnie, provided that Stahl and Danes are available. (He would have to appear at some point, but as a bad guy. His statement to Connor 'We'll meet again' wasn't so much a promise as a future historical fact  if you go see T3 you'll see what I mean about half way through.)

And there should be a T4. Mostow has proved that even without Cameron, this is a franchise worth building on. (And let's face it, Jimbo seems to have lost his way lately anyway.) There is still a huge story to tell.

title: Not sure why they told us this story
review: I came out of this movie with mixed emotions. The special effects were good, the chases were tense and the backstory of this new Terminator's relationship with John Connor was clever. Still, there was a fatalism throughout the movie that reduced the impact of the ending. The movie essentially says to us, "This is the way things will turn out...things are turning out as I predicted...I was right, this was the way turned out." Not only does this ruin suspense, but it also means that whenever someone dies in the picture, instead of pitying the dead, we shrug and move on. It alienates us from the movie and its characters when we want to feel close, and by the end my reaction to the story paralleled that of the kid in The Princess Bride who screams, "Jeez, grampa, why did you want to tell me this story!"

title: not as bad as I thought it would be
review:
I've seen this movie twice now - once on my own when I was a little bit drunk (and therefore not paying too much attention) and once with a friend when relatively sober. The first time I hated it - thought it was a cheap rip off - stealing scenes and lines from the original two movies. The second time I saw it I was starting to warm towards it and took the scene and line stealing as what I am sure it was intended, a homage to the first movies.

The action scenes were fairly good - Arnie could still cut it reasonably well as the terminator despite his age. The new terminator resembled the characteristics (the mannerisms not the physicality) of the T-1000 (Robert Patric) from T2 and this sorts of fits with the whole improved terminator line, i.e. less robotic more human. There were some glaring holes which although I tried hard I could not ignore

Spoiler possibility (I will keep as vague as possible) The secret base was stunningly unguarded, in fact most of the military establishments appear to have an open door policy for strangers :-)

I won't go into anymore but there are some

One of the things I did not like at all was the development of the John Connor character. This I feel betrayed the first 2 movies. In the first movie, Sarah Connor starts off weak and becomes strong. In the second movie, John Connor starts off strong and gets stronger. In the third movie John Connor appears to have had a personality change. He seems like a frightened and confused child - not at all like the strong willed resourceful character from the second film. This grated on me a bit as he seemed very whiny and weak in this movie.

The ending was reasonably good - covering the "The future is not fixed" sort of scenario and therefore allowing the rules to be broken from one movie to the next in a reasonably sensible way (As sensible as you can get with time travel movies).

Summary Direction - nice and fast paced - all you would expect from a T2 movie. Acting - mmmm, ok - but then again you are not expecting Shakespeare here Script - Some corny lines but generally sufficient Story - Reasonably good

6/10

title: I'll be back...for more!
review:
I went to the UK preview viewing. Thought the T3 action scenes were very good. Good story line too. The ending asks the question will there be a T4? I think so. Only problem was that I wanted the old cast of T2 to be in this film.

Regards, CE.

title: Perhaps one of the best sequels ever.
review:
Can Arnie hack it a third time? You bet! - and in one of the best sequels ever. (minor spoilers follow).

Whilst building on T1 & 2, Rise of the Machines is also a self-contained film in its own right.

John Connor, now in his early twenties, is being pursued by a female terminatrix android from the future, determined that he will not live to defeat the machines in the post-apocalyptic endgame. He teams up with Kate Brewster (Clare Danes) who is also to have a key part in saving mankind's future, whilst Arnie comes back as a re-programmed terminator to defend them both.

For fans of Episodes 1 and 2, Rise of the Machines fills in some necessary history, and does it well. For newcomers, this treat is no money-machine pap growing fat on the name of its predecessors: Terminator 3 is well scripted, well directed, and (as far as such one-dimensional characters require it) well acted. But the thing that really makes it is the excellent pacing and editing that keeps the suspense going through climax after climax. Of course it's still mainstream Hollywood - but, in the wake of so many brainless and nondescript CGI-overloads, this sequel stands and delivers

title: Good for the Hype
review:
I watched the T3 flick a few weeks back and I have to say that it passed the action ratings barnone. As with the storyline, well, I can say that it couldn't have ended in any other way. (spoiler?) The effects were great but the CGI couldve been a bit more polished? Im not a big fan on CGI media especially when you can really tell that its CG. Unlike the fight scene in Matrix:Reloaded where Neo kicked ass in the park. That CG was wayyyyy too unrealalistic.

The big disappointment was the script though. You'll find the Terminator to say some sharp remarks more now than previous movies. Too much "I'll be back", "She'll be back", "He'll be back", "I'm back", "We're back"... get on with the movie will you?!

Arnold was the great Terminator again and to be honest he looks better now than he was in T2. Although I dont think machines are supposed to age...

Rating: 8 1/2 of 100 = MUST SEE!

title: After all that.
review:
WARNING THIS MAY CONTAIN MASSIVE SPOILERS READ AT OWN RISK.

The 3rd installment of the popular Terminator trilogy has been released and i of course had to see it. After the whole, What could it be an hour and a half? i managed to say to words "s*** house!" now Dont get me wrong, the movie was not that bad to watch, but my peeves are this

1. too short 2.Arnie sux as this robot, i mean the guy Actually kills john conner and than gets sent back to help him for gods sake! 3.S****y ending

After taking all these things into account i give it a 3....but then where would it be without those exelent Special effects..After disregarding the plot, spending lots of time watching the pretty colors, and remembering that they are going to make a 4th (probally) i give the movie 7 out of ten....5 being way below par. so i guess if all you want is a good solid hour of killing, big bangs....and a bit of boobies from the TX this movie is good for a rentle, but i would not recommend watching this movie before T1 and T2....ok this is Princey out. Enjoy the movie.

title: I want my 9 dollars back
review: I must preface this review with saying I was never a big fan of the Terminator franchise. That being said, the movie was terrible. I knew going into it that it wasn't going to be the next Citizen Cane, but this movie was missing many fundamental features of a movie. First they relied way to heavily on the prior movies explaining this one. Unless you watched the first two, the movie didn't make much sense. I think Velveeta made this movie, because it was cheesy. All of the silly cliché catch phrases made me wonder if it was on purposed to mock itself or mock us. Arnold should be ashamed of himself for even uttering some of those lines. There was no real plot development; it was more like one giant chase scene(which was very cool). I mean if that's what you're interested in.... That brings us to the end of the movie. It was like a cliff, it just stopped short. And that was quite a romance at the end too. How many guys have heard the phrase `not if you were the last guy on earth,' while trying to pick up chicks. Who would ever thought one of us would actually have to worry about that?

title: Too much bad Sci-Fi, too little suspense
review:
Oh great, flying robot gunships and robot half-tracks. Is this "Star Wars"? And the Terminator battling for his own soul scene was old when Spock used to do it in '60s on "Star Trek". The second half of T3 is as mis-directed as the Terminatix's mission, which keeps changing. Besides the hoary cliche scene where the Terminator is wrestling for his soul, there are several scenes where you can sense the movie go off track: 1) In T2, during the "Hasta la vista" scene, the T-1000 begins to reform right before his prey, heightening their horror. But in T3, when Stahl and Danes have impaled and they assume left for dead the Terminatrix on the supermagnet, they are long gone on some other adventure by the time she begins to free herself. 2) Why does she need a gun to kill her victims when she can shoot electrical bolts? 3) How do the heavily-armed Terminator and the kids enter the secret Air Force base? How does the Terminatrix?

So much is left unexplained, in comparison to T2, in which you get to see how the T-1000 stalked its prey. But in T3, the Terminatrix just disappears from the screen for long stretches of talk about "man's destiny" blah, blah. In T3, she and all characters just show up whenever they're needed, miraculously!

title: Enjoyable in its own right...
review:
T3 is a great movie. In a way, it's everything a great action movie should be and nothing it shouldn't. It contains some good-ol' fashioned action movie elements like car-chases, explosions, combat scenes, etc. It also contains the mandatory odd humour and romantic undertones. However, just like with any action movie, there are flaws, and since this is a sequel to one of the best action movies of all time, these flaws are perhaps more serious.

In all honesty, a third Terminator film should never have been made, even IF James Cameron came on board again. T2 pretty much wrapped things up as Cyberdyne was destroyed, thus eliminating any chance of a machine-dominated future. The plot of T3 makes T2's plot null-and-void. One cannot help but feel that the entire integrity of T2 is destroyed: it's like the events that happened in T2 were meaningless. T3 was obviously created to needlessly cash-in on the Terminator franchise.

However, if you somehow succeed in forgetting everything you knew about the first two films, T3 wouldn't seem all that bad. As mentioned, it was made well and you do get a sense of closure at the end of the film, which is increasingly rare to find in films these days. While the script is somewhat inconsistent and the dialogue crude, the movie as a whole stands up pretty well, thanks to some great action sequences. Personally, I didn't like the idea that T-800 wasn't the same protector as the one we learned to love in T2. His character fails to develop as he did in T2. In fact, Arnold's character seems to combine the best parts of the T-800 from the first film and the second one. Nick Stahl does a great job portraying John Connor, albeit giving him a new sense of values. I would've preferred to see Edward Furlong reprising his character as there was clearly a chemistry between him and Schwarzenegger in the second film. Stahl definitely has the qualities of a man leading others against the machines, but I got used to Furlong playing bratty child-like Connor.

Apart from these flaws, the movie is otherwise very enjoyable to watch. I think director Mostow did a fine job in creating an entertaining movie, especially keeping in mind what he was following up to...

title: Terminator 3 revamps the legacy
review:
There's a lot to get excited about here folks but first let me start by saying right off the bat, this aint Terminator 2 (T2), nor does it come close. Well there are moments but what are sheer moments when you have an entire film, right? T2 is both a stroke of sci-fi and action splendour. There are not many films, old or new, that can match its ferocity and grandeur.

Most of the films success must surely be credited to director Jonathan Mostow. You ought to feel so small coming up against a giant like this. His direction was superb. That includes the nicely choreographed action scenes that dominate from start to finish in the relatively short running time. The soon-to-be-famous demolition crane scene elatedly swept me back to the days of T2 and the strength of that film. Though being several years in transition (twelve years to be precise) Arnie is still in top gear. It is as though he was made for these films, robots suite his range as an actor quite perfectly.

Score: 3 out of 5, Matt Noske

title: The Best Movie Of 2003 And By A Land Slide
review:
After all the garbage I've seen this summer (The Matrix Reloaded, Hulk, and X-Men 2), I was glad to finally see a good movie (Terminator 3). Not only was Terminator 3 good, it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. The story was great, the Terminatrix was awesome (better then the T-100), the action was intense, the ending was perfect, and Arnold was funny as hell.

Terminator 3 is by far the best movie of 2003 and it will still be the best movie of 2003 when the year is over. Even Return Of The King won't beat it and Return Of The King is sure to be one of the best movies ever made.

There was one thing missing from Terminator 3 and that was the Terminator music. It was played during the end credits but who know why they left it out during the entire movie. If Terminator 3 has the Terminator music, I would actually say that Terminator 3 was perfect. Getting over this minor fault, Terminator 3 easily made it on to my top 10 movies of all time list. This is saying a lot since 8 out of the other 9 of them are from the 80's or earlier.

As much as I love Terminator 3, Terminator 2 is slightly better. Terminator 2 makes it one place higher then Terminator 3 on my top 10 movies of all time list. This is due to it being a longer movie and having the Terminator music played quite a few time through out it. Neither one of these things is a big deal but it helped me decide which movie I liked better.

If you haven't seen Terminator 3 already then do yourself a favor and see it right away. If you have seen Terminator 3 and didn't like it then see it again because you obviously missed something.

title: Enjoy the ride...again.
review:
**Warning! Mild Spoilers Ahead!**

"T-3" is a straightforward picture, setting the stage in the opening twenty minutes, then propelling its characters into what is basically a chase movie for the final hour and a half. Sound familiar? Well, why mess with success? Although it may sound boring and routine, the movie is neither. The script and pacing are both tight and constantly in motion, leaving no time for boredom.

The plot of "T-3" is pretty much the same as that of its predecessors. The machines have sent a new and improved terminator, in this case a stunning T-X played by the smokin' Kristanna Loken, back in time from the future to kill someone who will eventually lead the humans in their fight against the machines. Naturally the humans also managed to sneak back their own terminator, albeit an older model, the T-800. This is of course Arnold Schwarzenegger (although not the same robot as in T-2), and he must prevent the T-X from accomplishing her mission.

What separates "T-3" from lighter summer fare such as "Pirates" or "The Italian Job" is the effective philosophy. While not quite up to the high standard of "T-2" or "The Matrix", it still churns the mind with its issues of fate and time travel. Go ahead, try to completely figure out how a machine from the future can go back in time to affect events that ultimately create the machine itself. Despite the density, every event that takes place makes perfect sense both within the movie and within the trilogy.

Schwarzenegger is once again at his best, as the simple-minded and stoic T-800. He slides easily back into the character, and even at age 56 is still a perfect physical and vocal fit. Some say that the role doesn't demand much of Arnold, but perhaps he does it so effortlessly that we don't notice. Either way, seeing him back at the top of his acting game is a pleasure, after such mediocre fare as "Collateral Damage" and "The 6th Day".

Nick Stahl, no longer "In the Bedroom", fits into the part of a twenty-something John Connor with ease. He provides Connor with the proper world-weariness and gives him grounded logic and street smarts that befit someone who has grown up under his unusual circumstances.

Loken, much like Robert Patrick in the second movie, doesn't get to display much versatility, but her icily gorgeous eyes and facial features combine with appropriate body movements to supply the T-X with a chilly and imposing aura. She's not quite as fearsome as Patrick, perhaps because she's female; but her character's unstoppable nature is enough to compensate for that.

Claire Danes, in a role that one might not expect to find her, is Kate Brewster. She happens upon Connor at her veterinary clinic, and is properly naive, much like Neo in "The Matrix", as she gets sucked into the tidal wave of action and adventure. The rest of the actors, in mostly little-developed parts, are sufficient to round out the cast.

The comedy in "T-3" was an unexpected enjoyment. Much of it was derived from Schwarzenegger's machine mind failing to comprehend various aspects of humanity, verbal and otherwise. Arnold's classic monotone delivery is perfect, both in tone and timing. Other comedic sources included a number of references to the prior films. Some are obvious ("She'll be back"); some are less so (the reappearing shrink). But they are all amusing, providing necessary comic relief for a movie that could easily have been overbearing and overly serious. One other amusing theme is the one-upmanship involved in various stunts and chase scenes. Things just keep getting bigger, and I couldn't help but laugh. "T-3" wasn't bust-a-gut funny, but it consistently induced chuckling from the audience in a number of ways.

One of the joys of "T-3" is the physicality of the stunt and fight sequences. Because of the virtual immortality of the two terminators, brutal acts of violence are necessary when fighting them, acts that can't be done to normal humans. There's something painfully (sadistically?) enjoyable about watching someone bashing a foe with a just-ripped-off-the-wall urinal, or seeing a truck slam straight into a building. I found myself constantly wincing, but also grinning at the same time. Seeing someone get the crap beat out of them while knowing the characters won't actually be injured is surprisingly, perhaps frighteningly, engrossing. Additionally, those scenes appear to be mostly stuntwork, not CGI. Contrasting the highway chase scene in "Matrix Reloaded", which is gloriously sleek and jaw-dropping, the car chase in "T-3" is brutal and punishing. In a cinematic time that favors heavy reliance on computer imagery, that honest physicality in stuntwork is extremely refreshing.

This is a movie that should be seen on the big screen, preferably one with a high quality surround sound system. The theater I patronized was unfortunately lacking in the aural department, as the audio was front-heavy. But I still appreciated the sound. Without being overly loud, the sound effects did their job quite well, providing the proper noises at the proper times. The score was not very noticeable, which means that composer Marco Beltrami did his job suitably. Somewhat surprisingly, the recognizable Terminator theme of Brad Fiedel did not surface until the end of the movie (unless I missed it).

The other reason I recommend the theater experience is the bigness of the flick. Like its prequels, "T-3" is simply a large movie. Arnold is big; various vehicles are big; themes are big; everything is done on a grand scale. Plus the picture looks good. With machines as a primary subject, the film is conducive to a slick appearance, and cinematographer Don Burgess ("Cast Away", "Bourne Identity") delivers a gleaming final cut.

If you haven't seen the first two renditions, you'll definitely miss out on some of the jokes, and won't have a full understanding of everything discussed, but you can still enjoy the film. I recommend seeing the other two first, but it's not entirely necessary. The presence of Kate, also a newbie to the world of terminators, allows John Connor and the T-800 to explain much of the backstory without seeming dry. Taking a cue from the original, most of the exposition wisely occurs on the run, so it doesn't slow the movie down, but rather fills in the blanks of the plot while still moving forward.

Not comparing "T-3" to its predecessors is impossible. This one isn't quite as cultish as the first, nor as dark or ground-breaking as the second. However "T-3" is still a thoroughly worthy and engaging finale (?) to the series.

Bottom Line: The issue of fate combined with the spectacular action sequences make this an above average flick. Terminator fans should be pleased too. Worth a big screen viewing and surprisingly enjoyable. Three of four stars for now. Maybe more as it grows on me.

title: Really wish he wasn't back.
review:
My heart goes out to James Cameron. I'm pretty sure he had no control as to whether or not this film would get made. If did have any degree of control then he wouldn't have let this sort of thing happen!

There was never any creative call for a third film (unless, perhaps, we have a prequel giving us a run down of events prior to Reese getting sent back, but that's stretching it a bit). It's a pity that such an obvious business decision has reduced a sci-fi classic to a mediocre TV movie (resplendent with terrible acting, a horrible plot and bland characters).

Like the latter Jaws films, however, the original only gets stronger with every terrible sequel.

title: An enjoyable addition to the series.
review: T3 is an enjoyable action film with Arnie looking as good as ever as the Terminator. It's a little disappointing that the film makers couldn't develop the female T-X a little beyond the enemy of the second film, although she can form weapons with her arms she is for all intents and purpose a female T-3000. If I wanted to delve into the flaws of the film I could argue that Arnie's constant insistance that he's a machine with no emotion is undermined near the end by his apparent fight with conscience as he trys to overcome his "evil" programming at the hands of the TX. All in all though as an addition to the series it's pure fun with all the dark forboding that earlier installments indicated e.g. the end of the world as we know it !! ENJOY.

title: Come with me, if you want to live
review: Terminator 3 is a good movie, don't let anybody tell you different. Sure, it isn't as good as its predecessors T1 and T2, but those movies were instant classics. My expectations in regards to T3 were low, but as the movie progressed it got better and better. ********7/10 -If T4 is ever made please let it take place just before Skynet gets defeated(AD 2029 ??), while Arnold is still looking good and please let James C. finish what he started in the mid 80's.-

title: T1-10 T2-10 T3-8 T4-?
review:
Remember T2? , Arnie CSM-801 (Cyberdyne Systems Model 801) says to Miles Dyson that no-one must follow his work, so Dyson drops a piece of the "chip" on the detonator and the Cyberdyne Systems building blows up. The T-1000, The Terminator and John Connor would have dissappeared before Sarah Connor's eyes and the building she was in would have instantly changed to a shopping mall, carpark anything.(Like in "Back to the Future 2" when Marty & Doc leave his girlfriend behind, Marty wants to go pick her up, but Doc says we don't need to as the timeline will change around her.) So Mr Cameron didn't tell us or Miles Dyson that the Hi-Tech chip from the first "Terminator" was sent to Miltary Intelligence, when they finished with it they sent it back to Cyberdyne Systems. Cue T2,Young Tech;"Where did it come from?" Miles Dyson"You know I asked once, know what they said?,Don't ask."(You could take that comment from Dyson that the "chip" and "Arm" came from anywhere, let alone from a hydraulic press from inside Cyberdyne.) The "chips" the military made would have been stamped CSM because they (CSM) still owned rights to the design and the US miltary do not want a lawsuit over it. So the timeline continues, the T-1000 chases the T-801,Sarah and John into the steel-mill then a delayed Judgment Day, the war against machines will happen, they lose so they try time travel to wipe **SPOILER**



out Sarah Connor, then John, now his Commanders. If they CSM-101, T-1000, T-X succeed the machines will rule the planet, if not the humans will have their freedom back, but in a desolate wasteland 2029A.D.

Terminator 3 is ok, but I missed Brad Fiedel's score during the film. In T2 when John is chased by the T-1000 in that big black tow-truck, you've got a mixture of truck/harley/dirt-bike/shotgun but it's that pumping music that Fiedel does so well it's like musical kinetic energy. If only Fiedel was allowed to score the pick-up truck, crane truck chase it would have raised adrenaline levels as it did in T2.

Weapon Systems; T-801 has to find guns, T-1000 knives and stabbing weapons, T-X has a multi-purpose gun built-into arm. Some comments say that the T-1000 is better than the T-X and that the T-801 is to old, seriously if this were real, it doesn't matter which one is after you, If you get caught its game over. T3 on the whole was a blast to watch and I will go see it again.

T3 ended leaving it all set up for the Future War against the Machines, so how long till T4 turns up at the theatre?

title: The best action movie this summer
review:
Bottom line: while not as epically cast as 'Terminator 2' nor as low-budget gritty as the original 'Terminator,' 'Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines' delivers precisely what it set out to do -- create high-budget kinetic fun with characters by now so familiar that dialogue is rarely ever necessary -- which is much much more than one can say about almost every other film this summer. (The exceptions, of course, are 'X2,' 'Finding Nemo' and '28 Days Later.') Der Arnold fits his role like finely-cut body-built hand to black- leather glove, and new-to-the-series director Jonathan Mostow injects a very welcome sense of knowing humor into the proceedings. Meanwhile, somehow Nick Stahl and Claire Danes manage to not only avoid the curse of the young-pretty-talented-actor- cast-in-overwhelming-Hollywood-spectacle, but actually ELEVATE the film with their subtle, emotionally grounded performances.

8/10

title: Series worthy
review: If you're reading to see if you should see T3.  YES go see it.  Worthy of the collection.  My only gripe is that you can see the U-571 sap in a few places.  I rolled my eyes, but those moments were brief and for the kids. Nitpicking here: They could've found a better babe than Clair Danes but she is adequate as far as acting.  I guess a major leader in the future of mankind's resistance probably won't be a 10.  Kristanna Loken is hot but her smirk is way too human for a terminator.

title: Disappointing; Shocking Lack of Originality
review:
If you want to see T3, just watch T2 again and then add on five minutes worth of plot mythology development. Basically, T3 seems to exist to make money, instead of make money and take us meaningfully forward in the Terminator franchise.

Let's see ... Terminator sent back in time to kill John Connor (and a few others, given lip service but no meaning)? Check. Other Terminator (older model) sent back to protect Connor? Check. War between humans and self-aware machines coming? Check. Car chases involving big, destructive trucks? Check. Bar scene where naked Terminator gets clothes? Check. Organization that will unwittingly allow self-aware machines to control nuclear weapons? Check.

I mean, what was new? Very little. A minor philosophy change involving fate (Sarah Connor turns out to be wrong after all). A very brief bit of reprogramming that causes a good guy to be a bad guy for a few minutes. Even the fancy new Terminator is very similar to the new one in T2. It has an additional weapons ability and one minor wrinkle where it can control machines, but really, who ever thought a Terminator couldn't do that?

That's just the beginning. This movie raises many questions about its own story. For instance, if it is so easy for the machines and humans to send machines back in time, how can this ever end? Why not send a Terminator back to 1961 and kill Sarah Connor as a child? Or kill her parents back in 1930? The franchise really needs to point out that this process is terribly difficult and limited.

Also, John Connor knows how he will die. So now that he knows, why can't he prevent it? It's not like it is a random bomb. There is a very specific set of actions that must occur for Connor to die, and Connor himself must OK one of them. So why would he ever do it?

T3 is very disappointing, and one of the most crass cash grabs I have ever seen from Hollywood.

title: Arnold falls short as the machines rise
review: Overall I feel like the movie was worth the price of admission but I was a bit disappointed.  The story was good and it answered all of the questions I had going into the film but where the movie fell short was in Arnold.  His movement, facial expressions, and overall speech pattern strayed from that of the previous two films.  It seemed to me that the attitude he brought to the character had to be forced out where as the other two films it seemed to come natural for him.  At times it seemed as if his movement resembled that of a 70 year old man with a sore back instead of a nearly indestructable cyborg.  Maybe I am being overly critical.  Being a movie fanatic, I tend to expect more than the average movie goer.  I'm sure, however, that I am not alone in complaining about the feeble attempts at comedy (like "she'll be back" and the starred/glittered sunglasses).  Moments like that took away from the serious and intense nature that the movie should have displayed. I urge everyone to see this film but I also urge everyone to question how old is too old for an action star and more importantly is it the age of the body or the age in the heart they bring into their work.

title: Mindless violence without substance.
review: Cheap (though not monetarily) "sequal" (so the producers say...) to James Cameron's earlier masterpieces. This flic is as lame as ALIEN 3 was. Cameron told it all in the first 2 films - there is no conceivable reason to come out with this 90 minute demolition derby and room/building trashing fest, except that Hollywood, as usual, can't let a very good film(s) go, without cheapening their memories by coming out with some inferior "continuation." This is like every crappy follow -up Disney has put out on direct-to-video. Arnold looks great, but some of his "clever" lines seem desperate. There's no believable chemistry between John Connor and his "future bride". Claire Danes is a very good actress, but she seems wasted in what is little more than a "scream queen" role. Balitrami's score is lame - he should stick to David Lynch films. All in all, a big disappointment from the director who gave us the excellent U-571 and the even better BREAKDOWN. As far as Arnold,he, like Stallone and his endless ROCKY sequals, should know when to quit.

title: An amazing end!
review: The beginning of the third Terminator was too noisy, too destructive... then the pieces of the puzzle came together and everything just made perfect sense. The end of this Terminator 3 makes you dream about what Terminator 4: Post-Judgment Day could be!

title: With a good story...
review:
I was wondering at first if this third installment would live up to the class of the original saga without James Cameron. No, an aged Arnold Schwarzenegger was not my subject of concern. It was director Jonathan Mostow. He was good in U-571 but it was to see how he makes up with all the hypes. I was wondering about the story as well. The Terminator saga differs in this point from the other contemporary movie serieses. That it never had a specific storyline. When the Terminator (1984) was made, nobody knew nothing about a sequel. Terminator 3's exact story was not planned while making Terminator 2 (1992). This is probably the reason behind such long gaps between the movies.

But I am quite satisfied with both. Mostow did a nice job. Of course he is no Cameron, but I liked his simple style. This movie had to contain some first-person storytelling by John Connor himself. There was no other way to describe the situation. I felt relieved to see Mostow did exactly that. There were some rather 'comic' sequences and dialogs. I take it as Mostow's credit as well. The casting was quite interesting. Schwarzenegger... well, it's irrelevant if he was good or not at this point. Claire Danes, probably one of the most underrated actresses of recent years, performed very well. Hers was a strong role. And it was perfect casting. Nick Stahl may look geekish in the movie but I found him not that bad as critics are saying. The surprise was Kristanna Loken. The idea of a female terminator was very unique, though not too unexpected. Whether she is decent as an actress the future can tell, but all I can say she fitted into the role very finely. She turned out to be one of the major attractions.

And the story! I feel very happy to write that I enjoyed the story pretty much. It has probably the best story out of the three. Why? simply because it connects the past and the future. In the other three movies you just saw the possibility that Connor's going to lead the war against SkyNet in some future. But this movie showed exactly how it all began. In the shell it may look just like a replay of T2, with a robot from future to kill him and a robot to save him. But T3 is not all about that. It was a bold and revolutionary idea to show the start of the war at last. I don't know any plans about T4 this time, but as far as the things are going it may not feature Arnold at all.

Quite enjoyable; 8/10.

title: Cool action but nothing else much
review:
(SPOILERS inside)

Tagline: If you're a true fan of Terminator & T2 then forget T3 (or whatever!). And if you actually think JP3 is better than JP & JP2 and MIB2 is better than MIB then you better go now to book your seat for T3!!

First of all I'm a fan of Terminator the original and the first sequel. I find T2 is better than the original in many ways (although this is somehow a tough decision to make coz the original was great). T2 got great great action scenes, better story, great special effects by ILM, great acting by Linda Hamilton, cool ideas with a great story all the way, great directing, and great music. Enough? I dunno. I may add that I love it how T2 unfolds the story and all the scenes that make you scream COOL (like young John Corner riding his bike/ Sarah and her sporty acting/ T-800 looking for cloths with that song/etc..).

So I went to T3 wishing to see something equal to that or maybe (just maybe) better. I knew I wouldn't buy anything if it's not James Cameron but I went along with the story anyway. Well, I tried alot to enjoy it but I couldn't. I laughed few times for Arni's lines. I actually started enjoying this movie in the last minute and couldn't understand how can it end like this, and now I hate it more because of this. The ending was very interesting: It's kinda promising ending (for at least another sequel) as hell as possible but you can use it as the true ending of the series. One thing to add is that I totally hated to see how Matrix Reloaded was affected by Minority Report, and now I see T3 getting affected by Matrix. Give me a break!

Let's get to the details: Arnold seems to get better in the Terminator series. He started to look older though. I missed Sarah Corner and I especially missed Linda Hamilton. John Corner got some nice acting but he surely doesn't look like young John (from T2) to me. T-X was cool and it's good acting by Kristanna Loken, but I don't see her that much of sexy as they wanted us to think and as everyone is calling her that. Music? Well all I can say that it's nice, not much. Cinematography? Also nice, but not so great as Minority Report or Matrix Reloaded. Story? We all wanted to know more and more about the future and how everything happened and all, but I don't find T3 necessary to the series. I also hated how it ended, because we can end it just here (i.e. you know the war of the future and all) but it also opens the door if there ever gonna be T4 or more (i.e. we can actually see the war finally). Anything positive? Well yeah, the action scenes. They did a very good job on the action scenes. Cool action, they tried to make it as real as possible, and the special effects were great. If it was up to me, at least I'd shorten the introduction and add more to the story after the ending.

Was this any real review? Nope. I just wrote my opinion.

title: Great summer movie....
review: Not as good as t1 or t2 but still overpassed my expectations, thinking that this is the 3rd movie in the series and James cameron wasnt directing it i was expecting a blow out, but i got the opposite, i didnt get what i got from the prior films ( got u thinkin bout how the world will end) but i got a great action film and lots of comic relief. The ending was great but although pretty cheesy, but what can u expect from an Arnold movie? Great summer movie with amazing special effects( in my opinion better then the matrix reloaded), go see it, 8 or 9 out of 10.

title: Big disappointment.
review:
As I sat watching this movie I had an inescapable sense of deja vu. All I could think was, "I've seen this movie before." And the truth is I have, only when I saw it the first time they called it 'Terminator 2'. The "liquid metal" terminator? Bad one liners from Ah-nuld? They even reshot some scenes from T2. Such as the classic Arnold clearing an area of police vehicles then doing a scan to compute how many casualties he's caused. (0%)

The TX seemed to be doing her best to mimic Robert Patrick's T-1000, and that too is part of the problem. I know the T-1000. I've spent years studying the T-1000. Dear, you are no T-1000. You'd think that since she's supposed to be even more advanced than the T-1000 SkyNet would have been able to make her less "robotic" in her movements and speech. Hell, the way they look at you with glazed, steely eyes you wouldn't need dogs to detect them.

All in all the movie proved to be a big disappointment for me.

title: Plays like a pilot to a Terminator TV Spin-Off Series...
review:
Both of the previous (and only, in my opinion) Terminator films are self-contained epics that each in their own way provide viscerally involving, intelligent, masterfully crafted, emotionally dynamic and, in more ways than one, downright meaningful and relevant stories that deserved to be told... And were in both cases told extremely well.

They were as good a fusion of pessimistically prophetic science fiction, human drama and social awareness to have been a big box office success as any film of the last quarter century. Oh, and on top of it all, they were kick-ass action flicks to boot.

Terminator 3 should have been a continuation of this. In the absence of the story's creator, those in charge of making the next Terminator film clearly must have acknowledged that they held a certain responsibility to the characters and story that had been told thus far, and they very clearly threw it everything beautiful and important about the Terminator franchise in favour of what they perceived in their narrow, bank-balance-oriented minds to be what 'the Terminator' is all about: Explosions and trucks and one-liners. Like I said, the film plays like a TV spin-off. It looks like one, it's crafted like one, it has the "Tune in next week, Folks!" mentality of an obnoxious TV Pilot, and finally it transfers only enough surface-level material from the previous films (the trucks, the explosions, the character's names, Arnie) to bear a passing resemblance to the Terminator films, but only remind you of how great the others were, at least in comparison, and what a cheap, misguided, misinformed, mistreated, disrespectfully and condescendingly poor excuse for a cash-grab this bad one-liner of a joke this film is.

What a shame. What a damn shame.

title: Not as good as I thought it could be...
review: I liked the movie as a stand alone but, as the third in a series I thought it was seriously flawed. Terminator and T2 were serious movies about the end of the world due to mans insistence of technology and machines. This third movie was spattered with one-liners referring back to the previous two - it made a comedy of it. The acting and effects however were excellent and I thought the movie was well presented. This movie was not really for the fans of the previous Terminator movies but I'm sure it will be very popular to those new to the 'Terminator' storyline. I hope the story will continue.

title: OH GREAT ITS A NEW TERMINATOR
review: (SPOILER) T3 is amazingly pretty good, it has an ok story plot and ok acting, but what makes it really good is its special effects and sound. After T2 though you would have thought it was over and it had a happy ending hinting it was all over. Arnold has come back to protect John Connor from an even more powerful Terminator, which in my oppinion doesnt live up to the T-1000.  Yeah the T-X (Kristanna Loken) is amazing not to mention very attractive. The movie does have some errors from the whole story plot, but James Cameron didnt direct this one.  I felt this could have been better, but then again it shouldnt have been made.  T2 still in my mind remains the greatest Terminator movie ever and one of the best action films of all time.

title: Series Terminated
review:
Once again, it amazes me how a group of movie makers can take an established, solid concept with splendid plot elements, and mould it into a hair ball of cheap, run-of-the-mill entertainment. This third installment continues the story about ten years after T2, and once again John Connor's life is threatened by a killing machine from the future. In other words, you basically get exactly the same movie all over again, only with an altered cast. If anything, it just serves as a cheap build up for a fourth Terminator movie that shows what will eventually happen in the future. No wonder the director is relatively unknown either. Not many people would want to droodle on from James Cameron's modern day sci-fi classic, T2.

Nick Stahl is a good choice to play a more grown up version of John Connor. The problem lies in the script itself, handing him some awfully dull lines. His speech about the death of his mother for instance, is a painful scene to watch. Flatly written and executed. Claire Danes on the other hand, however cute and sympathetic she might be, is clearly miscast for this role. I don't think she delivered a single one of her lines in a believable manner. She's supposed to go through a whole lot in this movie, transforming her from a scared young girl to a confident action companion for the lead hero. Hearing her yell "Die, you bitch!" to the TX at the top of her lunges, with her usual shrill voice, just didn't cut it for me. Neither didn't any of her more quiet moments of grief and guilt when her loved ones are slaughtered seem very natural. As for Kristanna Loken, she does what she can with the premise of the female Termitatrix - and that's that. This movie was never meant to display any of her eventual acting abilities anyway.

Sure, the third Terminator movie delivers a lot of action, huge explosions and even some wry humor, but is that really all you want from this series? In that case you'd be just as well off watching Bad Boys II. The epic scope of T2 is completely muddled here, as are some earlier vital plot elements ignored. And what's up with the screwball comedy?! To watch Arnie's Terminator don Elton John glasses by mistake, crossing eyes when malfunctioning and getting crabbed by the crouch, just seems totally out of place. It's one of the things that makes T3 seem much brighter and less filled with tension than the previous installments. Almost like A Disney movie with some added gore and violence. Even the short Terminator-3D-movie made for the theme park ride at Universal Studios is more interesting than this mess.

title: Top Class film but plenty of spoilers
review:
This movie is brilliant and I am going to rate it at **** out of *****

Arnie is his old character of course.He is funny as usual.He is still my favourite actor.I have been waiting a long time for T3 to come out because ever since T2 was released I have been wishing for another Terminator movie.So I was absolutely thrilled last summer when they announced there would be a new Terminator movie.

The film is brilliant.The plot to the story is very good.

The action and fight scenes are good though nothing that we have'nt seen before.

**Spoilers**
