At the end of T2 we had the clear impression that that was it -- no more Terminators. Errr... they are back with a rehash of the T1 story with a few mediocre actors; these even make Arnie look good. The script is pathetic -- just to generate some cheap jokes. The plot, if one call it that, is flimsy, full of holes, and guaranteed to enable the production of yet another sequel. Finally, it is evident that the film sets and paraphernalia were generated on the cheap.

This film is very bad, and a grand disappointment. I am certain that on the basis of this Arnie won't get elected to the governorship of California. (3/10)

title: Not what I expected
review: T3 was a major upset for me. First let's talk about the animation it was okay, but much of it was computerized or looked that way, which made it look too fake. What did t3 accomplish in its triple sequel? I have no clue, I was expecting more and didn't get it. If you liked T1 AND T2 you won't like this one, let's just hope the next t-movie is a lot more better and well thought than this.

title: Terminator vs. Robobabe
review:
*SPOILER ALERT* *SPOILER ALERT*

I was a little worried going into this one. The Robobabe Terminator angle felt like a desperate attempt to inject some (unneeded) sex appeal into the franchise. I was worried there was going to be a scene where the Terminator and his Termimistress were going to try to consummate their Roboaffair. I am happy to report my fears were vanquished. Or do I mean terminated? They didn't really exploit her femininity at all. The supermodel Terminator was just there as a pleasing visual effect.

So I'm relieved to tell you that "Terminator 3" is a success. This is a return to form for Schwarzenegger. It may very well be the best movie of the summer. I found myself amazed at some parts. The demolition derby with the big trucks was the kind of mindless destruction I used to associate with Arnold flicks. Great to see it back.

So once again the Terminator has to jump through the time portal and save John Connor's rear end. Why does the human resistance keep sending back a dinosaur machine like Arnold? Surely they could come up with a more advanced killing machine or at least upgrade Schwarzenegger to meet the current supermodel preferred version.

At any rate, the two Terminators are going to have to face off. This was the part I worried about the most. Was I going to enjoy watching a hot babe walk off the cover of Vogue and thrash Schwarzenegger? Could I even believe it was possible? Once again, the movie succeeds. Their fight in the bathroom was fantastic. It was a special effects overload. Many toilets were destroyed in the fight for the future.

Overall, "Terminator 3" is a great summer flick. All I can say about the ending is this: Begun this Terminator war has...

title: Good movie but a let down
review: T3 was a good movie don't get me wrong. However, T1 & T2 were such great movies it had a hard act to follow. T3 had great action at the beginning & the car chase was excellent but it just didn't live up to the first two. Had it been a stand alone movie, I would have been impressed but it just didn't reach the heights of T1 & T2. Ah-nuld is still good though!

title: Michael Biehn (Kyle Reece) must be in Terminator 4 or it will FAIL!
review:
Personally I wasn't too pleased with Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines even though the movie unexpectedly ended the way I had hoped for. The feeling I was given during Terminator 1 and 2 was completely gone by the third. I blame this mainly on the music and weak characters. I see the first two movies as a puzzle. All the pieces seemed to fit together because James Cameron took the movies to heart and made sure everything was perfect. In the third movie it seemed like the movie was filled with many holes. The theme was completely lost, certain elements which I had hoped to see (the familiar picture of Sarah Conner from the previous movies, how in the world Cyberdyne Systems was able to rebuild itself and continue research) never showed.

Agree with me or not, I believe that Arnold shouldn't have been in this movie. He was no longer necessary for the movie. Having another Terminator going back through time even though it was getting old with all these Terminator's going through time just doesn't work in my opinion. T3 should have been focused on the character John Conner more and on the birth of Skynet as it unleashed its wrath upon the world. I would have continued with the "Empire Strikes Back" theme but would have put more emphasis on it. I would have shown more T-80's (Those Terminator's from the T2-3D show at Universal Studio's.)

Now for the point of me posting this topic. I feel the 4th and final movie should include Kyle Reece. His importance in playing the important role of the soldier going back in time to protect the past Sarah Conner is all too important. Plus he's one of my favorite characters!

With Arnold supposedly coming back for the 4th, I think thats lame! >.<

title: Best Terminator Ever 10/10
review: in my opinion this is the best terminator of all way better than first and second this movie is gonna fly over charlie's angel's 2 in the box office trust me this movie right now is no.1 can't wait till dvd comes out

title: A decent follow-up
review: Good action, good suspense, and fairly decent acting for the price of admission.  Weak points claire danes, rehash of old terminator sequences and cutting of the film. How do they get into a top secret lab? Looks like the dvd will answer the questions of who, what, where, why. Next story line will be living with the machines...

title: Terminator fans should think twice
review:
Well, on it's own merits, T3 is a good movie. However, it is not a good sequel to T2, and is absolutely not an adequate ending for the series. If you are a fan of Terminator, pass on this film.

Jonathan Mostow was obviously not a fan of the first 2 Cameron films. If he had been, he would have been true to the world of the Terminator. In the first place, Sarah Connor is the heart of films -- not the T-101. Obviously, Arnold is the boxoffice star, but he is not the protagonist of the story. Neither is John Connor, for that matter. Since Mostow didn't have a problem casting Nick Stahl as John Connor, he should have cast another actress as Sarah Connor -- T3 needed Sarah Connor. And why is Eddie Furlong not in this film? Nothing against Stahl, but he was miscast. And so was Claire Danes.

Good chase scene -- mega destruction. Pretty, pretty T-X. Story needed major re-write and some James Cameron input.

title: Cameron is not a GOD
review:
Ok all i see on this forum is Cameron isn;t attached to it, he is such a great story teller. Though I do like Cameron's movies I will now snap the plot holes in T2 and why T3 had to happen.

Ok all you Cameron fans are quick to point out that in T2 he ended it by avoiding judgement day, ummmmmmmm incorrect.

If judgement day was avoided Kyle would not have come back in time, and John Conner would not have been born. How do I know this did not happen, Once skynet was destroyed Arnold should have disapeared as soon as skynet was destroyed. also John Conner would have ceased to exist also.

Sarah would still be a waitress, so please Cameron left plot holes. T3 starts to fill them in. T3 is an awsome movie and the ending is the best I have seen in along while. Do yourselve a favor go see the movie, buy the popcorn and enjoy.

Oh yeah TITANIC was only good for the ship sinking. King of the world my butt. Is it so believable that the rich man would chase a guy with a gun while the ship is sinking.

It was a ship, it sunk, get over it.

title: Better than I'd expected
review: After watching a lot of recent overhyped films I'd expected Terminator 3 to be boring and predictable. I was pleasantly surprised by the interesting storyline that many sequels lack. The action in the movie was extremely good and the acting was also above my expectations.

title: What a waste
review: I honestly am shocked at how bad this movie was.  The acting was laughable: at times you could almost see "John Conner" looking for a cue.  If this comes anywhere close to making a dime I will be surprised.  The action sequences were silly, the dialogue was CHEESY, and the story almost seemed like a farse.  I almost hope for a sequel just so the story can be salvaged, but don't hold out hope for an improvement without a James Cameron.

title: Major letdown (spoilers)
review:
I just returned from seeing T3 and sadly it was a major letdown. The entire conflict was pointless as Skynet goes online and successfully brings on armageddon. No wonder Cameron didn't direct it. It is much like the Star Wars prequels... you have no chance to identify with any character and plays out like you're just watching a show about stunts.

I actually would have preferred not to have seen it. It ruined my whole perception of the Terminator series.

I'll give it a 4/10 simply for the special effects.

title: overall great film
review: i thought was a great film the only thing im not sure i liked was the villian being made of metal and liquid. in a way it seems like this would have been like a second type of terminator. ie, the first was all metal. second should have metal and liquid, third liquid. seems natural progression to me. but overall great movie

title: Good movie - go see it
review: Loved it.  Only problem, too short.  I wanted more and hopefully I'll get more in T4 if and when it is released.  Arnold looks great, the effects were great and the story was great.  Personally I think it had some very good writing.  Those who say it didn't may not have gotten it.

title: Each one in the series just keeps getting bettter than the previous one!
review: Each one in the series just keeps getting bettter than the previous one! Arnold is secure in his status and ability as as actor that he can make fun of his own movie image in this one.  A real must see!  The opening chase scene must be way in excess of 10 minutes and it is a thrill a second!

title: I Thought That this was The Terminator Movie Yet!
review: I thought that Terminator 3 was the best Terminator movie yet. The special effects were fantastic. I thought that the acting was great. Arnold was awesome as always. I am in love with the sexy, beautiful, and talented Kristanna Loken who played T-X! She gave a memorable performance!

title: As good as the orignial...Loved it
review: Done so well, the action and the story line moved right along.  I was caught up in the story within minutes of the movie starting.  Just tell me how Arnold S. stays so young looking.  He hasn't changed at all from the original movie.  All the actors were good.  Would see again and for me thats saying a lot.  Recommeded to all my friends.

title: Back to back home runs with T2 and T3
review: Terminator was a great movie in it's own right. It was an 80s horror film that introduced many of us to Arnold (those of us who hadn't seen Conan). However, Terminator lacked intricacy in it's writing and plot. That problem was quickly resolved in Terminator 2, which showed us that there was so much more to the future, Skynet, and Cyberdyne systems than we thought. Terminator 2 not only brought more story to the table, but more action. It also introduced us to a couple of great actors (Robert Patrick, Edward Furlong). The long anticipated Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines picked up right where T2 left off. Where can you go from T2, some may ask? The story was already brought to a conclusion, right? Wrong. Just when you thought you knew everything, you finally realize that you hardly anything. T3 does exactly what T2 did for Terminator. It takes us even DEEPER into the world of the Terminators and answers a lot of questions that many of us had after T2. The creators of this movie took a series that seemingly had it's strings tied up and created a whole new chapter that is brilliant in it's depth. Not only does T3 bring a great story to the table just as T2 did, but it too brings blockbuster action. After watching T3, it's arguably the best action movie of this summer. Mostow does a great job of filling in for Cameron (we miss you James!). It's truly enjoyable to watch action movies as they used to be made...without much aid of computers. Matrix Reloaded was great...but it relied heavily on computer imagery. Most of T3's action is genuine, jaw dropping stunts. And just as T2 introduced us to new Hollywood faces, so too does T3. Nick Stahl, who plays John Connor, has a great deal of acting talent. He brings his own touch to the character of Connor, now 20 something. We see a whole new side of Connor, very different from the one we saw in T2. In T2, Connor was a rebellious teen who just wanted to have a good time with his friends at the arcade. T3 shows us a worn down, depressed, junkie. Stahl did an excellent job of pulling off the role. He reminded me very much of Tobey Macguire in this movie, perhaps due to his narration and soft-spoken demeanor. We're also introduced to Kristanna Loken, who plays the T-X. It's hard to gauge whether anyone who's recruited to play a terminator truly has any acting talent. The role just doesn't do actors any justice. They must literally constrain their acting talents to the confines of a robot. We obviously know, now, that Schwartzenegger and Patrick were better actors than their terminator roles made them out to be. So too will be the case, I believe, with Loken. Not just anyone can play the role of a terminator. It takes a certain breed and I believe the creators of T3 did a great job of casting. All in all, I give this movie a 9.5, but seeing as that's not a choice, I just rounded up to 10. Bash me if you wish, but I suggest you see the movie. It really is worth the time and money. It delivers in every possible way.

title: I assure you that I was the last one happy to hear about the third installment in this series
review:
I assure you that I was the last one happy to hear about the third installment in this series, especially since James Cameron, Linda Hamilton and Edward Furlong were not attached to it. However, I did notice and recognize the talent in Jonathan Mostow's work, as well as in both Nick Stahl and Claire Danes' previous performances. Fortunately, Arnold remained constant.

So, Wednesday, I finish my shift at work and head to the movie theater. I sit down and am anxious to be mad at God (though I actually don't believe in him) for letting this event happen. The credits start rolling and, suddenly, I'm 14 again! And, I enjoy every single second of this sequel to one of my top ten favorite movies of all time. One might even say it became part of it too.

The only thing that displeased me the first time around (because, yes, I saw it twice already) was the fact that the music was Marco Beltrami's and not Brad Fiedel's composition. Instead of having this machine threat feeling to it, I felt like the music had a Scream-flick feel. It did not affect my thoughts on the script though. T3 makes sense of T1 and T2 where they failed to.

The thing I really appreciated from this great action-FX filled thrill ride is the gutsy ending. I hadn't felt like that since Face/Off when Nicholas Cage kills John Travolta's son during the opening credits. Mostow makes us believe we'll get a happy ending and, then, all Hell breaks loose. The ending is not "bad", it's terrific. And, I mean that in every sense of the word(s) and sentence...

Now, and it's not like me to say this, I really hope they'll make a sequel to this because I want more. No, I need more. And, though not everyone might agree with me on this, I hope that a lot of movie goers appreciate the film the way I did. First, I must warn you: if you did not like The Matrix Reloaded because it had too much action and complicated dialogue, it's the same here.

title: Good, not great sequel to the series
review:
Let me start off by saying the first two Terminators are among my all time favorites. I left the theaters amazed and thought the ticket was well worth it. I'll always own copies on tape (and now need to purchase the DVD's with the extra features).

I can't really say that for "T3". While there was good action and Kristiana Loken was very good as the T-X, I thought there could've been more new ground to cover. How about a more extended look at the future, after the nuclear bombs have dropped and the humans have to fight the machines? How about seeing John Conner as the great military leader he supposedly is? Or seeing how the terminators were first created? Maybe we'll see those concepts in "T4" assuming there will be one. There can only be so many times these machines can go back to track down John Conner and whoever he's associated with. Overall this wasn't bad, but after 12 years of waiting and hoping for another sequel I expected a little more.

title: Entertaining, a pleasure to take in.
review: THE TERMINATOR series of movies have all been entertaining, sometimes poignant, and thought-provoking joyrides sprinkled with droll humor. Terminator 3, though not directed by Cameron, retains much of the feel of Terminator 2.  Once again, a malevolent machine is sent to the past on asassination mission(s), and (what is left of) humanity in the bleak future have sent back a protector (always excellent Arnold, now portrayed as the Edsel of robotdom, outmatched by the radical new robot models).  As in the other two movies, the science fiction story, though solid, is a bit sleight and is really just a framework for the kind of thrilling chase scenes one usually associates with these movies. In content, T3:Rise of the Machines could actually be called T2.5:Judgement Day, but frankly I wouldn't mind seeing TEN more films with this same outline-they are just so fun to watch! If it seems like the franchise is just spinning its wheels, hold on because T4 will surely break the mold and not deal with protecting Connors anymore-in fact, don't be surprised if Arnold isn't even in the next one. Recommended, esp. if you liked the first two!

title: Looking forward too directors cut!
review:
This is one of the years best movies and completes one of the best triology ever made. Special effects are good, the acting is good and the story is ok. Kristanna Loken as the new T-X does a really good job, but the way they cut the gore parts she seems less frightning then t-1000 in T2. This is why I want the too see the directors cut, hopefully it will have alot more gore and bring back more of the horror from the earlier terminator movies.

My rating : 8/10

title: For the fans
review:
I didn't expect much of this. A third chapter in any franchise never had much success. However this one does not suck. To some extent its even better than T2. I didn't like the goody goody side of the second installment, brought on mostly by the winy Edward Furlong as John Connor and special FX aside, it was an Arnie vehicule and not much of anything else.

Here however, the machines, despite the subtitle, are actually put a bit to the sides in favor of the evolution of John Connor's psychologically messed up mind, from bum to General. Kate Brewster(Claire Danes) is a very welcome addition providing a few nice twists in the story. Her character is also well defined, despite too few appearances(I like Ms Danes, a very underrated actress).

The violence is also more present with some gore and lots of guns, not to mention the blood scanning process of the T-X... The "R" rating in the US is well deserved(PG-13 in Canada)

Story wise, the fans of this franchise should be very pleased with the outcomes, the twists and the turns and trying to figure out what is this T-X's weakness??? For those neophites looking simply for some special FX ladden action sequences or those that do not care to much for this "Cameronworld" will surely find just another Hollywood-action-popcorn-selling sequel. If that's your thing, fine. But it's much more than that for the rest of us.

So, here's the lowdown : A very well made sci-fi action film with good performances and no sleep inducing moments. Arnie is finally back! Just sit down and enjoy it while it lasts.

title: James Cameron?
review: I just got back a few hours ago from watching this movie.  I must admit that though I enjoyed the battle scenes and explosions, I still liked T2 more. Maybe James Cameron should've directed this one as well.  (The T-1000 was cooler, the T-X was just to sexy and desirable to be a villain!)

title: Popcorn Movie...nothing more, nothing less
review:
It seems like the problem with a lot of reviews is that many are forgetting this series is called: "The Terminator", and that is what is continuing to happen in Terminator 3.

"John Connor" is looking to be terminated by the machines who rule existence in the future -- come heck or high water. That is THEIR plan which is the whole point of these films. Send a machine, or machines, to kill John Connor or to possibly SAVE John Connor. Once you get that in your brain, nothing else matters. What we are seeing is what occurs in and around John's life as this happens and why these machines NEED for it to happen. Remember that, and you may -- or may not -- enjoy, Terminator 3.

With that in mind, who cares if Arnold is there or not. He's a lovely "familiar" addition, but by no means the make or break all of the central idea. This franchise CAN go on without him. Arnold's character (if you want to call it that) is a TYPE of machine model that will either save or destroy John Connor. Depends on who's programming what at which time...

This terminator MODEL has the same face. Arnold's. Do not be surprised if the next Terminator movie (God Forbid, hut hey, money is money) has several Arnolds in it and ya don't know which is "good" or "bad". There are other advanced models sent as we now are aware such as...the "Robert Patrick" model and this Barbie doll from a Rodeo drive window. (As a resident of Beverly Hills I take offense, she should have been at least 53 years old, and should have came out of a plastic surgeon's chair as she was getting rhinoplasty/breast augmentation or a tummy tuck. Now that would have been a fun film!)

There will be many more sent, etc...but don't forget the point --- that the Arnold model terminator is a "dependable", "stronger" model even if its older than the others send to do the job of terminating John Connor at various ages and stages in the game.

Heck yes, I miss James Cameron's work, but I would have been disappointed if he went into this mire of Hollywood Franchise Business at this stage in his career. Same with Linda Hamilton. Onwards and upwards, I always say.

Mr. Mostow has HIS chance now and he's done exactly what was needed of him. Studio execs are applauding. To produce an adolescent testosterone driven Holiday release popcorn movie heavy on explosions, action and pyrotechnics and thin on plot, story and series continuity.

MAJOR Terminator fans will be scratching their heads at a lot of this installment, younger viewers will be thrilled and give the film praises because it's all the old Hollywood rape your pockets for the summer shuffle and jive of "smoke and mirrors action". On the other hand, the ending (like everyone else I wont give away) but for me, well worth the price I paid to get in this weekend to see it (and that was on a matinÃ©e.)

Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines (Which by the way, is the best title since "South Park - Bigger, Longer and Uncut") is nothing more than some popcorn selling "entertainment" to kill a long drawn out holiday weekend and another, installment in "the Life of John Connor, human savior."

title: Out of this world special effects
review:
I just have to say, if you are a fan of action movies, go and see this one. It's a step above almost all "heavy action" movies I've seen in awhile. I would highly recommend going and seeing this at the theater to experience it to its max.

As far as the story goes, I think it's pretty hard to come up with a great story/script with 2 already great films preceding it.

I think they did a great job and will highly recommend this to all action seekers. Go to a theater with THX certification and listen to the sound system get a serious workout.

title: 2nd Good Film of 2003
review: Along side The Matrix Reloaded, T3 is the second best film of 2003. I enjoyed every bit of the film. Arnold Schwarzenegger was incredible, revisiting his role as T-800 and the girl that played the Terminatrix was both sexy and mean. I liked her character as well. The action was great, and unlike The Hulk, this film gave me everything I anticipated. Oh, and it was worth the 11 year wait.

title: Action scenes with little plot
review:
Ok, there is this movie called Terminator 3, but the only thing that resembles anything related to the Terminator franchise here is Arnold and, unfortunately, he alone doesn't convince me that this is the Terminator.

T3 is a not-bad summer action film, full of action and adventure, but not much in the way of a plot. I read a comment on imdb that says that the ending alone is worth the price of admission; that reviewer is apparently very easily amused.

Throughout the film, which does have some interesting action sequences, there was a noticeable lack of depth. T3 almost seemed like it was developed "by committee" with little bits that had a certain feel, and other bits that had another feel.

Kristanna Loken, who played the T-X, was fine as an actress. She performed her role well. But, what is the point of getting a supermodel to play John Connor's killer? Her beauty had nothing (at least not revealed in the film) to do with the role of the T-X, and there was no reason not to use a more sinister character. Casting her degraded the film to less-than-science-fiction, because good science fiction films avoid such fluff. Based on T3, I could see Kurt Russell, Steven Segal and maybe Jackie Chan getting involved in T4, almost to the point of slapstick

T3 actually hinted that the 'plot' was about to go somewhere, when the T-X began programming machines to help her. This was where it was getting interesting, and it happened pretty early on in the film. I could see where the "Rise of the Machines" subtitle was being utilized. Then it totally fell flat, with virtually no mention of the rise of any machines, except little bits that were touched on here and there, and that which was implied at the end of the film.

The special effects and action scenes were technically good, but my policy is that good special effects, by themselves, are useless.

Overall, the film is somewhat interesting, with a light plot and strong action sequences, although in the end it seems as if I was ripped off with hardly any payoff. Certainly not along the lines of T2 (James Cameron), which is one of the best films to ever come out of Hollywood, and one that I've seen dozens of times. T3 had none of that.

title: Excellent
review:
I must admit that I was not expecting a tremendous movie when I went to see T3. I was happily surprised at how fast paced and fun this movie was straight off the bat. There was some great suspense as I found myself asking of the main

characters: "How are you going to get away from the T-X now?" Kristanna did a great job at playing the hard-core, cold-hearted killer that every Terminator should be. She was brutal and efficient, and best of all never stopped in the middle of killing someone in order to explain her master plan. I like that in a villain. Arnold was once again amazing as the protector, and Nick and Claire were fantastic as his suporting cast. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to see an action-packed flick that has some great twists and turns. The ending is also perfect for the ideas and theories the story conveys about fate and free will.

title: Better than 2, but surpasses the first? No.
review:
POSSIBLE SPOILERS. READ WITH CAUTION.

The first Terminator movie was an excellent action-thriller, with Arnold is a complete cold-hearted a-hole. The 2nd Terminator movie was supposed to be even better, but it was a dry, worthless, shameful rip-off of the original. So, how does part 3 stand?

I've hated just about every movie I've seen since May. X-men 2 was disappointing, Matrix 2 just plain stunk, and Hulk was bad. Very, very bad. T3 is actually more enjoyable than these films, but it fails to capture the magic of the first one. However, it at least does not cut-and-paste every scene from the first one into this one, like part 2 did. Overall, it's not exactly the best action flick of the year *cough, Cowboy Bebop*, but it does have some memorable scenes.

Questions fill my head. No, not ones that question the series continuity, but ones like: How come in the series, any time the good guys or bad guys touch a single vehicle, it does not last even five minutes before getting destroyed? This question haunted my brain during the entire third film.

The TX in this one is basically a T-1000 on steroids. It has the same abilities as Robert Patrick's character, plus literally can do almost anything.

The action emphasis on this one is more on destruction than the first two films combined(not that the second one counts, since it was just the first film with the characters changed). The scene where this is most evident to me is in one scene in which T-101 and TX fight in hand-to-hand combat, pretty much destroying everything in their path. More things get demolished in this part than in an episode of Dragonball Z.

That one psychologist from the first 2, Dr. Stieberman, makes a humorous return appearance. It happens about halfway through the film. Speaking of humor, there's quite a few humorous scenes throughout the entire film, moreso than the first one.

This film probably wouldn't exist had Cameron chosen to use the original ending to T2. Some people are probably really happy about that.

BOTTOM LINE: If you're looking for a decent, brain-dead action-adventure flick, this is currently your best bet.

title: Great movie!
review:
I went into this expecting a decent movie, and was pleasantly surprised. Nick Stahl replaces Edward Furlong as the John Connor, who is now a man, with a destiny. I think Nick Stahl did a good job as John Connor and was completely believable. Claire Danes does the best job in this movie in my opinion as Kate Brewster, a future lieutenant and wife to John Connor. She has this amazing charisma about her and I enjoyed watching her on the screen. Arnold Schwarzenegger reprises his role as the T-101 (NOT T-800 like the Plot outline says, jeez get it right!) terminator, now obsolete. I wasn't a big fan of some of the one-liners he used but it was a decent performance in spite of it. Kristanna Loken plays the new T-X terminator. Now although she has very few lines, her face speaks in great detail. Earl Boen also reprises his role as Dr. Silberman in a quick spot, which I found to be very funny.

Now as far as the movie goes I think this was more funny than the previous versions but it still maintain its action/thriller appeal. It was suspenseful when it needed to be and that was very important. And I think the last thirty minutes of this movie were really quite good and thought provoking. The end really came too soon, which was my only disappointment. I don't really enjoy movies which try to stick too much information in too little time, as this movie does. However its done well enough that you do not become bored or puzzled at some of the things that happen. However my only problem is this film really should have been longer. I think had they had another twenty or thirty minutes we could have seen a little more story. The movie seems more concerned with the action than the dialog which doesn't quite turn me off, though I would have liked to see more. My hope is that the DVD will include much more that was cut from the film. And I think while deleted scenes are good, I'm much more on the special editions where the cuts are seamlessly added to the theatrical release. In any case this movie is good, and can only get better with more scenes. I for one am wishing and waiting for a fourth installment.

title: Perfect Summer Movie (Minor Spoilers)
review:
Minor Spoilers

Terminator 3 is exactly the type of movie that I like to see as part of the summer blockbuster season. It's loaded with incredible looking action, it's humorous , and it has a huge cheese factor. The storyline is only used just to get to the next explosion or the next joke. But even so, for the most part the story seemed right on par with the previous installments, and at the ending, it completely took off and a classic was born.

In a huge departure from the previous installments, director Jonathan Mostow has taken the James Cameron-abandoned franchise and made it his own with a very exciting and thrilling film. I thought the ending of T3 was simply amazing and such a welcome change from the 'happy' ending that follows so many of the summer movies. Very courageous of Mostow as well, I might add.

The films titanic budget is all up there on the screen and was used to great effect (minus Arnie's $30 million take of course).

The action in this movie is truly the show stopper here. The sequence with the upending crane truck was absolutely staggering and completely blew my mind. The best car chase scene I have ever scene (or at least the most destructive). The hearse sequence, is also very noteworthy. The action sequences never let up and really demonstrate just how far along the advances in CGI, animatronics, and even make-up have come. Kudos to the always excellent work by Stan Winston with his T-X design and fully-functioning T-1 robots.

I think that what many of the negative reviewers of this film take issue with is the lack of subtle humor that was so prevalent in the first two movies. The comedy was put into overdrive for this film, as Arnie delivers more one-liners than ever, some of them absolutely atrocious. But if you can just laugh them off, you'll still be in for a great ride. The humourous cameo by Dr. Silberman was a nice touch.

Schwarzenegger however to my surprise, is still very convincing as the cybernetic organism that he first played almost twenty years ago, and his physique for the most part is as it was back in 1984, although he does look a little smaller. Kristanna Loken did a great job too as the female T-X, but I still think that Robert Patrick as the merciless T-1000 is still the most ruthless of the villain Terminators.

Nick Stahl and Claire Danes as John Connor and Kate Brewster respectively, also put in decent performances. Connor does look like a grungy vagrant, but a liquid metal terminator coming through the future ten years ago solely to kill you, is bound to be somewhat traumatic for the guy, and might just cause him to live an alternate lifestyle.

All in all, a very entertaining popcorn flick. Highly recommended if you enjoy action movies, or the Terminator film franchise (if you can digest some minor plot holes). I can't wait for the DVD, and I hope that T4 gets the greenlight too, with Mostow once again at the helm.

title: Excellent! Best movie of 2003
review: Out of all the big movies released (X2, Matrix 2, Hulk, etc) this one is the best!  Non-stop action, a solid cast with top-notch acting, and a very good ending.  I didn't actually expect much since Cameron wasn't directing T3 but it turned out to be a pleasant surprise!  See this in the theatre while you can!

title: Very good
review: This was one heck of a movie. The Effects are good. The Acting is Superb Especially by Kristina Lokken and Arnold. Nick Stahl was also very good as John Connor. Everything about this movie is excellent. It was well worth a ten year wait. Although I don't think it is better than Terminator 2 Judgement Day. I think it is a tie between them. I was Shocked to see that Judgement Day still happened. I guess Skynet did win.I wonder if they will make a Terminator 4. Overall excellent movie ****

title: Good but not great.....
review: Good action Sci-Fi. Nothing new for everything here has been done by parts 1 and 2. The Directing was not as good as parts one and 2. The story here was only fair and did not connect well with parts 1 and 2. The CGI technology here was better but not as creative as Terminator 2. This movie was obviously done only to make more money for it really lacked CREATIVITY and lacked ORIGINALITY. The Actor who plays John Connor does not look like the younger John Connor of part 2 at all. Very sloppy things like this were prevalent in this movie. Only for Sci-Fi action fans and big fans of the lead actors......

title: A Good Continuation of the Story
review: Humor mixed with action adventure.  I loved it!  I only wish John Conner was tougher, as he would have been having gone through the last movie and having been raised by Sarah C.  Look for the scene with the psychiatrist - he is also in the second movie but the humor will be lost on you if you don't notice that.

title: Mediocrity Unacceptable for a Terminator Film
review:
Terminator films are supposed to rule. Even in the age where sequels, by definition, suck, somehow Terminator 2 still ruled (maybe even more than the first). A standard was set, they aimed high and they hit higher with strong characters, a strong story and excellent effects.

T-3 did NOT rule, however. There was virtually NO story, the special effects were completely derivative of T2 (couldn't the cgi geeks come up with something better?), the characters were so devoid of depth that you almost wished them dead and the authors copped out by simply dismissing the well crafted plot of the earlier Terminator films.

The introduction of cute one liners from T2 was so overused in T-3 that it got stale quicker than a "Charlie's Angels" sequel. The film makers of T-3 simply cashed in on a proven formula and didn't seem to care one bit about fumbling on one of the best film storylines ever created. I, for one, had expected that they would have spent much more time on the story and had done justice to the prior films. Mediocrity does not belong in Terminator films;they deserve much, much more. 6/10

title: Not the 'feel' I expected.
review:
This movie was much more enjoyable than I had expected it to be. Though I was really hyped up and ready, I knew it could be awefull. And it wasn't - not aweful-, but I didn't get the feel I had expected to get.

It wasn't the script or the story or the action... for me, it was the score. That background music that you hear playing was different (oddly different) than the other two. Kristina Loken did a great job as the TX, though a bit robotic in her actions, she had the look and glare that said she had what it took to be as "unstoppable" as Arnold and Robert were in the first two... but not as creepy. I know it may sound odd, but I blaim her lack of creepyness on the score. I was expecting to hear the violin screams and machine roars as in T2 which made the T-1000 absolutley desturbing for me. When I did her the T-1000's music in the background (which was only about 4 times lasting 3 seconds) I was like "OKAY!!! Here we go!"... Then it was gone. Oh well. I thought I might talk about that in this review.

title: Good casting choices
review:
Terminator 3 was a very enjoyable movie due to both a good story and good casting choices to surround Arnold. Kristanna Lokan is the standout of the movie as the ultra-sexy and menacing Terminatrix (TX). She has terrific screen presence and makes for a cold and relentless villain, on par with Robert Patrick's terrific turn as the T-1000 in T2. Here's hoping Lokan gets more good roles in the future. Nick Stahl and Claire Danes both do well in the pivotal parts of John Conner and Katie Brewster. The relationship between these two characters is central to the film and Danes and Stahl showed good chemistry together.

The story I thought was very good with an interesting blend of humor with a grim storyline. It worked, though. The movie manages to tell a good story without being too pretentious or taking itself too seriously. The ending was certainly an eyebrow raiser and certainly distinguishes it from the other two Terminator films.

One complaint I have was the lack of the Terminator theme music in the movie(until the end credits, anyway). But other than that, I thought the movie did what it set out to do- tell an interesting story while entertaining the audience. 10/10

title: The best thing I can say: It Didn't Suck!
review:
I know that most of us went into the theater with this silent prayer in our minds: "Please don't suck! PLEASE dont SUCK! PLEASE DON'T SUCK!"

First, the good news: It didn't SUCK!

Now, the not so good news: It wasn't great either.

The best I can do for this movie is say it was pretty good. If it were a stand alone movie, that would be enough. But since it follows two of the best sci-fi movies ever made, it's a bit of a letdown, but not much.

This movie is certainly worth watching in the theaters, if for nothing else than the action sequences. Of which there are some doozies! The chase scene with the crane alone is worth the price of admission!

The acting in this movie was well done. Being an action flick, I'm not looking for Oscar worthy performances, but I did start to care about these people. Kristanna Lokken did quite well as the T-X, her performance as such rivals that of Robert Patrick as the T-1000 in T2, and she has a nice butt to boot! Nick Stahl fills in quite well as John Connor, though I still would rather have seen Edward Furlong reprise his role and give the film more of a connection to its predecessors. Claire Danes works well too, though her part seems a bit like a redux of Linda Hamilton's Sarah Connor from the first film, even to the point where John Connor says to her in a scene, "You remind me of my mother!".

Then of course there's Ah-nuld! what can I say? The man was born to play this part! The only problem I had with this rendition of the T-800 (or T-101 in this film) was that for the first 2/3 of the movie, the script relies so heavily on the amusing one-liners (in their defense, they ARE funny!)that the movie threatens to become a parody of itself.

Jonathon Mostow does a good job directing, but I really would have liked to have seen what Cameron would have done with this movie. His absence I think is what stops this movie from being great.

The biggest gripe I have with this movie is its ending. While it does set up a possible T4 movie, it is anti-climatic to say the least, and furthermore in contradiction to the theme of T2.

I give it a 6.5 out of 10.

title: A mere segue for T4?
review:
OK, you know what? Arnie can't carry a movie with the Terminator shtick anymore... it's just gotten TOO old. You gotta give him credit for looking so good at his age, but all the one liners he's forced to utter seem so contrived and derivative (as does the majority of this movie). And that opening sunglasses gag?!... Gimme a break!

It was Edward Furlong and Linda Hamilton's energy & desperation that brought T2 home, and their absence is acutely felt here (not to mention James Cameron's story telling and direction). I'm sure Furlong's real life personal challenges could have been incorporated to make John Connor's current state that much more striking... but oh, that would be too "risky" for such a cash-cow franchise. Clare Danes is the only actor here that could have generated some real empathy and humanity in this movie, but the poor writing does not ask her to.

Robert Patrick's liquid-metal Terminator was excellent in T2 (still gives me the creeps just thinking about it) and his abilities & limitations really added to the story and made some kind of sense. Kristanna Loken's coolness was great and her TerminatriX had real potential (should have had more sexy/gory scenes) but was ultimately derivative, as well. In addition, I didn't buy her upgraded terminator-ability of molting specific body parts into complicated machinery, and even less the idea that they could be permanently "damaged". (The story suffers when the writers don't follow their own rules.) God knows what unbelievable gimmick they'll come up with for T4, to try to out do the T-X!

The action scenes were impressive, but I've grown tired of chase scenes pretty much altogether, each one trying to out do the last... they're just silly (e.g. Matrix Reloaded)... try spending the same time advancing the plot! (The last time I saw a decent chase scene was Ronin.) On top of that, they must have had wheels on the crane spreaders for that thing not to completely tip over right away!

The only part that was really new and interesting was the end, at the military research facility, with the prototype robot tanks and planes running amok, but that was like only 10 minutes! There should also have been much more interaction with Colonel(?) Brewster, instead of killing him off as soon as they get to the research facility. It also made ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE that there were no military personnel manning that VIP bomb shelter... Very weak. However, I did like the CGI of nuclear missiles and explosions, but they didn't play up the Apocalypse enough... don't want to use up too much T4 material, I guess.

Since this movie does a complete 1-80 with the deterministic aspect of fate (I thought "Fate is what you make it"?), it is a lot less hopeful than T1 & T2 were. The only positive aspect about this new storyline is the relationship between John Connor and Kate Brewster, which everyone seems to like.

With the amount of money they spent and the potential of the Terminator/Skynet premise, I was very much disappointed. This movie has its moments and could have been great, but it felt more like an expensive pilot for a post-doomsday TV series, and ends too early, just as things start to get interesting. Hopefully, they'll hire some real storytellers for the inevitable T4 for which this movie appears to be a mere segue. Rating for this `genre', given T2 is a 10/10: 6.

title: Pretty Good, but too short (mine was 1 hour 42 min), and does NOT beat T2
review: Well, the movie in no way was bad. After all, the Judgement Day we heard about in T1 and T2 start in this movie. but still, I did not find the essence of the hardcore terminator, as there were several places where kiddy and babyish stuff was happening. But I would recommend it to all Terminator fans out ( Like Me). I think there might be a T4, since the ending was not proper. Arnie says "We will meet again" in the end of the movie, and I think the last sentence said in the movie was "The Battle has just begun ". So, I sure hope there is a T4, which really kicks ass, but I dont want to wait another 10 years or so for it...

title: Arnold is damn funny
review:
This movie is awesome. Terminator is not about man against machine, it is not about the end of the world, it IS about one liners spoken in an austrian accent by a man who could at one point bench two of you put together. I laughed so hard I almost got kicked out of the theatre. By the way, cameron is the wrong guy for terminator. he is too serious and deep.

The new director finally realized terminator's potential as a comedy, and exploited arnold's arnoldness to create the most lighthearted and funny terminator yet. It is too bad that all three weren't like this. Anyone who complains about his movie is a loser who can't lighten up and just have a good time. This is the best arnold flick since "Last Action Hero".

title: Good entertainment
review:
I just got back from it and I wasn't disappointed at all. It was entertaining, enjoyable, had a lot of terminator jokes, and was action-packed from start to finish. I gave it a 8/10.

Mostow surprised me with the decent job he did, and that chase scene in the beginning with the crane was pretty good.

In the beginning of the film, how and where Arnold gets his clothes was a riot. Everyone in the theater was cracking up.

title: film sinks under its own weight
review: Having seen all three of the Terminator films as an adult, I've been progressively disappointed as the movies have come along. The first was by far the best, with real characters, a great story idea, and a solid script. The second, Judgment Day, presented a great chase sequence, but progressed poorly thereafter with weak acting and a script that steadily worsened. While the special effects were amazing at the time, the film failed where it counts most: the appearance of sympathetic characters. This last installment, which hopefully will indeed be the last, is easily the weakest in the series with very poor acting, and a script that relies mostly on special effects and chase scenes. The attempts at humor are badly needed in this movie, which was borderline boring. Even Arnold, sorry to say, seems tired of his character. With all its heavy machinery, the film sinks under its own weight.

title: Disappointment Hurts
review: The Terminator series began with two thought provoking well done films. The second one, while incorporating mindless action, still stay true to the spirit of the original.  The third is contrived, derived, and shallow. LEss U571, more Terminator 1, please.  Thanks

title: Just Keeps Getting Better
review:
Quick and too the point. Lots of action, some laughs too. The doctor from the second movie is back. Of course the terminators just get nastier every time, and much better looking.

Great ending, and you got to love the T-2! What more could you ask for?

title: better than expected
review:
i was expecting a average movie since cameron was not directing the movie. but the movie wasn't a disappointment. its a good movie, the ending is very good. i found myself in the mood halfway through the movie, 'the fear of machines' brought about by the other two movies. it gets real interesting after that. the director has brought some humour which works, but unecessary. i would love to see a T4. Now the bad aspects. Loken does not fit the TX profile that well, she looks beautiful but a girl more athletic and more importantly a bit muscular would have been the better choice. Stahl is also not a very ideal choice either. he is short and has a softer image. i don't know why Edward Furlong from T2 was not chosen. the continuity had a very strong impact on the appeal of John Connor. Otherwise a taller guy with chiselled features resembling the John Connor from T1. The movie was shot mostly in daylight, T2 was shot in the night giving that somber and lonely feeling putting a fear in the hearts of audience. It should have been followed here. Action sequences are great, again night would have been better.

But that sould not spoil the thrill of watching T3.

title: What a great movie - Arnold is back.
review: This is a great movie.  Great action, good story...an enjoyable hour and a half with some popcorn and coke.  If you go looking for the meaning of life from this movie will be disappointed.  If you're looking for a great action movie with Arnie in it...go see T3 - it delivers!!

title: A shadow of its former self
review:
To each his own, but I cannot believe there are so many positive reviews for this movie. Doesn't anybody care that underneath the action and special effects there was nothing going on in this movie??? From Hollywood that's nothing new, but I thought Terminator fans had grown to expect more than that from these films. You can blow up as many things as you want, if I don't care about the characters on the screen than it's pointless.

Look, the action scenes are nothing short of breath taking. Probably some of the best ever captured on film. That's about all the movie has going for it. The so-called story contradicts rules and plot points made in the first two films. There's never even a logical explanation of why T3 even occurs. Every time someone's about to explain that, or something else of importance, they either end it with a one liner or someone interrupts them. Lazy screenwriting. I don't mind them changing the theme of the movie, too bad they didn't change anything else. This is T2 with a woman and no subtext. The subtitle was fitting since like a machine, the movie was cold and emotionless. The humanity the was stressed in T2 is completely missing. Those of you calling this the best in the series need to rewatch the second film. Why is it nowdays that the minute a budget goes over $100 million, all semblance of originality, character development, and logical thought goes with it?

This is not a Terminator film. This is a very expensive fan film that almost parodies its predecessors. Like Friday the 13th or Halloween, they turn the character into a cartoon. They actually make a fool of the Terminator. You laugh AT him. Way too much humor that just doesn't work.

Before seeing this movie I thought T2 had wrapped everything up and there was no need for a third. After seeing it, I KNOW there was no need for it. The only thing it was successful at was showing me what a skilled director Cameron is. This is crap, folks. I can't be nice about it. It was just a bad, bad movie that played its audience for idiots. The last line is a slap in the face. It's an insult to the intelligence of movie-goers.

Everbody complains about the state of the movie industry. Then everyone fills these boards with positive reviews of crap like this. Only reassuring Hollywood they're making the right decisions. T3 may be bigger, louder, and faster than the first two but it's also a lot dumber. You can put the body of a ferrari on top of a Toyota, but just bc it looks good doesn't mean its worth getting into.

And Arnold clearly needs Cameron to bring out the actor in him. Thanks for ruining the Terminator guys. One more thing I loved that Hollywood's 'Nothing Sacred' attitude has ruined.

title: awesome flick
review:
didn't expect much since cameron didn't direct, but whoa...

they really went all out, one action sequence after another, tightly integrated at a super fast rate.

best summer action movie of the 2003 hands down, with matrix reloaded at a close second. :)

title: The Best Terminator movie
review: I really love T3 10 times better than the first two movies. The entire movie was loaded with sweet-ass viual effects created by ILM and lots of action scenes. I love the female TX characther villan in the film played Kristann Lokienn, she is so sexy and hot-looking, its not even funny. I would love to take her out on a date if I was already in the film industy. My favorate scene was when the TX and The good-guy terminator were fighting in the restroom when Arnold lifted TX off her feet and body slams her head first into the toilet breakin' it in half. I thought that was the funny thing even to take place in the event of a movie in general. I hope this is the last Terminator sequel, seriously. The movie was that damn good I would go see it again.

title: WOW WOW WOW!
review: WOW! WOW! I went into this movie expecting just another rehash of T2! BOY WAS I WRONG! Everything about this movie is great! The acting was great, although Kristanna Loken was a bit of a downer, she could've been better. The story took the T franchise into a whole new direction. Lemme also say that as an Arnold fan AND a HUGE T fan, I was never skeptical of this movie. It's not as PG-13 friendly as most of you people think either, at one point the TX shoves her arm through a guy's back and out the other side, I won't say who though since I'm not one for spoilers. Overall a worthy addition to the T franchise, it's GREAT!

title: James Cameron is Missed
review:
From beginning to end you could say this movie is missing all the things that made T2 such a remarkable movie in 1991.

The artistic style of James Cameron is gone, replaced with a dizzying fast-paced shoot-em-up. The character development that played such an important role in T2 and T1 is missing. It's replaced with a quick intro about a neurotic man named John Conner, and a stereotypical daddy's girl who has a hotshot father in a secret military facility.

The whole anticipation of the Terminators finding John Conner is missing, replaced with a quick cut into a vet's office where ironically both Terminators find John Conner and Punky Brewster...err I mean Kate Brewster.

After that point, there isn't much time for explanation, it's just shoot this, shoot that, leading to a bland ending that could be used to milk the series for another few summers.

This movie was completely half-assed by directors, writers, and producers who weren't interested in reliving one of the James Cameron's greatest movie series of all time, but just using the name to sell tickets so they can suck the series dry before Arnold gets too old.

title: Great Follow-Up to T2
review:
I was a huge T2 fan, so I've been waiting for this movie for a long time. I'm glad to say that I was not disappointed at all.

The movie was exciting, funny, clever, and delivered exactly what I wanted.

There were a couple cheesy scenes, but for the most part, the movie was great. The Terminatrix was actually cool, even though I initially thought casting a woman was a mistake.

I had a great time, and will definitely see it again and buy the DVD.

title: Certainly not sublime
review: I was quite dissapointed in this third installment of The Terminator. It simply was lacking.  It was incoherent from start to finish, and it has to be the biggest downer of the summer.

title: Just garbage...
review:
ALL MY REVIEWS HAVE SPOILERS. EVERY ONE OF THEM.

Terminator 3 defies logic on so many levels. First of all, I have the same initial question with T-3 that I did with T-2. Why the hell does the future John Connor (or military personnel) continue to send old, obsolete model cyborgs to save him in the past? Wouldn't it make sense to send the same updated, slicker model that was sent to kill him? And why does the female T-X pump up her clevage to flirt with a cop? Isn't she the Terminator?? Why does she need tricks to get his gun? Just JACK HIM FOR IT like you do everything else! Speaking of the cop's gun, why does she even need it?? Her arm can shape into a gun, a rocket launcher, and a flame thrower. And why does she need to taste a bloody woman and bloody gauze pad to identify people? Isn't her tongue made from the same synthetic material her finger is? She should taste it as soon as she sticks her finger in it. She also murders a guy in a drive thru burger joint, but the window is on the right hand side. Why? Isn't this America?? And what happened to her mission to destroy John Connor's future lieutenants? She abandons that idea early on and decides to pursue John Connor and his future wife for the duration of the movie. The ending is anti-climatic. So anti-climatic in fact, I don't even remember how they destroyed the female Terminator in the end.

T-3 is a poor movie with a convoluted plot, uneven pacing, and boring action. The film in general feels small and incomplete. It ends with a door open for a sequel, but my anticipation is greater for Problem Child 9. Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is simply garbage and anyone who likes it is stupid. Zero stars out of 5.

title: Malfunctioning weapon
review: I loved the movie, but what is up with the T-X having a malfunctioning weapon? She can replicate anyone or anything, but cannot blast anyone after falling on the pavement twice. This is just a problem associated with creating more and more super terminators. What are they gonna do next time? Have one that reads minds or teleports itself? Too much...

title: Not as bad as I thought.
review:
Potential Spoiler:

Overall, the movie is fun, entertaining, and worth seeing on the big screen. I was REALLY VERY skeptical about this film, but I went to see it just for SAG (something and giggles)

OK, James Cameron didn't do this one, and it has a totally different flavor from the first films. It is as different from T2 as T2 from T1. I think it combines the cheesy B movie with the serious sequel and adds a bit of humor. For the purists, the one scene I had a problem with, actually has a precedent in T1.

In T3 Arnie tries to kill "someone" by throwing them around a lot, instead of just crushing them like a bug. In T1 Arnie throws around Sarah's room-mate's buddy until he dies. There is no reason, he subsequently blows away Sarah's room-mate with a laser sighted big huge handgun. Ammo conservation glitch? You'd think a fist in the skull would be more efficient, but obviously there is a bug in the program somewhere.

Go see it, it's a laugh and a half. There is a lot of eye candy for the big screen. If you are an Uber-Geek and think you know how it really should have been done don't bother.

Jim

title: generally positive
review:
I'll limit my comments so as not to reveal anything significant.

Overall, I liked this movie.

It is not as groundbreaking or thrilling as the original one was when it was first released 19 years ago. It is not as mindlessly entertaining or slickly crafted as the second installment. It is, however, a worthy sequel.

Here, in a nutshell, is why: Have you seen the first two? Do you remember how bleak the first movie was, and how brilliantly (for an action movie) it played with the logical paradox of time? Do you remember how the second movie blatantly violated the paradox, and how this caused a nagging feeling of -well...- intellectual disappointment which diminished the strength of the film? How it got just a tad too mushy (diminishing, most notably, the power of the performance delivered by Linda Hamilton)? Well, this third installment "fixes" those problems, answers a bunch of begging questions, and returns very solidly to the stark tone of the original. Thank God.

Arnold turned in the expected performance. Claire Danes was surprisingly authentic. The plot was solid. I cannot say more without spoiling.

Pacing was a little spotty, but I think that was actually a strength - some things happened which really needed a pause from the buildup-to-climax which drove the original and second movies. The effects were well conceived and solidly executed.

The only defects I can point to: They tried just a little too hard with the TX - I dunno, but it seems to me that they could have done better with a little less "oh, wow, look at THIS nifty feature" nonsense; The actor playing JC was not particularly impressive in that role - I know what the intent was, but there was not enough evidence of character development to make his reactions at the ending really believable; Lastly, I think the end was just a tad too clinically executed - *I* would have hammered the audience quite a bit harder with the enormity of the events in question, so that instead of leaving the theater a little sad they'd leave staggering in awe and horror, but that's just me.

I'd rate T3 a solid 4 of 5, sliding scale adjusted for genre.

title: Thrill ride that should have been longer...
review:
Entertaining road movie that is, sadly, not as ambitious as the first two Terminator movies. Could have done with at least 10 extra minutes of character development, which would have added to the impact of several clever plot twists.

Unfortunately, the vulnerability of Edward Furlong would have been better suited to the role of John Connor in this flick than the "action figure/pretty boy" features of Nick Stahl. Nevertheless, Claire Danes is more than effective in her role, and Arnie's Terminator remains an iconic figure.

The crane chase may be the second best stunt of the summer, behind the Matrix Reloaded's freeway scenes.

title: Lives Up to the Second
review:
I think the Terminator series is one of the greats in film history, which led me to be concerned that this one would be the Rocky 5 of the group--take away all credibility it had won over the previous dozen years, made possible by great action with equal quality story.

At first, I was concerned that this wound tank-an hour solid of only action. But a decent story did flesh out, and I was surprised and happy with the result.

The highest praise I could give this movie going in was that it lived up to the second. As my summary notes, it clearly did.

title: Pretty good, Ah-nold does his best turn yet
review: A lot of cynical people will not be pleased by this film, but the problem is not in the film they're watching. Ah-nold is geat once again as the T-101. Stahl does aight, Danes is ok, and the Terminatrx is rightfully creepy, and its about time we saw some female booty in these films. The start with Stahl narrating is unnecessary and too long. There mustve been better ways to explain the set up. The action scenes are fanatic, not qite as coherent as Cameron's but they are on a much bigger scale. T2 had a semi versus a motor bike, T3 has a big crane truck and a bunch of police cars versus a pickup. The terminator vs. terminator fights are terrific as well. The ending to this movie is absolutely brilliant. a lot of people are going to complain, but they are dumb. The end of this film finally clears up the paradoxes of time travel in the first two. In T2, when they destroyed the pieces of the previous T-101, that T-101 should've ceased to exist, sorta like Mike J. Fox n Back to the Future, but this problem is solved ingeniously. All in all, first is the worst, second is the best, and the third is in-between as far as this trilogy goes. Dont get me wrong, the original is great, it just hasnt aged well. It seems a lot of people have it out for Ah-nold, I really don't understand why, Arnold has more charisma ad star power in one  arm than the Rock or Vin Diesel have in their entire bodies. See this movie, lighten up, enjoy it. Arnold is still the king of action, and he makes  trumphant return to form in his film, which is his best since True Lies.

title: Better than Expected
review: Having, at last, seen the much hyped third installment, I must say that I was pleasantly surprised.  With such movies, I always watch as many previews as I can, read lots of reviews to get a feel for what other people think, and I try not to get my hopes up too high.  That said, there are three questions that must be asked.  Is it better than its predecessors?  Of course not!  Is it as good as it's predecessors? Yes...almost...particularly if you squint and cock your head to the left.  Is it a worthy addition to the dynasty? Absolutely!  I've read arguments that though TX is cool, she's a pale shadow of the grandeur that was T1000.  This is true.  But while T1000 was revolutionary, the TX seems the follow the natural progression. She was certainly acceptable.  She satisfactorily functioned with the absolute singularity of both the T101 and the T1000.  My main...in fact, my only complaint is that the heavy action commenced with very little preamble and, in my opinion, without enough explanation which really didn't work to the film's advantage as it did in T2 with the surprise of Arnold being the good guy.  I was placated, however, by the quality and originality of the action.  The action in this film was complex and well done and didn't drag on like the overwrought, rather pretentious scenes of the Matrix...but that's a whole other can of worms.  The acting is fine.  Arnold, who I think is always fun, is at last back in the role he was meant to play.  And 12 years later he still looks fabulous.  I would have liked to see Edward Furlong back, but junkies are notoriously difficult to employ.  Nick Stahl was more than satisfactory.  He captured the childlike vulnerability of John Connor that Furlong's youth gave him.  Claire Danes is wonderful as always. She's so real and genuine that it makes her very easy to care about.  And even if the movie hadn't been as good as it was, the ending would have made it worthwhile.  The rest of the story wasn't quite as internally cohesive as the other two, but it was reasonably close...but the end...I can't over stress how wonderful the ending is.  If you're not a total movie snob and as long as you don't think that the idea of the Terminator series is to make some huge social or cosmic point...if you'd like to see a movie with fantastic action sequences and effects, good humor, fine acting, and *gasp* a completely acceptable story with a stellar ending, go see T3.  You won't be disappointed...Oh and P.S.-I fear that there may be yet another sequel. And if there is...I don't think I'll be going to see it.  This movie ends too well (remember the end of Alien 3 followed by Resurrection? *shudder*)

title: pointless re-do of T2 without feeling....
review: T3 is nearly a clone of T2 but without the interesting concepts and humor that made Judgment Day a classic sci-fi actioner.Although there are a few interesting visuals and a plot that could have been worthwhile if it had been fleshed out a lot more and infused with a little more originality,Rise of the Machines is ultimately a vehicle for Arnold to utter humorless one-liners and do constant non-stop action sequences with a villain that is nearly a carbon copy of Robert Patrick in T2.Curiously,this film does have an intriguing finale but it is not enough to save the overall movie.Too much action,not enough brains.It's time to let go of the Terminator franchise.No T4 please...

title: To much of the same thing
review:
I enjoyed some of scenes but for the most part it left me dry. There were way to many similarities to T2 like when TX Said I like your gun or something stupid like that. Most of the time TX did not care if she exposed the fact she was not human so if she was suppose to be this ultimate killing machine why not form herself into a

multi-leg multi-arm bug looking thing that had eyes all around its head that could run a hundred miles per hour flat out and shoot multiple laser weapons at once. TX reminded me of one of these Century city receptionist that breaks down into tears when she brakes a nail. Even Linda Hamilton in T2 buffed out to some degree to look hardened for her roll. I think I had much bigger smile on my face after me and my kid seen the Hulk last week.

title: exploitation of the theme and effects, not good.
review:
i am sorry to report that t3 - rise of the machines, which could have been a truly great movie, nothing missing in terms of plot possiblities in that concept, fell totally flat, in fact melting into the ground in implementation.

most of the scenes were some kind of spoofy sub-par rehashes of previous scenes in the series, in terms of the continuity. the only think different was that the action was so over the top it was almost funny. for one example there is a scene when the new t-x liquid metal terminatrix as she is being called, is driving a huge truck, which Arnold manages to get a grip on. The truck is like a ladder truck, so the terminatrix moves the ladder out to hit everyting it her path to knock the good terminator off. When it hits a building, instead of wrecking the ladder, and bending it all around, the ladder goes through everything in its path, and does not slow down or twist the truck. it is just ridiculous. it takes so long to explain who how absurd this movie is, i just cannot do it.

onward now to the characters. arnold is the same terminator, though how he plays this without crying at what they have done to the legacy of this series is beyond me. the kid who played john connor was like a weaselly homeless guy, i suppose to give the loser teenage boys in the audience some hope or something. even this could have been used creatively, as some sort of play on how things can get twisted and goofed up, but that is way above the level of this movie.

the new terminatrix, seems to me like a terrible part. she is supposed to be more advanced and more human-like to root out humans in the future that could detect the older clunky terminators, but they are clueless about writing her part. She is this very sleep flawless beautiful women, and her programming seems to be to create as huge a disaster as possible for the cameras. I still remember being chilled as the first terminator movie used its smarts to track down sarah connor in terminator. i felt no suspence or tension with the terminatrix, just waiting to see how diverge from a good story to an exploitative one.

finally, the story is boring, predictable and does not draw one in in the least. after my initial understanding that this was a ripopff movie, i just stayed because i felt i had to, and to get my money's worth. i have the other two of the series on dvd, but i would never consider this one, and would warn everyone away in hopes of sending the studios a message that we do not like being ripped-off.

title: A let down beyond all beliefs
review: I have been a fan of the series my entire life, having seen the first two movies dozens of times (saw the first terminator at the age of 7 initially). After seeing this third installment yesterday, my heart was completely broken.  I didn't think I would take it that seriously, since it is just a movie, but I guess I did.  This is my favorite series after all, and I've been looking forward to the sequel for the last ten years.      What I saw, however, was not a terminator movie, but something else.  With all due respect to Mr. Mostow, it felt as if he had a vendetta to remove every single element that James Cameron had used to make the first two movies what they were, and expect this to be even half a decent sequel.  What was he thinking?  This movie turned into a disaster on a grand scale.  The terminator was completely ruined.  In the first movie, the terminator was portrayed as a cyborg from the future with no sympathy for its victims, and a mission to accomplish.  It was a killing machine, and in my opinion, it looked frightening, and serious.  The second movie I thought did an equally acceptable job at painting this picture.  Both movies had the right music, the right mood, and the suspense required for us to believe that these terminators are not playing around, not to mention the sympathy for the main characters.  They had a very dark touch to them, and seeing the movies as a little kid gave me the creeps.  In this sequel they took that entire aspect, and ripped it out, leaving it as a souless parody.  First off, where did that music go?  That was essential to the movies, but apparently it was decided to be unnecessary this time around.  Second, is this supposed to be the terminator, or a kindergarten cop?  What is the deal with all the poorly written jokes and the ridiculous one liners.  "Talk to the hand", "I'm back" - give me a break, this is supposed to be the terminator, but they decided to turn it into one long gay joke.  The T-X did not participate nearly enough in the story, and definitely did not display it's full potential. Frankly, I was not impressed.  Instead of an evil terminator, the T-X acted more like that evil alien dressed like a Victoria Secret model from Men in Black 2, although I can't say that I wasn't impressed by the entrance. Bottom line is that the 170 million dollar budget went into some special effects and nothing else.  Here you hardly even get to see the terminators killing their victims, most of it is off screen.  Where is the blood? What's the point of the R rating?  The budget for Terminator 1 was under $7 million, and a lot more was done with that, a LOT more.  Maybe I came in with too high expectations, and the next time I watch the film it won't seem as disappointing.  But  so far all I saw was a Sci-Fi channel original presentation.

title: I said I'd be back
review:
Ahh what can I say about this movie, First of I was sceptical of the whole thing when they cast a girl as the bad guy I relly hoped vin diesl would have got the part but I saw the Movie and was impressed.

The thing you got to understand is this is like jurassic park three it is a none stop action packed romp no most people were expecting a film like the previous two where we new little about terminators or what they could do. in this movie it's more about survial and coming to girps with reallity.

All the preformances where supurb and arnold was amazing for being 50 he still wowed me at every turn

I recomend it for anyone like for action packed movie. 9/10

title: Things are not what they appear.
review: OK first of all it wasn't better then T2. but then again I don't think it was meant to be better. Who ever said that claire daines performance was poor dosen't know acting well. The scene alone when her father was dying was very sentimental. The ending of that movie is actully the beginning of T2. We got a prequal and a sequal thru temperal flux all in one movie......that really takes a brilliant writter. True it was not directed by James Cameron, but you have to think about the expectations that this director had to comply with (lots of pressure). I think he did a rather good Job, considering the movies reputation. sthal to me did a decent job of playing connor. Not the best, but good enough to gain my approval. Now as for the terminatrix......Please now that was bad acting. And can someone explain to me how she got crushed so many time and her make up never ran or smeared!!!! I don't know what kind of maybelline she was using ,but I hope it comes out on the market soon!!! Also the ending of this movie sent shivers up my back. For as much as anyone would like to down the plot, our machines attacked us (Computers) the very thing your on now.The scary part is that its not far fetched at all. We will be our own destruction. I give it a 7 out of 10.

title: T3: Rise of the One-Liners
review:
From the moment he walks on screen the T101 (Ah-nuld) is a gimmick...a pale shadow of the brutal killing machine in the first film and a one-liner spouting mockery of the ardent protector he played in the second. Sadly this film is more like the crappy first trailer that was released than the subsequent trailers that made the film look salvagable.

John Conner (Nick Stahl) is still pretty much whiney and pathetic and he seems to have developed a severe eodipal complex. Claire Danes has her 'Alien Ressurection moment' as Kate Brewster, the damsel in distress. While she has a bit more initial spunk and know-how, she is basically Sarah Conner from the first film, but not nearly as engaging as Linda Hamilton. The TX (Kristanna Loken) is a waste. She has some nifty powers, but she lacks any real 'personality.' The original T101 was brutal and methodical, the T-1000 (Robert Patrick) was cold and steely, the TX can make her breasts bigger at will. A combination of T-101 and the T-1000, the TX (or Terminatrix as they refer to her once) is an endo-skeleton covered by the shape-changing liquid metal. She doesn't talk much--which is a blessing because her delivery is stale and wooden...much like the mannequins in the window she first appears with. Seems all she can do is cock her head like a confused labrador retriever.

The action and visuals are pretty good. Nothing really truly original, but it is at least moderately satisfying. Most of it takes the form of destroyed property. There are a couple of blood n guts scenes, but alot of the most gruesome stuff is kept off-camera. The soundtrack was mediocre...I missed the very recognizable Terminator theme music.

The writers try to tackle some of the plot-holes left by the first two (self-negating) films. Some of this works and some of it doesn't. This film and the events therein BEG to be taken seriously, but belagered with such horrible dialog and cheesy one-liners it's really hard to care about the impending war and subsequent apocalypse. All they (writers and director) really managed to do was turn a smart (albeit flawed) and intense franchise into a stale and watery crockery of fondue. I knew I would miss Linda Hamilton, but I never thought I'd say this...I missed James Cameron. 3/10 Stars.

title: the BEST movie EVER
