With his complete absence from the third installment, hardcore fans will definitely notice the change in style for T-3. This comes as both a positive and a negative. T-3 does not come close to being as good as T-2, however it is still a solid movie on its own. Its action is exciting and well executed, and it's visual and sound effects are far above average. However the presence of Cameron's humour and action is sorely missed. Perhaps this is because we were so used to him being attached to the first two films that with the addition of Jonathan Mostow instead as director, things just feel a little too different. I suppose one could compare this to Steven Spielberg's departure from Jurassic Park 3 (Lost World sucked, so maybe he was just being smart, but Jurassic Park 3 was the better movie overall). Jurassic Park 3 was handled by Joe Johnston instead and with its brisk running time, the action and humour was quick and fun. T-3 has the same feel to it. Its story is not as gripping and the human emotion is not as strong as T-1 or T-2. But credit must be given to the writers and director for their attempts at matching Cameron's previous works. This film serves as an addition to Sequel Summer 2003, but it's a better than average sequel for the most part.

The acting is decent for a Sci-Fi action film and as stated before, the action and visual/sound effects will keep you entertained. The humour from the three main central cast members of Arnold, Nick Stahl, and Claire Danes is just right (Arnold's one linear are for the most part fun, but maybe a little too used towards the end of the film.). The film is also not overly long, perhaps clocking in at exactly 120 minutes.

My only major problem with the film was its musical score by Marco Beltrami. I don't understand at all why Brad Fiedel was not used again to compose and conduct the musical score. His transition from T-1 to T-2 was amazing. The new score is not horrible; it's just not memorable at all. I left the theater missing the Terminator overture (however it is played during the end credits with less effect than the touching finale in T-2.)

Another oddity was "Where exactly did Arnie get the shotgun from?" We see him get his clothes, but when he first arrives to save Katherine Brewster, he is suddenly blasting away at the T-X. An easy mistake like this would have been avoided by Cameron. This is not a big deal, but before watching T-3, I viewed T-1 and T-2 again, and Cameron was quite careful with subtle details. Perhaps a deleted scene with commentary will clear this up, but this sort of problem gives way to the notion "This movie is pretty clean cut in terms of technicalities, but because of that one noticeable error, it annoys me."

As for the T-X, I thought she was a sexy robot assassin; however I could not help but feel her improvements as a Terminator were just modified for coolness and not for killing efficiency. T-X does not hold a candle to the T-1000 in terms of presence. For the most part, Kristanna Loken's attempt as a Terminator was well attempted, but falls flat. I never felt intimidated by her and she didn't have that poker face look that Robert Patrick had when asking "Are you the legal guardians of John Connor?'

I kept myself in the dark for T-3. I didn't want to ruin it for myself. I didn't follow any news from its official website or read magazine articles. I even felt that the trailers and TV spots were poor. But upon watching the film in theaters on opening day, I was satisfied with the end product. It was just a fun film to watch. I wish the film luck in breaking even with its $170 million U.S. budget.

8/10

title: Terrible
review: You come into the movie thinking well Ebert didn't like it, but Roper did, on the second thought Roper is a little easy on judging movies. So you start to think well maybe this will be a good movie. You come out of the theater saying, I HATED THIS MOVIE, there was way to much destruction, way to many chase scenes, it's a total dissapointment to all Terminator movies, it barely anything changes anything in the Terminator saga. I gave it a 5 out of 10, the only ting that made me give more points to it, because it captured me to say "I bet you the next one will be great," this one leaves you an ending to make you think what might happen next. Out of ****, it would be a **.

title: Where is the THX????
review: I went to see T3 on Tues, night in a THX certified theater, after buying the T2 Extreme Edition DVD which was THX mastered, my hopes were that it would spill over into T3. How disappointed I was when I didn't see the THX Logo come up on the screen. Why wasn't T3 done in THX??????

title: Typical 3rd Entry
review:
T3 is like most other third entries into trilogies: it has run out of steam. The idea of a futuristic, omnipotent robot being sent back into time to eradicate the head of a stubborn resistance to a future apocalypse was novel in 1984 and was mastered in 1991. But now it is getting old, just like Arnie.

The following is a step by step analysis of why T2 just didn't work.

SPECIAL EFFECTS: The notion that after a 12 year impeovement in technology and 70 million dollar increase in budget will ensure superior special effects is a given. T3 has better special effects than T2. But that is the only significant category that it scores a win.

VILLAIN: This was the biggest mistake made by the developers of this film. The TX was not nearly as imposing or fearsome as either of her predecessors. I just don't have the same fear of a woman that I would a man. Secondly, why would Skynet go back to an exoskeleton robot?! Robert Patrick's liquid metal was an idea that should have been expanded in this movie, not scrapped. They should have gone with Vin Diesal, a man who can hold his own with Arnie.

JOHN CONNOR: Although Stahl was adequate as Furlong's replacement, he didn't have the same edge.

PLOT: There were way too many holes in this plot. So many things were left either unexplained or were not elaborated on. For example, how could Skynet have been created after they destroyed its roots in T2? Granted, the end twist was clever, and the last 30 minutes were definetely a return to T2 form, but it just didn't feel like a Terminator movie, and too many questions were left unanswered. Interestingly, hints were given for a T4, and the ending left that door wide open and swinging.

MUSIC: Music plays a vital role in the suspense of a movie. So many times in T3, I was wishing for the T2 theme to start playing. It really would have added to the adrenaline rush that I felt so many times in T2.

In conclusion, T3 seemed like a hastily prepared entry into such an intricately developed franchise. While T2 is the greatest action movie of alltime, T3 is an adequate sequel, highly entertaining (in part because of the humorous side to it), but nothing more. It sits nicely alongside the first two, and is by no means a Jaws 3, but doesn't have the chemistry that either of the first two had. Mostow is not Cameron, Loken is not Patrick, Stahl is not Furlong, and even though Arnie was still Arnie, T3 is not T2.

title: Robots, Guns and Hot Chicks??? What more can you ask for!!!
review:
I just saw this movie today and man was I blown away. T3 has everything a guy could ask for, hense the title. But where to start, hmmmm...

Let's start with Arnold. The original Terminator really puts life into a movie franchise that has been missing for almost 12 years. He really blew the movie away with his incredible acting and even better fighting scenes. The new John Conner, Nick Stahl, may seem like an odd and unknown choice at first, but he is really worthy of the role of Earth's future leader. He really breathed life into the role, plus he didn't sound like a girl when he screamed. Together, Arnold and Nick really make a great onscreen team.

But moving on to the main reason the movie was so great, the girls, Claire Daines and , especially, Kristanna Loken, were down right hot. Claire Daines replaces the empty role of the fighting machine that Linda Hamilton was in the first two movies. But even her good looks couldn't compete with Kristanna Loken's sexy killing machine that is the TX. Armed with a multi weapon arm, a shape-shifting body, an inflatable chest, etc. Kristanna really proved that the new female Terminator is nothing to be triffled with.

Overall, this movie rocked and is definantly a movie that needs to be seen by any sci-fi or Terminator fan. MAKE SURE IT BEATS OUT SINBAD AND LEGALLY BLONDE II!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Good Day....

title: With a slight bit of cheese, T3 still works for me
review: I was kind of reluctant in seeing this movie today but I am very glad I did. T3 really lives up to the other two. The weaponry of the terminatrix kind of left me uneasy and I was asking "How could the car speed up when she killed the guy by impaling him and she was in the back seat?" Oh well, all in all it was still a good movie. A couple of things I liked about the movie was an AWESOME chase scene with the crane. The best I have seen in a long time. Also the ending (I wont give it away) was reminiscent of my feelings of when I watched the end of the `The Planet of the Apes.' Should you go see it in the theaters? YES. for the crane chase scene alone. yes yes yes. But for the rest of the movie?  Sure, why not. Although if your like me and you like everything to fit. some of the scenes might irk ya.

title: T3 just good enough
review:
Why did Jonathan Mostow blow all the one-liners and comic relief in the 1st 1/2 hour? There was absolutely no tension in this movie because every time you got into the movie, it'd be like "Hey look what the funny emotionless robot's doing! oh arnie, will you ever learn?!"

A lot of awesome action sequences etc in this movie, but I didn't believe for a second that these people feared for their lives. I'd watch T2 again before T3. And Reloaded kicks the shiza out of it.

title: Plot holes, but not bad!
review:
Okay, there is a lot of plot holes! To begin, many things that were supposed to be explained were not. That's the biggest stuff.

I did miss Sarah Conner, because she was MUCH better than the new gal that is replacing her (no, she is not Sarah Conner recasted, her name is Brewster, and she's not even half as interesting as Sarah).

Still, the movie is good for a sequel. Better than the first (since it mostly was to set up 2 anyway), but definitely not better than T2. It's just a decent sequel.

Some stuff works, some doesn't, but overall it's a good film. I recommend it for the fans.

8/10

title: Spoilers!!!!!!! My Review
review:
This is my full review of T3:rise of the machines i just saw this movie about a half hour ago.

I must say that i had doubts when i went into the theatres that this movie was not going to be as good as the first 2 one main reason is that James Camerons name is nowhere to be found but i must say i was pleasently surprised with the outcome.T3 has action and lots of from the crane chase to the end of the movie it is a non stop thrill ride complete with the humor and gore.Oh and don't forget the best part of this movie the story it has a great one and i must say this movie was not just mad for the sake of making a sequel they took great care in coming up with the plot (thats why it took 12 years)to make the film.

On to the next part of my review which is the acting.The acting is very good from Nick stahl to Clair Danes it is on par with the amount that is required to do a movie like this.

The Cgi flawless i thought it is the best and most realistic i have seen so far this year it is used sparingly and sometimes u never even know that its there.

The Direction i know it is no James Cameron but it still is a accomplisment to take on a burden this much and then pull it off as much as Jonathon Mostow has.good job

The Music the one thing i hate about this movie no use of the original theme only at the end but still has an ok score.

The Story on par with the rest of the series and has its place within the terminator construct.Well done and i look forword to the next one.

The script very good explains whats going on very well the only thing that sucks is the comedy to much in a film franchise that focused on taking itself seriously.

Final word good addition to the best trilogy ever yes there are some bad things about it but they are overuled by the good things a good sequel and i hope they mke a T4 before Arnold gets old.Oh and don't forget the T-X great entertainment

All in all BEST MOVIE OF THE SERIES AND THE SUMMER!!!!!!!

9/10

title: Must See
review: Awesome action and special effects, nice actress (Kristanna Loken as TX), humour, I think Terminator 3 is a suitable continuity of terminator 1-2 (you will notice it in the begining) as it it one of my favorite film ever! Long life to "The rise of machines"!!!

title: Hmmmmmmm......
review: Being a huge fan of the Terminator series I was skeptical about T3.  At first I thought there was no way it could be as amazing as T2, especially since it was being done by a different director.  When I saw the trailer to the movie, my mind changed instantly.  I couldn't wait to see it.  In the end however, the trailer was better than the movie.  Sad... It happened in Star Wars Episode 2, and it happened in this.  The problem was the story. Very weak, not enough of it, and too many parts left unexplained.  This probably is the greatest "B" movie of all time, but it could never stand up to T2 or even T1 for that matter.  Why?  No Cameron.  It's just that simple. He created the idea, he knows it best.  Mostow did good with the action, but the story just wasn't up to expectations.  The TX had the potential to be an awesome villain but in the end I think Dr. Silverman could have kicked her ass.  Good action, weak story.  This movie was rushed.  I give it a 5 out of 10.

title: "Anyone expecting something special is gonna have a real bad day get it!."
review:
The first TERMINATOR remains my favorite film ever. The second is right up there. So as far as film going goes these films mean a lot to me. Is it just me or are big films getting worse by the month. Even with hints of decent stories pictures are so rushed now. Special effects, BOOM, special effects, JUMP CUT, F/X GALLORE, BOOM...THE END.

I miss the days of the eighties action flicks. Even the early nineties hung in there a bit with TOTAL RECALL, TERMINATOR 2 (despite its morality) and NATURAL BORN KILLERS. My point is these films the good ones, the intense action ones...the fun ones all stuck with violence. Shying away from violence teaches us guns and explosions lack consequence. Not to mention it's all fantasy. We're being taught not to have imagination.

The evolution of film ceases to exist. Technology needs to complement not substitute a story (a la MATRIX RE-LOADED and Terminator 3). Hopefully M. Night or Peter Jackson, or some kid at home writing a great story will inspire us.

title: It's no Matrix Reloaded, but...
review:
To say that the chase sequence, one of the few in Terminator 3, is as good as the highway chase in The Matrix Reloaded is stretching it a bit. I should say this though: The action in T3 is better than the action in any of the previous installments. They do a good job of tying in the previous two movies with references to Sarah Connor, as well as John Connor's lines to T-101: "Don't you remember me? Hasta la vista? Any of that ring a bell?" As well as a cameo by one of the supporting cast members of T2.

I'd say one of my few disappointments with this film would be the opening credits. I was expecting something along the lines of T2, but they went a different route this time, and the catchy Terminator music doesn't come into play until the final credits, but oh well, just one small gripe.

This movie is definitely worth seeing, and this is coming from someone who goes into movies like this thinking, "Great, another sequel. It's going to suck." But I enjoyed myself. They obviously didn't make this movie to get any Oscar bids, but they did cater to the audience, and made sure those who paid to see it had a good time...afterall, isn't that what it's all about?

title: Great movie, must see! Arny still kicks butt.
review: The action of this movie was intense. The stunts were well thought of, and well done. The plot is great. T1 was pre skynet, T2 was present skynet, T3 is future skynet. Even with the T-X model sent back to destroy Connor and his leutenants, the T-101 still is the force to be tested.

title: ONE OF THE BEST MOVIES OF THE YEAR!!!!!!!!!!!(No Spoilers)
review: I am not joking when I say this movie is the best of the year. I saw it opening day and I will never forget it. It could be one of the best in the series, and I am one of the die hard fans for the terminator series. It is Worthy of 1st or 2nd. The action is incredible. It was some of the best special effects ever. It looked as real as it could get. Even though Cameron was not the director, it would not have made a difference. An ending to die for is what left me with my jaw Dropped. Go see it now. And if you have seen it see it again, as I know I will. You Will Not be disappointed.

title: HE'S BACK!!
review: TALK ABOUT A TREMENDOUS MOVIE!anyone who's anyone will watch this movie, that's how good it actually is. The movie is basicaly about John's final adventure with the T-800 before he faces the complete destruction of America. I, honestly, thought Jonathan Mostow was going to present to the audience an over-exaggerated sequel that had NOTHING to do with the actual terminator script. However, i was mistaken and pleasantly surprised. My suggestion is for people all around the world to go see this movie; it's worth watching. "TRUST ME".

title: The trailers made this movie look bad!
review: I was a little nervous going into this movie because of the trailers, but my skepticism was for nothing.  The movie is great!  TONS of action, good story (I think they resolve this issues of judgment day and skynet very well). I'm VERY into the first two movies and I believe this one is a fantastic sequel and you shouldn't be disappointed.

title: Thank you God
review: I am a huge fan of the Terminator films and since i saw the first trailer I've been hoping this film doesnt suck and ruin the franchise (a la Batman and Robin).  Well they pulled it off.  While its not as good as T2, T3 is certainly an action packed film from the start, and I thought it was awesome.  It moves along at a much faster pace than the previous two films, therefore it lags behind the others in plot and story, however its right up there with them in adreniline pumping action and that occasional humor. However, the timline explained in this film is even more messed up than the timeline in T2 believe it or not.  Am I the only person who has ever noticed that in T2 when the T1000 looks up John in the police database it specifically says he is 10?  Well, those are the only gripes I have cause the rest of the film was awesome and I will see it again.

title: Very Good.
review:
31/2 stars.

This Terminator is not only better but it also lives up to the originals. Why! It has a new Terminator which is a female. I loved it. I think its one of the best sequels ever made. This movie has lots of explosions that will blow you away! However in any good movie there is problems. This movie is short about 1 hour and 39 minutes. "Spoiler Alert" Guess what if you thought John Conner stopped Judgement Day in number 2 you are wrong. All he did was postponed to a later date. Thats all I am willing to reveal for the secrets. One last thing the ending is so good you will want to see more. Unfortunately we have to wait until Terminator 4 comes out.

title: Great Fx, but is that enough?
review:
This did not live up to my expectations for the Terminator series.

Yes, there are REAL fx, and the crane scene is fantastic. It's tough to beat the cgi of the matrix, but reality is a lot scarier than a stop action fight scene on a semi.

And yes, the terminatrix is amazing. Great acting and cgi, but the T-1000 in T2 just seemed to be a lot scarier. She held her own, and tried to play the T-1000 style, but... Is it even possible to destroy her?

The lines in T1 and T2 did seem like they were 'right on', but like the other reviews have said, T3 just seemed a little off here and there. And just 'appearing' in a top secret base with weapons loaded is a BIG stretch. Did they cut a scene or two to get it under two hours??

I could watch T1 and T2 a few times, but I was disappointed with T3.

All your base are belong to us.

title: James Cameron: where art thou? The spirit you gave T1 & 2 has been Terminated!
review:
Plot Details: This opinion reveals minor details about the movie's plot.

T-3 doesn't have the feeling, spirit or intensity of T-1 or T-2. I say this with a heavy heart.

T-1 & 2 are among my favorite movies of all time. Arnie is the perfect Terminator, and I love many of his movies. This is the first time I've seen Nick Stahl, Kristanna Loken, or Claire Danes, and they all did a great job.

But the magic of the previous films was not there. The movie seemed like it was made by following the script and storyboards like a studio musician playing the notes from his sheet. Done correctly, but certainly not a Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison... and others like them who gave performances that explode with intense passion.

John Conner (Nick Stahl) He's burned out, on the run, doesn't have a plan or any direction, and a total wimp. Not even his Terminator obeys him.

T-X (Kristanna Loken) She's the new Terminator, and like her predecessor, the T-1000 played by Robert Patrick in T-2, she can change her appearance (but confusingly has the hard steel skeleton of the earlier model T-800, that Arnold plays) So sometimes she's liquid steel, and sometimes not, since she can change from female to male. Her face is beautiful and exotic, and she can look very cold, confident, and robotic; but not wicked evil and totally dedicated like Patrick's Terminator of T-2.

Kate Brewster (Claire Danes) Nice close-ups, a beautiful face and good acting, she played her part well. Still, there was simply not the intensity of purpose that Linda Hamilton brought to the previous films.

T-800 (Arnold) Erroneously calling himself a T-101, Arnie, is back! Arnie, of course is `The Terminator,' so it's hard to screw-up that role. But he can only do what the script allows. He plays his part, delivers his one-liners, but is a different Terminator than he played earlier. Same model, but as we all know, the second Terminator played by Arnold, was terminated. So there is no `feeling' between him and John Conner, or Kate Brewester like there was in the earlier films between John and his mother Sara Conner. In fact it seems Arnold doesn't care about them at all.

Music Score: What score? Although Terminator has one of the finest theme and soundtrack music in the history of modern movies, they simply didn't use it. It's like a Star Wars movie without the classic theme song. A major mistake.

Tension, mood, drama, feeling, intensity, story, plot. ooops, completely forgot about all of that. Just cram in as much action and destruction as a movie can hold within one hour and 45 minutes.

Special Effects: At least most of them were real (I hope) as opposed to computer generated. I'm talking about the `Vehicle' chase scenes. In this episode, female Terminator TX remotely controls un-manned police and fire engines, while simultaneously and physically driving a large crane on wheels, laying massive destruction in her path. Many cars and telephone poles lost their lives in this chase scene. While very destructive, it just didn't compare to previous Terminator chase scenes, especially the one in the concrete storm ditch of T-2. Surprisingly, special effects were minimal and not very impressive. The steel Terminator endoskeleton was the same as the original, so nothing new there and personally, I thought the flying robots looked very amateur and out-dated.

The screening I attended was the first public showing in one of Los Angeles', newest and largest theatres. It was of course filled, but the audience reaction was very subdued. A few chuckled at some of the one-liners and one couldn't help but laugh at Arnie's first pair of sunglasses. Another laugh came when the Female Terminator TX saw a billboard with a Buxom model with the words: What is Sexy?' and decided to redirect some of her liquid steel to her chest area and - Viola! Instant breast enlargement! The interesting thing is the very favorable and quite audible reaction was by the females in the audience as they squealed with joy and envy at such power.

In conclusion, I think the movie suffered without the direction of James Cameron. The plot was filled with holes the size of large nuclear craters. The movie was dependant on fast action to carry it, but other than the chase scene near the beginning, it just didn't. The ending was very weak, but its intent was quite obvious - it was a lead-in to Terminator 4. As Arnold likes to say: "I'll be back!"

The Bottom Line: Disappointment. Even still, I recommend seeing it because the series, like Star Wars, is a legend. It would leave a void otherwise, and it's necessary to understand future Terminator movies.

title: Unworthy to carry the name Terminator!
review: I watched this film eagerly as a fan of the first two films and was disappointed.  James Cameron's characters and story has been changed (in the words of monty python)  "for something completely different"!  The Terminator series is a world envisioned by Cameron and the director of this film took the story along his own path. Granted, the special effects were excellent as was the acting of the two terminators, but Linda Hamilton was wise to back away from this third film as it had no heart. It's an excellent action film with its humorous moments, but the true fans will see this film as an unworthy creation undeserving of the title Termiantor 3.  This film does not make the terminator series a trilogy as it begins a whole new story into the wars after Judgement Day.  Its title should only be "Rise of the Machines" for this film failed to live up to the TERMINATOR standards created by the cast and crew of the first two films.

title: A Hero in the making
review:
T3: Rise of the Machines is the 3rd installment of the Terminator series. Though many critics may claim that the absence of director James Cameron may have influenced the style and feel of the movie, I beg to differ, and must add that Jonathon Mostow has done a great job at elevating the depth of the Terminator series fanthom more. Of all the features that this movie displays, its main appeal comes from its level of realism, which adds to its worth in our everyday lives and its influence on various choices and applications that mankind drives to make.

The cast is mint, fresh off the shelf (with the exception of Arnold, and on a lighter note, a comic relief Earl Boen, aka. Dr. I'm not Crazy but I am going Crazy). Nick Stahl does an excellent job at fitting the role of John Connor, as he is an highly undescisive character that is not obviously determined to save the world, nor denies his existence, but rather, lives to see himself evolve into the leader of the resistence. Clares Daine does a pretty good job at playing newly introduced and old time childhood friend Brewster, but nothing worth noting. Arnold? Heck, this guy is unstoppable, since he is essentially, body, mind and soul, the living version of Terminator itself. Unfortunately, Loken, falls a bit short in giving the audience that thriller look. Certainly, she is sexy, sleek and even a bit quirky, but I don't think it was really her fault for her lack of thrillism (invented word), but the castings' fault. All in all, she does give it her best.

The first half hour of T3 is sort of an introduction of what John Connor has become since the last installment. John Connor, trying to protect mankind, hides himself from society and becomes a ghost to the world. Not quite, as KAZAAM, TX appears in her little magic ball, etc. etc.. etc... From here on, there is nothing but pure heart-pounding action, and perhaps the greatest scene was the massive 6 car/truck chase b/w TX, T Model 101, Connor and Brewster. The effects in this movie puts Matrix and its successors to shame. It just goes to show that to make something look real, it ought to be real. Anyhow, that's my 2 cents. I give this installment 4/5 stars (relative to 4/5 stars for T2 and 4.5/5 stars for T1).

title: A surprisingly good follow-up to one of the best action movies of all time.
review: I, like many other people, went into see terminator 3 with a grim face. After all, how could any movie top terminator 2?  Especially with everything that was going against this movie being good.  After watching it though, I am a convert.  Terminator 3 is both an excellent movie experience and a thrilling follow-up to T2.  The only thing that dampened the movie for me were the sheer number of people who sat their hating on the movie. Going to see T3 with loads of amateur "movie critics" is a bad idea.  As is going to see T3 with the impression that its going to be anything more than a thrilling action romp through the present day.  In my book T3 succeeds to do everything it set out to and then some.  I definitely rank it a 10/10

title: Much better than it should be
review:
Mostow's a hack, Arnold has lost his machismo over the years, and the story of T3 is nearly the same thing we saw 10 years ago in Cameron's T2.

So why is this movie *the* summer action movie of 2003?

Because it avoids using tacky, modern, computer special effects (*cough*...Matrix Reloaded) and instead uses classic Hollywood stunt work and REAL cars smashing into each other. Because it has a tight narrative that doesn't indulge itself while keeping the audience hostage until the climax we all paid $8 for.

The (surprisingly thin) audience for this flick on July 3rd was only happy to oblige the film with applause and laughs. This movie is great fun, much more fun than Hulk or Matrix 2. There is something charming about an action movie where the hero actually looks like a hero rather than some pallid dork in a black trenchcoat who is more interested in looking good than pounding their enemy into a pulp.

The best action sequences of the summer of 2003 are in Terminator 3, no question about it. The movie cost $170 million and you see every cent on screen. Arnold's T-101 takes more and more damage as the film progresses. You first see blood, then scaring with metal underneath, then complex CGI/makeup/prosthesis where you can actually see THROUGH Arnold's jaw structure. This is Stan Winston's best work in years and proves he is still at the top of his game.

Linda Hamilton's Sarah Connor was always an annoying character and it's good to see her out of the series to focus more attention on John Connor. Sarah always came across as an anti-social, bitter hippy rather than somebody who has the burden of man's ultimate survival on her shoulders.

The script is nothing amazing, although it has an excellent ending that gives the film some real gravity. The film is full of humor and resembles the original Terminator film more closely than T2 in this regard.

If you want to know what T3 is like think of it this way:

Take T2, strip out Sarah Connor, take out about 30 minutes of worthless boy/robot bonding and ridiculous man/machine sentiment (remember that horrible weepy ending to T2? LOL!), add an Arnold who is less apt to mock himself and a very serious, somber ending and you have T3.

Really the only thing lacking is T1000 from T2. Robert Patrick did a great job, and don't get me wrong...the chick who plays the T-X does a great job as well, but for some reason she just isn't as menacing. She seems to not be able to handle good old T-101 as well as the T1000 could. I would also really like to see her in a bathing suit.

title: inferior
review: This was a sad sad attempt to make a another installment to some pretty great films.  First off, they try to add too much comedy to the movie making it a times just plain stupid.  The T-X is great to look at, but other than that, she is cheap attempt to recapture the magic of T-1000.  The sound is off and cartoonish at times, just to name a few flaws.  In my opinion, the only redeemining thing form this film is the ending which I thought was kind of cool.  See it if you must, but it really is a let down.

title: Dispite bad scripts, good movie
review: Terminator 3 Rise of the Machines is a good movie for kids 14 and up.  I don't really understand why it is rated R except for the strong violence. Arnold does a awesome job at being a bad ass and kicking some machine butt. In the beginning they try to set up the viewers with a little information about what Judgement day is and who John Conner is.  I would however recommend seeing one of the previous Terminators before seeing this film. It is action packed and very funny (in a good way).  Arnold has developed a witty sense of humor in this film and it lets the audience take a deep breath and relax from all the action.  A good movie for guys, girls-only go as a favor to your man, otherwise you'll be bored stiff.  Good film, check it out for yourself... It IS the summer of sequels after all.

title: Great Special Effects! Exciting!
review:
Well - of course the story has plenty of flaws.........but that's to be expected - this film is about the special effects and the cyborgs! It kept me on the edge of my seat the whole movie.....

As good as the other two, if not better in my opinion.........

Definitely worth seeing in the theatre! And then again on DVD later!

I highly recommend this film - 9 out of 10.

title: Wow -Spoilers-
review:
Spoilers............................................................................

I thought the movie was actually pretty good, action was great even though some scenes dragged like the one where the huge crane truck was tearing up the whole city but it made for a pretty enjoyable film.

I know there are a ton of hardcore Terminator fans that are probably gonna be disappointed with the movie because of many things, director change, the female terminator (who i thought actually acted pretty well for a big budget newcomer), and the new kid (Nick Stahl).

Personally I really liked the movie, action and all of that but I gotta admit some stuff was lacking like I missed the relationship building between the characters like Arnie and John Connor how they were 'friends' in the 2nd movie. In this movie Arnie seemed alot less friendly and I didn't really like that. But hey, everybody wants to have their cake and eat it :D so in my opinion it's a movie worth seeing even for die hard Terminator fans who might not get everything they wanted in it. I give it 8 of out 10 stars.

Good job on bringing the Terminator back to life.

title: Suprisingly not awful
review: No, I didn't think it was better than T2, or as good as T2. However, I do think it was a -HELL- of a lot better than I assumed it would be when I originally heard that a new Terminator movie was being made sans Cameron and Hamilton. Don't expect it to surpass the first two Ts and enjoy it for the solid action flick it is.

title: I'll Be... Funny?
review:
Given the advance word was so awful, I was relieved to find this to be an entertaining, almost jocular movie at times. Mostow made a good choice in making this a self-referential flick that borders on near-parody at times, only to lose the levity when the drama required it. I won't spoil the ending, but this movie has stones, that's for sure. High art it ain't, but high entertainment it is. Sure, it's got plot holes you could drive a giant crane chasing a giant fire truck through, but honestly, it's T3, what do you expect? Sit back, check that film school attitude at the door, and let Governor Arnie remind you why he is who he is.

And damn, Schwarzenegger looks as sculpted here as he did 20 years ago. It's a sight to behold. I wonder if there's a bit of Bond-O holding things together, but it's impressive nonetheless.

title: Loud, wantonly cruel, but almost thoughtful
review: This film is another step in a steady progression toward de-humanizing screen violence. There is precious little redemption to be had and a constant message of acceptance of wanton killing. Human feelings on novacaine.

title: too short, but still very good.
review:
Of course this is not better than T2, which is the best in the franchise so far. T1 is slightly better than T3 though. The movie just felt too short. Even at an hour & 45 minutes, it just felt like it should be longer.

The humor had its hits & misses. Ah-nold was great as usual, though some of his 1-liners weren't the best. Nick Stahl & Claire Danes did real good jobs too.

The T-X chick did good, though Robert Patrick is still the best villian in the franchise.

The CGI was actually decent when used, & didnt really ruin the movie (i.e. HULK, CHARLIES ANGELS 2).

This is 1 of the better movies to come out this year, so go see it. Though its still too short. :(

title: surprisingly good!
review: I went to see this movie today and I knew going in that it would'nt be as good as the first two film's since (1) James Cameron did not come back to direct and (2) both Edward Furlong and Linda Hamilton did not reprise they're original roles.  But after seeing it I was surprised that the film was actually pretty good.  The action scenes were pretty cool, especially the chase with the crane, and the acting was good as well.  One problem I had was the ending of the film which I will not spoil, but aside from that it is a pretty good sequel to two classic sci-fi action film's. 3.5/5

title: T2 is still #1! But T3 is a worthy sequel
review:
I saw T3 on July 3, 2003 and it was great! The effects were great and the characters! But there was one problem, EVERYTHING WAS TOO EXTREME! Almost everything seemed impossible! Something like the T-X can never exist! I mean a combination of liquid metal and a robot! It's impossible to create such a thing. Even for 2029, it's still extreme. Arnold was the best character and stole the show. The sexy T-X made a great appearance and I give this film a 7. Where's Cameron when you need him? The problem with the second milleniumm, is some of the movies. Matrix Reloaded was horrible! I hated it! X-Men and X2 were fantastic! Spider-Man was awesome! Hulk was extreme! T3 was okay, but still worthy to be called a "movie". Nice try, Mostow. If you have any comments for me, please e-mail me at tylerripen@yahoo.com.

P.S. Freddy vs Jason will be the bomb and Pirates of the Caribbean will make millions!

title: Not bad. Not bad at all!
review:
Being that 1. James Cameron had nothing to do with this picture and 2. I knew this movie was bound to turn the Terminator series into one big continuity error (which in many ways it already was), I went into the theater today expecting a disaster. Surprisingly though, the end result is pretty good.

My misgivings about a third Terminator film were, "Didn't James Cameron and William Wisher make it abundantly clear that they resolved it by the end of the last one?" But the new Arnold model explains that the actions at the end of the movie, "Only postponed Judgement Day. It is inevitable." Which explains it. The writing and directing on this film is not as solid as both of its' predecessors were, but they're not bad either. Only problem with Jonathan Mostow as a director was, if Ang Lee had taken this instead of The Hulk, he could have given it the darker Cameron-esque feel to it that it lacks with Mostow. But it is well-done with him.

People don't generally watch movies like the Terminator series for its' Oscar winning acting (and if they do, it's time to get off the reefer), but most of it is pretty good. The T-X is the most interesting Terminator villain, primarily because she is played by Kristanna Loken, whom I'm going to keep an eye on from now one because she's one of the most beautiful girls I've ever seen. Nick Stahl, as John Connor, is a little less successful than Edward Furlong, but he's not bad. Only real disappointment was Claire Danes, because I just don't see her as John Connor's girlfriend.

I'm not going to point out the continuity errors on this, no spoilers, just errors pointed out:

1. When the Terminator, John and Kate come across Sarah Connor's "grave" it is marked: 1959-1997. In the Terminator, which is clearly and distinctly set in 1984, Sarah is nineteen. So she would have been born in 1955, not 1959. 2. This movie is set in 2003, but John Connor is said to be twenty-two. In T2, which was set in 1994, he was supposed to be ten, not thirteen, as said in this movie. Although to be fair, the actor playing young John was 13 at the time.

A few nitpicks, but nothing major. Good day.

title: HUGE LETDOWN
review:
I need to be very careful not to give away anything, but I will state what I feel the major failings are:

1) From Edge of Realism to Comic Book. The thing I loved about the first 2 movies was even though much of it was unbelievable, there was quite a bit of tension and realism to the characters and chases. The problem was that T2 pushed the limits. They decided to go farther, and it just became rediculous. Most of the chases I found myself laughable they were so silly.

2) Too Many rules changed. If you watch T1 and T2 before T3, you will see exactly what I mean by the way the T-101 acted, especially, since it's not supposed to be the same as from the prior movie(s).

3) The theme changed. I feel like the story was going one way in the first 2 movies, and they completely changed their minds as to what to do.

Now, I don't want to say the story was without merit and the ending wasn't good, but it was executed and designed POORLY. It feels more like "let's revive the Terminator movie just to make it" rather than "now, how do we pull it all together?".

I think perhaps another 6 months to 1 year to work on the storyboarding and scripting was needed to make this a really good movie, because if this was the first movie, there would NEVER EVER EVER been even a snowflake's chance in hell on the hottest day of the year while sitting in an over set to 5,000,000 F all day for a sequel, let alone anyone caring about it.

James Cameron, WHY DID YOU LET THEM DO THIS TO YOUR MOVIE???!!!!! I DON'T CARE IF YOU DIDN'T WANT TO DO IT, YOU SHOULD OF DONE SOMETHING TO HAVE SAVED THIS MOVIE FROM WHAT HAPPENED!

title: Missing It's Heart
review:
I am Arnie's BIGGEST fan.....I don't think it's a coincidence that we were both born July 30!

My tradition is to see all of Arnie's movies on opening day and this was no exception. I really, really liked T3....Arnie is still fantastic. My only let down was how little I was "moved" by the message of the movie, as I was in T1 and T2. This was the only thing I felt was missing....there seemed to be no "heart and soul." Would I recommend going to see it? OF COURSE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

title: A- (Action Minus Soul)
review:
As a movie seen only for Action: finely entertaining. As a film based on some kind of story: hardly entertaining.

It's always good when a sequel can stand alone as a story, but T3 would fail (miserably) to do so. T3 is more of an extended ending to T2, as no effort is made to really set the scene in this movie. Instead, T3 relies on its previous incarnations for any understanding of what is happening or why.

As almost everything is recycled, and the only surprise is

the not exceptionally optimistic end, the Who Cares factor

kills the terminators deader than they already are.

So hey, the cars go boom boom nicely. The robots menace. Claire Danes looks less interesting than she would in a 30 second commercial.

See it because the action is decent. But don't go expecting to come out of it excited about the possibility of T4, cause the new improved terminator has no soul.

title: No No No!
review: No No No! Mr. Mostow, what are you doing! You had this movie going! This movie was fantastic! Why did you end the movie on a sour note? Why did you set the tone for another movie?! This could've been an amazing conclusion to it all! The movie was sooo good until the end. What a mistake. This movie had action, suspense, and curiousity. Why did you end the movie like that?! The ending could have been sooo much better. I'm disappointed. Up until the ending you made me not want to leave the theater. I hate when perfect movies end badly. It could have been better. I wish it was.

title: Wow...unbelievable experience
review: i just T3 Yesterday, It opened a day early in Canada. What can i say, it's the best movie i've seen this whole year. The action is non-stop and surprisingly it had a wonderful story. Arnie of course was just simply great as the terminator, althought this time he mad much more humour that the previous terminators. The rest of the cast did their roles accordingly. The highlight of this movie is seeing Arnold back and the dream is just watchin one of the greatest action movie franchises back. I love good action movies, and none is greater than T2, and watching T3 in this day, where they don't make good movies, it was beautiful to see a movie like this. Arnie is the kick of Action and the Terminator is his gateway to pure mayhem. A must see Movie. ****

title: A good, solid, film; however, the lack of Cameron diminishes it's overall effect.
review:
The original "Terminator" was an amazing film for 1984, the action was unprecedented, the visuals phenomenal, and the human drama a welcome surprise. In 1991 James Cameron shocked audiences by making T2 better than the original in almost every area; creating one of the greatest films of all time. T3: Rise Of The Machines is a really good film; however, the lack of Cameron's directing is felt throughout the entire film, greatly diminishing its overall effect. For instance, the acting sequences in this one are more confusing than the one's in T2; gone are the days of the T-1000(in a Semi) chasing the young John Conner(on a dirt-bike) while Arnold(on a Harley) pursues both of them. Cameron has a way of making audiences completely understand an action sequence, Jonathan Mostow still has a lot to learn.

As T3 begins we don't get any of the classic Terminator music that was present in the last 2 films, instead we get eary music which is very quickly followed by the film's title, "Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines;" which of course is then followed by Arnold's full name, reminding all of us that while James Cameron and Linda Hamilton may be missing, we all came to see Arnold kick some ass. The film has a hard time, at first, making us feel pity or any other form of compassion for, the older and more mature, John Conner. Thankfully by the time John explains to us how his mother, Sarah Conner, died of cancer we've actually grown to like John. Soon after the introduction of John, we meet the new terminator: a Terminatrix, played farely well by newcomer Kristinna Lokken. The TX is an improvement over the T-1000, she can form weapons with her liqued metal skin and she can also infiltrate and control other machines; however, despite all of her advancements she doesn't quite make us shuddder in fear like the original T-101 or T-1000. After all of the new characters have been introduced the movie descends into one action scene after another, while all are good, we still feel like we're covering old ground. Thankfully, just when you think the new Terminator is a little soft, she graphically impales a detective with her arm and then procedes to drive the car from the back seat: With Her "ARM" still sticking through his chest! Yes, it was a very disturbing scene. Despite all of the new action sequences, I really enjoyed listening the John Conner's little lectures about the future, fate, machines and his own destiny. They didn't feel "canned" in the least, I was very impressed.

By the end of T3, I realised two very important things: (1) I actually care about what happens to John Conner and (2) The storyline of T2 has become "almost" completely obsolete; I may be the only one who feels this way, but the 3rd film in a trilogy is supposed to build upon the plot in the "middle" movie, not refute it. So there you have it, T3 is a new kind of Terminator movie; it doesn't improve upon the second film, but it presents a new face that's different enough to make the film very entertaining.

title: Finally, for the Terminator series fan...
review:
I applaud the creators for taking the time to making sure a sequel is true to its predecessors. Although the plot is amazingly similar to the previous two Terminator films, it introduces enough new storyline content to make it interesting, and also leave you hungry for whatever may come next.

The action scenes were definitely in-line with what you would expect from a $170 million dollar budget, and the character development was right-on.

Having waited all this time for the next installment of the Terminator series, I found the movie was a must see, and I was not disappointed.

title: GREAT
review: This movie was absolutely awesome from start to finish.  Words alone cannot describe how I feel about this movie.  I highly recommend this movie to any movie-goer.  And, as a final note Bye-Bye Matrix Reloaded you've been terminated.

title: The Best Terminator Ever!!!!
review: this is the best terminator! tons of action, chase scenes and the T-X rules!!! I liked her better than Arnie!! The story is incredible and picks up where T2 left off. The special effects are so amazing that if you took all the action from terminator 1 and 2 it wouldn't even add up the amount in T3  go see it!

title: T3 Rocks!
review: I was completely surprised and impressed by this movie!  The acting was great!  The story was great!  and I think everyone that sees it will have a fun time! Nick Stahl (John Connor) does an amazing job!  I don't think they could have picked anyone better.

title: Best sequel I've seen in a while
review: Even if T3 seems to be just a modified remake of T2, that alone should make it worth watching. As a sequel, T3 will undoubtedly be attacked as not breaking any new ground like T1 (in a thematic way) or T2 (pioneering computer imaging), and for dragging out a franchise and career of an actor that some say should have long been put to rest. As a great fan of the other two Terminator movies, however, I have no problem with a 3rd installment that hasn't changed much. It still has thrilling action that even blows away summer block-buster rivals Hulk and Matrix Reloaded, and sustains the excitement through its open-ended conclusion. The dialogue, chock full of one-liners resembling classic Ah-nold flicks like Commando and Total Recall, is a bit corny in spots, but is generally enjoyable. Interestingly, this sequel returns to the gloom and doom theme choice of T1, and not the playful "boy and his robot" type of lightness of T2. All in all, this has been the best action movie and best sequel I have seen in a long, long time.

title: A great addition to the Terminator series, but it's no T2
review:
Just don't expect something to top Terminator 2 when you sit down and watch it. I can't say that enough.

However, the movie is definitely exciting and very good...finally a good movie in the summer of 2003. Incredible action sequences (the car chase is better than the Matrix's) and a great story with some interesting characters. The TX terminator does a really good job (almost as good as Robert Patrick did in T2) and is also extremely hot. So, yeah, nothing wrong there.

Go check it out, especially if you loved T2. This is definitely a movie to catch this summer no matter what, though.

title: Mixed Bag
review:
I went into T3 not knowing what to expect. I came away not knowing what to think.

The movie is entertaining, let that be said. The action never lets up except maybe at the end, where it could have used more punch. In contrast to some reviews I actually liked the storyline, it just felt like it could have gone on a little longer.

Arnold is as charismatic as ever, even with the low amount of dialogue. I was a bit disappointed the lengths the filmmakers went to poke fun at T-800. I wished he could have been a bit closer to the meaner Terminator from the first movie in contrast to the "softer" one from T2. There are many laughs in the film and this is welcome. The first movie was more of a B horror flick and T2 more sci-fi. T3 falls somewhere in between the previous two in nearly all areas.

The special effects were very good. The final iteration Arnold goes through in the end is magnificent. I wished it could have lasted longer.

With the Matrix Reloaded we had a film that was simply too much. It also had a story that was so convoluted I really gave up on caring what happens to the characters. T3 is the opposite in nearly all areas. It needed more of everything except a few less corny lines.

In the end I am now wishing for T4 and an all out battle. I hope it comes because like the previous two movies, T3 leaves the audience hanging wondering what is going to happen.

title: The Best Movie Ive Seen All Year
review: Ive always been a huge fan of the two Terminator movies.  They were both excellent.  I was really hyped up to see Terminator 3..and trust me, Terminator 3 is no let down.  It is the only movie that made me leave the theater wanting more, feeling good and feeling generally excited, even after seeing the movie.  It was just that good.  The action was unbelievable, better, in my opinion, then the action in Matrix Reloaded.  The movie cost 180 million to make and it definitly shows it.  Arnold IS back and gives an awesome performance the third time around as The Terminator.  I recommend this movie to all action fans, Arnold fans, terminator fans..just movie fans in general, CHECK THIS OUT! 10/10.

title: Best summer movie of 2003
review:
Arnold is finally back, looks just as great as he did the day he did T2. I was expecting the movie to be great and it was great, however as expected it would not surpass T2. Mr. Cameron can rest easy on that one, cause deep down we all know that nothing can beat T2, unless he decides to do a T4 which would be fantastic.

I loved the action, could be even better than T2's action, but that still remains to be seen. Both Arnold and Kristanna carry the movie very well together, and they definitely have updated their ideas as far as technology goes. Nick Stahl who plays today's John Connor was alright but not great, the thing I am beginning to discover behind his character is he doesn't have much of one to begin with, even when you look at T2 with John you can sort of see the same thing. Claire Danes was pretty good as playing Kate Brewster and had some great emotion in her character.

The only things I didn't like about it was it was missing the feel of soul, of humanity, the fact that machines were going to take over didn't really scare me that much in this one, I guess only cause in T1 and T2 we are told the stories of what happens and we can only imagine it which can be the true horror, but it would have been preferable if James Cameron were to illustrate that actual illusion because I know he can. The movie was too quick, as great as it was, we waited 12 long years for this and I think over 2 hours isn't too much to ask for.

But all that aside, I loved the ending, definately leaves the door wide open for one more, but I don't want to wait another 12 years for it, maybe 5 years at most would be good, but we will for sure be back!

title: Not even close to the original concept
review:
Oh, how I wish that I had stayed home. I knew that this movie was going to be the worst of the three, but I didn't realize that it was going to be quite this bad. I don't know if the people in charge just ran out of ideas or the fact that James Cameron wasn't really involved had that much of an impact on the final product. Regardless, here are my pros and cons of T3: Rise of the machines.

Pros (the smallest list): Great action sequence and great acting all around from the cast. Though I wasn't particularly happy with the casting choices in the matter of looks/public appeal/ect...all the actors did a fine job. Especially the in the role of the Terminatrix. She nailed the cold and dispassionate look down pat. Too bad they gave her lines like: a seductive "I like your gun" and inflatable breasts. The chase/fight scenes were great. One scene in particular (crane scnene) was dragged out too long, but overall it was great fun to watch. Special effects were awesome.

Cons (oh where do I start?): Arnold, though I adore him, definitely showed his age. Also, his role had too many speaking parts. Speaking parts are usually good, but for this character and his monotone voice, less is more. Also, they gave him way too many human characteristics than needed. The opening scene was real cheesy too. A badly cosmetically aged Stahl standing on a heap of rubble and pumping his arm like some kind of post-war cheerleader. Gag! They also tried to recapture the whole romance/fate thing like in the first but it was too obvious and there was no chemistry between the two. Add in a few subplots which were never resolved or expanded upon and the story pretty much limped along at a choppy pace.

One thing I loved about T1 and T2 was that the story itself was told fluidly and at a breakneck pace. The action was consistent. T3, on the otherhand, was filled with those tired old dramatic pauses which has the audience either shaking his head or yelling at the screen. John Connor wasting precious moments staring at liquid metal like he'd never seen it before. Talking scenes and poignant looks that have the characters actually STOPPING in the middle of a chase sequence. In "real life" they would have been wasted! Overall, it was just waaay too typical of every other bubble-gum scifi/horror flick in the past.

title: No expectations go a long way...
review: Okay, this wasn't as memorable as T1 or T2 but for some reason it didn't matter that much to me. I guess I really wasn't expecting much and ended up getting more. I have to say that without Linda Hamilton the film was missing something. She gave soul to the first 2 and her absence is felt. Would have been nice to see Edward Furlong back also but apparently he's chosen a career in drugs... too bad but his choice. Could Cameron have done better? I guess we'll never know. Again, it was his choice not to do it. Maybe he said all he wanted to say in the first 2. He mixes effects and story better than most. It's usually one or the other and he is excellent at both, so yes, I think he was missed. Bottom line... T1 and T2 both had many scenes that are etched in my memory... T3 is missing that. There wasn't one scene that I will carry around with me. That being said... it also wasn't insultingly bad either... so I'd say it was good but not memorable. It had some holes but not enough to sink it. 7 out of 10...

title: Dissappointing. (Contains spoilers)
review:
Possible Spoiler alert.

This films biggest flaw is that it ignores the message from the first two, "The Future is not set. There is no fate but what we make for ourselves." This film throws that concept out the window. The film's second biggest flaw is the ending, it's too indesicisive, Judgment Day still goes on despite all that happened in T2? Give me a break! Either make the bunker at the end the SkyNet Core, or at least the film shouldn't have foreshadowed that the future could be changed because at the end the future can't. Also what happened to Brad Fiedel's musical score? (Except during the end credits?) Also more of the future war would have been should have been shown besides the overhead shots that rolled before the opening credits. Dissapointing when compared to the first two. But to it's credit it did stick in a cameo from Earl Boen (Dr. Silberman) which was one of the very few redeeming features of the movie. Instead of this you should try wither one of the first two.

title: That is what I see an action movie for!
review: I won't go to a Terminator movie thinking about the writer, director, producer, composer, etc. Who cares about anything except huge effects, huge sound and huge Arnold (and this time a supersexy T-X)?! This movie ROCKS. See it, then report back here and tell me, did it not entertain?

title: just saw the film yesterday
review:
I just went to see T3 last night and it is well worth going to see. In this film there is much humor. The special effects are also really well done.

It is also a change from John Connor being the most important character. Unlike the second movie the Terminator is not programmed to listen to him.

The new terminator is also a surprise. More advanced than the terminators in the last two movies, she has special features and abilities.

The ending also is a very BIG surprise. All the way up to the last five minutes you are tricked. The end brings a shock that is well worth going to see.

I highly recommend this movie and give it 4.5 stars out of 5.

title: Setting up the Story for T4?
review: The Terminator is back. Arnold fans won't be disappointed, this movie is action, action, action. T3 movies so fluidly that you don't realize you've been sitting in a  theatre for 90 minutes, which is an ode to the talented James Cameron. Claire Danes has grown up and plays a good damsel in distress. Nick Stahl just seems to exist in the film only to give a body to John Conner, but with all the car chases, gun battles, and explosions most people aren't going to notice. Arnold has still got it. I was not disappointed. The action is non stop, the plot is pretty decent, and it has a twist ending that is inviting another sequel.

title: too short
review:
This movie was quite satisfactory as an addition to the other two Terminator stories. The action sequences were exactly what one might expect, and the characterization was similarly as desired. Arnold especially shines in somewhat of an unintended comedic light.

But I couldn't help feeling like this movie was just a very expensive campaign ad in which time was being paid for by the minute in order to remind the people of California who Arnold is.

This movie runs just over an hour and a half and I felt that it was missing something. All the essential plot elements were there, but there was no detail. There were no sub-plots or interesting secondary characters, and the resolution was unnecessarily quick.

On the other hand, there was nothing superfluous in this movie. Every scene drove the action forward and provided entertainment in many forms. I just wish that, with the $200 million budget, they could have drawn it out a bit. Hopefully there will be another sequel soon in order to fulfill the missing element.

title: What you Probably Expected from a Terminator Movie
review:
If you went to the theater expecting an action packed movie with lots of violence and state of the art special effects, then you should be happy. Is this a great moment in cinematic history? NO. But it wasn't intended to be and IS a worthy sequel in what is now destined to be a continuing series.

The only thing that really kind of gets to me after a while is the virtually invulnerability of the Terminators. Yes, they were designed to be unstoppable. However, after a while it is kinda like watching a video game with a "God Mode" cheat code. Nothing can stop or hurt you, so why do they bother.

We have a BIG screen THX theater in our movie complex. This, or a drive-in, is the place you need to see a movie like this or the Hulk for maximum effect. You will never get it at home if you wait for the rental, no matter how fancy your system and how big your screen. This summer will see an IMAX with all the whistles and bells open in the same complex. A lot of movies like Terminator 3 are starting to produce 72mm versions for the IMAX. Big action pictures like this are really going to start playing to this bigger format. Do yourself a favor and go find this on the big screen.

title: I was pleasantly surprised.
review: I really liked this movie.  I am a huge fan of the first two movies, and when I heard that Cameron wasn't directing this one, I was skeptical.  I went in thinking it wasn't gonna be any good, but instead was pleasantly surprised.  They did a really good job of sticking to the "Terminator" story line, without making a carbon copy of T2.  The TX was awesome!!!  The best scenes were when she was fighting Arnold.  I would recommend this movie. Also, there is a little bit of a twist to the "judgement day/Skynet" thing, but I think it was still faithful to the overall storyline.  I don't want to give it away, so go check it out!

title: Lots of Action !!
review:
Contains spoiler Being a big fan of the Terminator series, I had been looking forward to T3 for some time. The trailers I viewed made it more tempting.

I liked this film a lot, and enjoyed some of the humorous one liners. The comment Conners to Brewster when fighting the flying machine came across well. There were a couple of hokey moments, like Brewster recognizing Conner from an eight-grade party and her sudden abilities to fly.

I thought the action scenes, and special effects were excellent. The twist about John Conners fate in the future at the hands of the current Terminator savior was interesting.

I will look forward to T4 .

title: Arnold does it again!!
review:
Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines, although not the greatest film ever made certainly lived up to the hype. The latest installment takes the series in a new direction with great special effects, wonderful performances by Clair Danes, Arnold Schwarzenegger and the T-X kristianna Lokken. Arnold returns and plays the part (with a few exceptions) to perfection, Danes is wonderful on screen and Loken performance as a killing machine is second only to Arnold in the original.

The special effects are wonderful, their is a good story line to follow and a dark twist at the end which will set up the next film nicely for what should be an awesome conclusion to the series.

I give it a 4/5. The only drawback to this film is that their were a few cheesy parts (lines) that could have been left on the editing floor.

Overall they do not take much away from the film as a whole. KEEP IT UP ARNOLD!!!!!!

title: He's Back!
review:
In Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines, a film series is established that I never thought should have been established. I've ranted in depth on my thoughts on The Terminator and its sequel on my webpage, and my hatred for the existence of said sequel should have been a deterrent in my preparation to see T3. But my appetite for big-budget Schwarzenegger vehicles is one that must be fed, and Terminator 3 is the best tasting film Arnold's made in a while.

James Cameron moved on after directing the first two films, and the reigns are now taken by Jonathan Mostow. Mostow wowed me previously with Breakdown, a B Movie so simple in plot and so tight in action that it held me in its grasp from opening to close. Terminator 3 is definitely from the same mold. The pacing is perfect, the action scenes are relentless, and the philosophical banter (thankfully there's little of it.I was petrified this would turn in to another Matrix Reloaded) is simple and fitting. Mostow knows that a film like this, like a sorority babe, will not be looked at for its brains.

This isn't a bad thing. The script allows Arnold to appear much more like a machine than the first sequel, limiting him to short lines that are usually so corny they work beautifully. The aging Schwarzenegger shows that he has not lost his ability to carry an action film, although the lack of action from his character leaves us wondering how much is left in Arnold's tank. Hopefully we find out the answer in a different role. More on that later.

Among the other key players, Nick Stahl (from In the Bedroom, which is an excellent movie) shines while taking over the role of John Conner, the future hero who needs protection. The transition from the wide-eyed youth of Edward Furlong to the unaccepting adult is hard at first, but in the end Stahl's Conner is right on the money. Claire Danes joins the fray as the love interest who also must be saved for mankind's sake, and is sufficient in her role.

The most publicized addition to the franchise has been Kristanna Loken as the female nemesis of the Terminator, the TX. The TX model is much more impressive looking under fire than the similar model in T2. I know many people will regard this as blasphemous, but that liquid metal on Robert Patrick looked LAME! The TX has all the powers of her predecessor, but looks a lot better doing it. I'm referring mostly to the special effects, but yeah, the female aspect is cool to see too.

The success however, lies in the direction. Like Breakdown, Mostow masterfully crafts a film that manages to be both laid-back and wound-up at the same time, feeling simple in plot and hypercharged in activity. It's not a masterpiece in any shape or form, but it did what I thought it could not - It made me care about John Conner again while keeping me gazing at the pretty explosions and collisions for almost two hours.

I can't recommend Terminator 3 flat out. It's too simple to be called anything more than a popcorn flick, and too basic in its action scenes to be called revolutionary in that aspect. It does add some basic determinism for flavor, and there is a deeper message. But, in truth, T3 seems simply like a remix of the ideas that were used to make T2. But it's a remix that doesn't succumb to too much `intelligence' like T2 did. This is no substitute for the original. But if I have to choose between the sequels, I'll take the powderkeg that is Terminator 3 in a heartbeat over the flashbomb that is Terminator 2. Check it out.

P.S. - Love the Ending. It had to take a lot of balls to put that on the screen. Should be a fitting end to the series.I hope.

title: Great addition to the series
review:
I was skeptical about how good Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines would be. Sure, it's got Arnold, which is probably the most important factor. But there's no Linda Hamilton, no Eddie Furlong, and no James Cameron. He wrote and directed the first two. Could new people take over the series and do it justice? Well my fears were put to rest after tonight. T3 is awesome.

Even though the original date of Judgement Day has passed, John Conner is still struggling with his unknown destiny. But there's not a whole lot of time for philosophizing about fate and the nature of humanity. No need really, since that was already covered very well in T2. This film gets the action started early, and it's on full speed until the end. Everything is bigger here. You haven't seen a car chase until you see the massive action sequences here with so many oversized vehicles. I don't think I've ever seen so many broken windows, overturned cars, and explosions in one movie. The theater was shaking, and I was loving it.

I liked the idea of a sexy female Terminator, and not just because I'm a guy (although that helped). It made for interesting contrast to the previous villains of this series, and made a potentially similar sequel feel fresh. The T-X has all that liquid metal shape-shifting stuff mastered, not too mention plenty of new tricks up her sleeve. If Schwarzenegger wasn't such a cool hero, I would have easily rooted for the Terminatrix.

There's an awesome fight scene between the Terminators, T-X versus T-850. I've seen enough wire kung fu lately, so I really enjoyed this brutal fight where they literally throw each other through walls, floors, and anything else that looks painful. Plenty of computer graphics are implemented in the movie, but it is cleverly shot, and rarely noticeable. I doubt T3 will get the same "cartoony video game" complaints that plagued many Matrix Reloaded reviews.

If you like the previous Terminator flicks, and have an open mind about the new cast and director, you should have a great time. There's new catch phrases, as you'd expect. Some great moments of humor too, that really get a laugh against the otherwise serious tone. Your questions (Where's Sara? Why are the machines still rising? Why doesn't the Terminator remember John?) will be answered. And there's quite a few references to the older movies for those who really pay attention.

It's hard to say if Terminator 3 is better than T2. That 1991 film is a classic. Great story and ground breaking special effects. T3 isn't necessary to complete a trilogy, so it could have ended with T2. That's how James Cameron would have liked it. But T3 certainly doesn't feel like it was tacked on to the end of the series to make a buck. It fits very well with the other films, and shows off some incredible effects not possible 12 years ago. All the Terminator films have their own merits, so I can easily foresee my future. I am destined to one day purchase the 3 film DVD Terminator boxed set.

title: Mind boggling action
review:
Super cool 3rd installment to the series. Lacks the soul and heart of T but more than makes up for it in unrelenting action. A shame Eddie Furlong was not allowed to reprise his role. I kept envisioning him on the screen. He's probably banging his head against the wall somewhere.

This film will gross at least 200 million domestic. The end avails itself to a sequel. This ones worth seeing

title: Best Summer Sci-Fi Action Film of 2003!
review:
Whoa! That was some fun... 7.5/10

I must say that after being rather disappointed after watching the much anticipated Matrix and X Men sequels in May-June this year, July could as well be the best movie month with the welcoming of Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines.

I did like T1 and T2, but didn't expect much from T3. Surpisingly, it was awesome! Arnold was his same old, Kristanna Loken here was a better "bad" terminator than Robert Patrick in T2:Judgement Day, Nick Stahl did great job as a 20+ John Connor and Claire Daines, her humble self as usual, did a dignified supporting role as well. Good starcast, good action, smooth flow of the movie, ocassional wisecracks and "not overdone yet superb" special affects make this movie definitely enjoyable.

I was honored to see a sneak preview tonight, and indeed it was an honor. Everyone who came out of the 2 theater halls seemed content and satisfied with the third installment of Terminator. Mistow definitely did a good direction and James Cameron wasn't all that missed. Whew! what a break from pseudo-martial arts.

No spoilers: but the ending was rather different, compared to the first 2 movies. Looking forward to the fourth film if any. They better make one before old man Arnold has a farm. There has to be a conclusion, some way the future is changed. Just do your part and perform an advanced virus check on your pc every night before the Sky-Net "Super-Virus" takes over........

title: Bad critics, Great Movie!
review: I was going into this movie thinking that it was a generic money machine (so i thought from hearing all the reviews).  It turned out that i was pleasantly surprised by a well written and action packed movie!  It tied in perfectly with the past terminators and i was not dissappointed at all.  I thought the absence of Sarah Conner would be dissappointing, but after seeing the movie i was not.  To me its the surprise movie of the summer. Will watch this one again! Cant wait until the trilogy comes out on DVD!!

title: Silly and Monotonous
review:
First off I must confess that I'm not a member of the church of Terminator. I was 5 years old when T2 came out and I missed out on all the hype and excitement surrounding its release. The first time I saw T2 was right before watching T3; I had seen the first movie before. On DVD and 12 years separated from the hype, T2 is a decent action movie but nothing more; I found James Cameron's attempts at creating human drama to be just as laughable as they were in Titanic. Because I wasn't really anticipating this movie, it wasn't a big deal to me when it turned out to be a dud (especially considering I got in free thanks to an employee friend's passes). If you are a fanboy, brace yourself; I haven't seen anything quite so hilarious and sad for quite some time as the shell-shocked, horrified look on the face of a man in the row behind me at the end of the movie; as everyone filed out, he stayed glued to his seat, his mouth slightly open, staring transfixed at the screen like it was some horrible train-wreck. I have a creeping suspicion he was praying for Ashton Kutcher to appear and scream "YOU'VE BEEN PUNK'D BY THE PUNKERS ON MTV'S PUNK'D, PUNK!"

Before 1999, action movies were about big, brutal fights and explosions. On March 31, 1999, The Matrix slipped quietly into theaters and we all know what happened next. For better or for worse, T3 is a throwback film of sorts. There is, as in Matrix Reloaded, one huge car-chase set piece; it plays out more like director Jonathan Mostow challenging himself to see how much of the ridiculous $170 million budget he can spend blowing things up and knocking things over in a couple minutes, all while shaking the camera around and cutting quickly enough that you have only a faint inkling of what's going on. All the movie's action sequences play out like this; yes, the explosions are big, but none of it is terribly interesting or creative.

I'm not going to bother with the plot, which serves as a vehicle for 1) the effects and 2) the setup for a couple more of these movies than a story in its own right. What some will inevitably call a daring and imaginate shakeup of the Terminator mythos is more a necessarily overcomplex way to milk an artificial conflict out of a storyline that was concluded 12 years ago.

This is a franchise exercise and a calculated move, not a film. If that doesn't dissuade you from seeing it, since 90% of Hollywood's movies are that way, hopefully the fact that it's a bad one will.

title: Too short a film? Perhaps it's just me
review:
I was hoping to see X2 but apparently it's already out of the theaters. Shows ya how often I get out.

I'm surprised that the theater wasn't jam-packed - I walked right in and hardly anyone was there at the 8 PM showing.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film with Nick Stahl (John Connor). He portrayed Connor as I believe he should have been, but won't give any spoilers as yesterday was the first showing. He definitely out-acted the pubescent Connor in T2. Just the lack of the squeaky cracking voice was reason enough to like him! LOL

I can't say that Kristanna Loken (T-X) really had the latitude to do much with this role what with it being an emotionally void machine, but then again Arnold's T-100(?) had a lot more personality, if you will. I don't think this is a 'spoiler' but I kept noticing how perfect Loken's T-X looked regardless of how often she met physical impacts - not a single hair was out of place! I know, it's because she was a machine meant to look that way. Actually, I found it commendable that the production crew made certain that particular detail was not overlooked. There's so much going on in this film that I'm sure many, including myself, will see it numerous times since I was so engrossed in it that it appeared to end too quickly. Who knows, perhaps on DVD the deleted scenes and/or Director's Cut will make for even more an enjoyable experience.

Well, enough of that. I can't think of anything else to comment about right now since the film only JUST opened and I don't want to ruin any part of it for anyone.

title: 3rd installement is taking series in right direction but too slow.
