review: Terminator 3 is really based on scripts that have been flying on net since 1999. Some of the scripts that this movie is mainly based are called T3:Armageddon and its many versions over the years.(Personally the older versions were great) Those scripts call for Arnold Terminator back right before skynet takes over and with Linda and young John he helps them to survive through nuclear holocaust and then fights along Johns side. Now the T3 movie itself is very close to this script. John is saved and Arnold terminator ensures John survives the holocaust but of course his mother is already dead for while. Anyways, the movie itself is on fast pace with battles between T-X and Arnold as John and his future wife(Claire) basically are running away. The action sequences are good. The best part of the movie is when skynet is turned on and together with interacion of the global virus it takes over. Early prototype machines take over in the military building that John gets to trying to prevent judgement day. That's when Arnold gets to fight his precedessors for once and not the advanced TX. Kick ass. However, I wish we would see more of the Skynet taking over. Further the scripts that have been flying on the net explained why Skynet computer system actually turns against humanity. In this movie its not explained, although if you read the scripts you would understand possibly what the virus really was:)(hacker who admires world power and have Hitler for his idol). But, back to the actual movie. It seems that instead of showing us the judgement day and post battle to save humanity Jonathan Mostow decides to widely extend the TX vs T101 battles and finishes the movie on guess what(judgement day) so it's a perfect setup for T4(post nuclear warfare between men and machine). This should and could have been succesfully done in one movie, T3, but at least T3 takes the right direction. I was afraid this movie is gonna bring another ending where they think they prevented judgement day, thank god they didn't.

title: Another Franchise Ruined
review:
This is in no way a summary of the movie, merely a review. Like all fans of the first two films, I really wanted to like this movie. I thought the trailers sucked, but it seemed to be getting a positive reaction, so I watched it with an open mind. Unfortunately my fears wear confirmed about 15 minutes into the movie, this one just plain sucks. Basically, if you're looking for your run-of-the-mill disposable Hollywood action crap, go see it, you'll enjoy it; everyone else, keep reading as to why this movie failed.

I will start with the pros of the film (there are only 4). 1. NICK STAHL, easily the best part of the movie, a great John Connor. 2. THE END, shockingly it wasn't a happy one, but it seems forced and is too little too late. 3. THE STORY, actually it wasn't that bad, but the execution was awful. 4. SPECIAL EFFECTS, as always with Stan Winston, he delivers top notch make-up and FX.

On with the bad. I know you weren't supposed to view this as a James Cameron film, but here's what I have to say to the people who think he's replaceable (this might be a stupid analogy, but I think it works). When a band gets a new lead singer, everybody tries to make themselves believe it's the same band and just as good as the original, but it's not, most of the time it's subpar. That's the problem with this movie, it's not Jon Mostow's fault, but he is not James Cameron. James Cameron has a gift in delivering kick ass movies that center around story, not special FX, few can pull it off as is evidenced here. Essentially, you don't HAVE to have Arnie to make a Terminator picture, but you HAVE to Cameron. As I said the story wasn't that bad, but in the hands of Mostow it sucked. Cameron could've done wonders with it. You feel Mostow is just looking for another reason to blow s*** up rather than focusing on developing characters you care about. You don't even care about Arnie in this movie cuzz he doesn't f***ing DO ANYTHING. You really get the sense that the studio wanted a short combination of the first two films, nothing more, and that's exactly what you get. No memorable scenes, a rehashed basic plot, a villain who is laughable, and lots of lame ass explosions. I know it comes down to the almighty dollar and that's why this film was made, but for the love of God, I really feel that once the studio learned Cameron wanted nothing to do with it they should've stopped. There's my two cents. Just pray there's not a 4th.

title: visual masterpiece, if you like that kinda stuff...
review: the movie was conjested with action and special effects which took away from a strong plot line and good characters.  the visuals were excellent, although many things were regurgitated from the previous films.  many people will like this film for its stunning visual effects, and many people will hate it for its lack in good dialouge, plot, and characters.  i feel it would be worth while to see if you want to know what happens next in the terminator story, but dont expect the same feelings of intrigue or the same vibe from the characters like the cold, evil t-1000.  i think of t3 as a 'give the visual effects guys a bunch of money and see what they can do' kinda movie rather than a good sequel to a previously good movie.

title: You'd be foolish to miss this...THIS MOVIE ROCKS!
review:
I enjoy the luxury of having a good friend who's in the theater business. We try to do at least one "private showing" (just the two of us) once a month. I just got home from one with "Terminator 3." Gotta admit...it wasn't on the top of my "want to see" list. But, dear friends....GO SEE THIS STELLAR FLICK! It simply SMOKES from minute one to minute last! Credible acting, decent script, and absolutely astounding action sequences that are practically non-stop. I couldn't have been more pleased. (and if you're one of the few like me who loved "Breakdown" with Kurt Russell...you already know what this director is capable of.)

The word my friend the theater owner got late tonight, was that all sneak previews earlier tonight across Michigan did very poorly dollar-wise, which means people are obviously hesitant. I predict that word of mouth will keep this in the top 3 for at least a couple of weeks.

DON'T miss this one!!!

title: The tradition of great SFX continues
review:
The latest installment of the Terminator movies will not only thrill fans, but also impress the casual viewer. Time isn't wasted on useless sentimentality as this movie kicks into action from the very beginning. Schwarzenegger reprises his role to perfection and thankfully keeps the cheesy one-liners to a minimum.

Although it is noticeably missing the James Cameron touch, director Jonathan Mostow certainly delivers a quality picture worthy of becoming part of the trilogy. Some bad acting and poor writing hinder this from being a perfect film, but that was almost to be expected. Still, experience T3 on the big screen along with great sound, and you won't be disappointed.

title: very disappointed
review: I'm just going to make this short for now because I am very tired.  I just came back from seeing the "sneak preview" and I have to say that this movie should have never been greenlit.  Most of Arnold's dialogue were horrible but that wasn't the biggest issue of the movie.  The main disappointment is the lack of a strong story.  With a better director this movie could have been significantly better.  T2 had a great story and ended perfectly. The story ended so well that it closed the story preventing the making of a sequel which obviously didn't happen.  The ending of the movie doesn't necessarily leave it open for a sequel but there is a chance that there could be.  And if there is a sequel I hope I would have the chance to direct it, which I highly doubt.  But it is nice to dream.  I already have an idea on a possible sequel that would have a strong story and would be able to close the saga. But anyway I do recommend this movie to fans of the previous films so your knowledge may expand on the Terminator universe.

title: There is no fate but what we make for ourselves...
review: T3 was an amazing experience. I saw an advance screening of it tonight. I believe it surpasses it's expectations. Compared to The Terminator and T2, T3 is action-packed to the bone. Props go to the special effects team. I knew the action in the movie would be incredible. What I was concerned about coming into the theater was whether the plot would be strong or weak. After all, in T2, Judgment Day is prevented. Or is it? We learn early on in the movie that it's only delayed. The war with the machines is inevitable. The plot is complex but understandable. It's not like The Matrix Reloaded. Too keep things short and sweet, T3 spells the sad truth about mankind. The ending brings a tear to the eye. It made me think about how fragile life is. "The future is not set. There is no fate but what we make for ourselves." Think about it. Then go see T3.

title: A Very Worthy Sequel
review:
I can't believe it. After five years of reading through rumours and gossip, it has finally been unleashed. After a year of antcipating this movie and watching the previews over and over again "it is time". Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is here, and holy crap did come in style.

This movie blows all of the other summer movies away.

Before I go on, I must say this; MINOR SPOILERS (nothing drastic) will be given away.

The movie opens with John Connor now in his 20's. He's living off the radar, and moves around a lot. He sort of a has been now. Since they stopped Judgment Day from happening ten years previous, he has nothing to live for really. However, he's still paranoid and never forgets what his mom taught him. But now another, highly advanced terminator (Kristana Loken) has been sent back to, well, terminate him. The T-X, as it's called, goes around and kills all of John's future Lieutenants. The T-X also goes after a girl named Kate Brewster (Claire Daines) who we find out has a very important role in the future war. The Human Resistance was able to send back another Terminator (Schwarzenegger) to protect Connor and Brewster. But which one will reach him first?

Now, I'll get to the good stuff in awhile but first I want to mention the casting. The casting of Nick Stahl as Connor was great. I first saw Stahl in the Mel Gibson directed movie The Man With-out A Face. Then Stahl was just a kid, but he did a great job in the role he played. Stahl replaces Edward Furlong in the role of Connor and he does a great job at it. His performance is brilliant and the way he captures the character of a guy who knows that the world could be destroyed at anytime is excellent.

The casting of Claire Daines as Kate Brewster was a smart move as well. I can't actually think of any other actress who would fit in this role. As much as I like Natalie Portman, I don't think she would have been believable in this role, and it would have just been her doing her Star Wars bit again. Daines and Stahl have some great chemistry on screen together and that really helps the movie. That's one thing that can always hurt a movie if people are supposed to like each other. Bad chemistry is noticeable, and it distracts from the picture.

Now onto the choice role of the T-X, Kristana Loken. While she doesn't play the character as menacing as Robert Patrick's T-1000 character in T2, she does do a good job, at being the, sort of, innocent cute girl. She actually surprised me and did a good job. She's not a scary character, which is a shame, but she's a tough one. I wasn't to keen on the idea of a female terminator, I though it would be handled wrong, but I was wrong. I suppose that's what I get for under-estimating Jonathan Mostow, who did good job with this movie.

Sure T3 isn't as good as the first two. I didn't expect it to be, and it doesn't bother me. First of all, it's a different director and writers. The James Cameron Terminator movies are far superior to this one, but this one is still a worthy sequel.

Mostow, who directed the great Kurt Russell thriller 'Breakdown' and the tense submarine thriller 'U-571', handles this movie really well. He pays homage to the original Terminator movies as well as adding his own spin on it.

This one isn't as 'dark' as the other ones were, but it still works. I have said for awhile now, that this movie will either crush Mostow's career, or give him the respect he deserves. And it looks like I'm right.

Mostow has an eye for action, and a well placed eye that is. Most of the action in this movie is way better than most of the other action in any of the previous summer action movies.

And another good thing is it never lets up. The action just keeps coming. What a thrill ride. The massive car chase near the beginning was brilliant. I said the Matrix: Reloaded car chase was good, but this one is far better, mainly because it uses REAL cars and real stunts. It doesn't rely on CGI to make explosions and cars crash.

The first car chase, or rather truck chase, is fun and thrilling. It involves a crane truck and Arnie chasing the T-X on a police motorcycle. It's too much to talk about it, but it's great. What I also liked about this chase was something very subtle. The chase started a night, but it ended during the day. I loved the fact that Mostow decided to have the sun come up during the chase. I don't know why. Probably because most car chases either happen during the day or night, never in between. It was a nice touch. Lame I know, but I liked it.

The rest of the action is skillfully done and it was some neat stuff to see. A fight between the Terminator and the T-X had me worried for a minute that Woman's Rights Activists might sue the studio because of the beating Arnie gives the female T-X. But then she fought back, so I guess it evens the score.

Also, I must mention Stan Winston. He worked on the previous two Terminators and even won an Academy Award for make-up and special effects on T2. He returns here, and does a stellar job. I love seeing the battle damage on the Terminator, with the Terminator skeleton popping out and flesh still hanging on. It's really neat make-up and job well done. I think another Academy Award might in sights for Winston.

Now there was a lot of humour in this one. I laughed at a lot of it, and it was nice to kind of see Arnie play around and make fun of himself on screen. Like just after he gets his outfit and what he does. It was stupid, but I will admit, I laughed. It was harmless, but it could have done with-out it.

Now, there were some things that I didn't like about T3. Yes, I know, hard to believe, eh? I didn't like some of the dialogue. It was weak at times, but all the goodness about this movie makes up for all the bad.

I also didn't like the fact the classic Terminator theme was absent through out the whole movie. Now Marco Beltrami did a god job composing the movie. The soundtrack was great, it's just, I missed that Terminator theme. It's such an awsome theme, how could he not use it? Sure it appears in the end credits, but still?

The story moves along at break neck pace and keeps rolling and rolling. The movie does slow down from time to time to explain things and further the story as well. I don't want to say anything about the story in general, but what I will say is that it's pretty good.

In Roger Ebert's review he said `The ending must remain for you to discover, but I will say it seems perfunctory'. I disagree. I liked the ending. As did Ebert's reviewing buddy Richard Roeper. It does leave questions out there, but it also seems to say that, no matter how much we try, we are always doomed. You can't stop something from happening that's supposed to happen, you can only postpone it, and wait until it arrives to do what your fate has chosen for you to do.

The ending was good. I liked it. I don't care what anyone says about it, it was good.

So, now my closing comments, Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is a summer action movie that delivers. It doesn't have a complicated storyline that makes you stop paying attention and makes you just want to leave the theatre so bad (Matrix Reloaded). It doesn't rely heavily on CGI like the Matrix did, and when it has CGI, its damn good. It's not as noticeable or poorly done like the Matrix and Hulk were. It also has non-stop great action.

It's a great movie and I know I've said this before, but I recommend seeing this. Go buy a ticket, buy some popcorn sit down and enjoy the lame, but fun, humour, the action and spectacular visuals.

I have to say it, but Arnold is back everyone, and he's back in full force. Terminator 3 is here, and now its time for King Conan.

title: Worth it!
review: As far as sequels go, as good or better than Matrix Reloaded. This movie has some of the viciousness of the first one, definitely an R. T2 seemed to back off the violence a bit, but Kristanna Loken makes Robert Patrick look like a wussy. That chase is definitely as good as the Reloaded freeway chase :)

title: Good, but shows how amazing terminator 2 is
review:
I saw Terminator 3 tonight and I msut say that it was good. I was somewhat dissapointed by it since T2 set such high standards, but it was nonetheless a very solid movie. T2 was made in 1991 with a budget of 100 million. To me this movie still holds its ground to T3, a movie made 12 years later. Cameron's presence was missed on this film, but Mostow did a job well done and can hopefully spawn a sequel of two off this story line. Although not as good as T2 it keeps the franchise alive and the story provides more than enough interest for another movie.

8/10

title: Awesome.
review: *Spoliers* I just got back from seeing T3 tonight.  At first I was not sure whether I really loved it or I really hated it.   I have since decided on the former.  I went into the movie with a very hopeful yet skeptical attitude.  Ok, the movie.  At first I was afraid that my fears were coming true (the stupid sunglasses, talk to the hand - which actually was incredibly funny to me). The T-X made me quite sketical at first because she is so hot that I could not think of her being a mean ass. Then when she connects to the net through her phone I thought "oh d*mn." From then on out she is a bad*ss.  The chase through LA is hands down awesome.  Much better than the Matrix Reloaded chase (though not as long).  The Terminator is very good.  If a little more emotive than he should be.  Things about the movie that I really loved: Skynet coming online was so cool. There really wasnt much to it, but just knowing that it was happening was so cool. Conner realizing that judgement day cannot be averted was very good.  I also liked how the machines came to realize that just as judgement day itself could not be avoided, neither could John Conner, so instead they aim at the less important parts in an attempt to lessen the sum - the future generals that serve under Conner. At first I did not like how the movie ended, with the bombs dropping right at the end.  But in retrospect I think it was good that way.  However, it also necessitates another sequel.  I was sorta hoping for some closure.  But I was also itching to see everything blow up. Which also did not really happen.  But I guess that really was not all that necessary. There were a few other bad things.  First of all, there was just a little too much corny humor. Some would have been good, but not as much as was in there.  The sarah conner part was rather lame, in my opinion.  I wish they would have explained some more how the main players all happened to find there way together at the kennel.  The movie sorta throws out the whole "no fate but what we make" thing.  However, I think that is a good thing though. Lastly, I was hoping that Mostow would throw in something about Uncle Bobs left over arm at the end of T2.  All that being said, I am very pleased with this movie. 9 out of 10.

title: Two words sum up this movie for me and they are popcorn flick
review: Moviegoing auidences have been waiting twelve years for Arnold Schwarzenegger to come back to the role that made him famous and the question remains; was it worth the wait? For me the answer is yes and no. First I'll focus on the yes part of the movie. Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines delivers it's share of action and special effects which in the summer time is why we go to the movies. Nick Stahl whose is  a very talented actor takes the role of John Connor from Edward Furlong and does it well. And the T-X played by the sexy Kristanna Loken is meancing and a smooth bad ass bad guy. Fianlnly Jonathan Mostow handles the action sequences very well in the film. The chase sequence in the film is one of the best I've seen from the three movies he's directed . Now let's focus on the no part of Terminator 3 that will upset many moviegoers. Terminator 3 has two main probelms that makes the film pale in comparison to it's precassadors. The first being the lack of storytelling that trio of screenwriters John Brancato,Michael Ferris and Tedi Sarafian can't seem to capture that Cameron magic which affects the direction of the talented Mostow. The second problem is the familar score by composer Brad Fiedel which is gone from this film. When it comes to the females in the film Claire Danes and Kristanna Loken both kinda gives a paper thin performances. Danes over does the damsel in distress role and Loken is nothing more than eye candy (but damn does she look good). The film won't please all tastes but if you want mindless entertainment then check this one out. Hopefully the inevitable Terminator 4 with Nick Stahl in the lead will be an improvement over this one. It's not that Terminator 3 is a bad film it just wasn't worth a 12 year wait. Mt final verdict on the film is ** 1/2 stars.

title: WOW!
review:
SPOILER ALERT!!!

I loved it. What can i say! This movie is definitely my favorite of the series. Not only does it tell a great story, but it has awesome action scenes. The pacing is fast, just like the first Terminator film.

The acting is top notch and the ending is just awesome. Not only is it thought provoking, but it is also very emotional.

Ties in very well with T1 and T2, and it continues the mythology of John Connor in an excellent way. At the beginning of the film, he is a slacker who wants no part of his destiny. At the end of the film, he accepts his fate as the leader of the human resistance against Skynet.

10/10

title: Third movie does it's best to make two previous films pointless
review:
****Plot Points In This Review****

I went into Terminator 3 with high hopes and high expectations. What I left with, was the same feeling I had after viewing Alien 3 for the first time. It had somehow accomplished nothing more than tarnishing the two films that had come before it. Through two Terminator films, we were led to believe that things that happen in the future could be changed, that certain things didn't have to be inevitable. With Terminator 3, we find out that was all nonsense, that there was no reason for the existence of the first two movies at all, because what's going to happen is going to happen and you can't do a darn thing about it. (just delay it for a while till we can get the next movie made). So what we end up with is three movies from the George Lucas School of prequels, though we didn't know it till now. Thanks, but no thanks for cluing us in.

There are plenty of exciting action and chase sequences in the film, and they do grab your attention while they are on the screen. Still, they are nothing more or less than we've seen in any other Summer Blockbuster, so I can't recommend seeing this movie on that alone. Schwarzenegger does his usual fine one note job as The Terminator, but Nick Stahl's John Connor is so wimpy, we long for Edward Furlong to pop up and give him a swift kick in the pants. Clare Danes as Kate Brewster, Connor's future wife, is by far more interesting, and you begin to wonder how John Connor and not her ever became the one to lead the rise against the machines. It almost makes you glad that in the future a Terminator does take out John Connor. I for one would feel a lot better about it if Kate were leading my revolution. Kristana Lokken, despite not having much to do except morph, is menacing enough, but no more or no less than Robert Patrick was in the previous film. She just has the advantage of having a few more tricks up her sleeve.

Will there ever be a Terminator 4? Could happen I suppose, if this one makes the major dollars as the previous films did. Trouble is, we now know the ending, and as in the Star Wars prequels, when you know what is going to happen, getting there just isn't that much fun anymore.

title: Lots of good action but disappointing story
review:
There was much room for improvement in the third installment of the series. I enjoyed the action just as I would have expected but the new John Conner, Nick Stahl and Kate Brewster, Claire Danes do not have much screen presence for these roles.

The one liners and references to the previous films are very good and are enough to keep it interesting. I noticed that the audience did not catch many of the references and wondered if the humor was only there for the die-hard fans. Overall I would say go to a matinee instead of paying full price.

title: Just garbage...
review:
Spoilers Warning...

Terminator 3 defies logic on so many levels. First of all, I have the same initial question with T-3 that I did with T-2. Why on earth does the future John Connor (or military personnel) continue to send old, obsolete model cyborgs to save him in the past? Wouldn't it make sense to send the same updated, slicker model that was sent to kill him? And why does the female T-X pump up her clevage to flirt with a cop? Isn't she the Terminator?? Why does she need tricks to get his gun? Just take it like you do everything else! Speaking of the cop's gun, why does she even need a gun? Her arm can shape into a gun, a rocket launcher, and a flame thrower. And why does she need to taste a bloody woman and bloody gauze pad to identify people? Isn't her tongue made from the same synthetic material her finger is? She should taste it as soon as she sticks her finger in it. She also murders a guy in a drive thru burger joint, but the window is on the right hand side. Why? Isn't this America?? And what happened to her mission to destroy John Connor's future lieutenants? She abandons that idea early on and decides to pursue John Connor and his future wife for the duration of the movie.

T-3 is a poor movie with a convoluted plot, uneven pacing and boring action. The ending is anti-climatic and the film in general feels small and incomplete. It ends with a door open for a sequel, but I am not looking forward to it. T-3 is simply garbage.

title: well done
review: This film was awesome. I enjoyed the story, character development, action, and I hope we see a T4 very soon. I went into the movie with high hopes, and I was very satisfied with what I saw. I cannot think of anything negative to say about T3!

title: Solid Arnold Action Flick
review: I went into this movie with a very low expectation.  After so many bad movies this summer I was sure they were going to ruin Terminator as well. That however did not occur.  The filmmakers obviously knew that they were not up to the task of coming up with a coherent story line so they just decided to have two hours of non-stop violence.  Add to the mix some outstanding one-liners and very twisted time humor and you end up with a movie that was refreshingly good.  If you are looking for a film that will get you emotionally involved as you watch the characters struggle with themselves to grow...this is the wrong film.  If on the other hand you just really want to see a bunch of stuff get blown up then this movie is right for you.  8/10

title: James Cameron's Absence Felt....
review:
So here's the thing... Jonathan Mostow is a good director, and T3 is aa good movie. Mostow however, is not James Cameron, and T3 is half the film that T2 is.

T3 reminded me of The Matrix Reloaded: Awesome special effects, robotics and CGI. Great editing. Poor story. T3 has no heart, no real substance. Fans will be suprised by the twist-ish ending, but this film did little to move me emtionally, as T2 did.

I was only 11 when T2 came out. It remains pretty much my favorite film, and I compare its perfection to everything I see today. T2 is stylized and smooth. In the early days of computer generated images, T2 blew my mind with its then-new morphing technology. The T-1000's morphs were so smooth, so fluid, and so simple. While T2 had a lot of effects shots, it focused mainly on the morphing, which made it all the more impressive. Less is more, no?

I read somewhere that T3 had 400-500 effects shots, and as in Reloaded, it was overkill. There was very little dialogue, and the relationship between John Connor and the Terminator is barely showcased. The real star or T3 is the TX. I sat in a theater with about 200 horny straight college guys, and undoubtedly, their favorite part was the shot of the TX's boobs.

T3 relied heavily on cliched and corny humor. In one scene, the Terminator puts his hand up to a cop and says (In Ah-nuld voice) "Talk to da hand." Of course, it was funny, but pretty disappointing.

Everytime I watch T2, I am fozen by the scene in which the Terminator tells John Connor that it is in man's nature to destroy himself. This powerful message has stayed with me to this day, and I can safetly state that Terminator 3 is a poor follow up to Terminator 2.

Overall: (3 out of 5)

Cast: 3 (And 2 are for Arnold) Visuals: 4 (Too many CGI shots!) Sound: 3 (I didn't like the mix) Plot: 1 (LAME, lame, lame) Stylization: 2 (Typical half-assed 2003 movie) Effects: 5 (I love REAL robots. Lots in this film!)

title: No fate but what we make or inevitability?
review:
I've loved the first two (especially the second) Terminator movies ever since I can remember. I was only six years old when I saw the first one. This was because my parents left us with a babysitter who was not supposed to show us the film, but did anyway. If I still knew who that man was I would thank him today because at age six I was scared of the Terminator but loved Arnold Schwarzenegger. He is still my favorite actor today.

In the first two, the story is very similar, but the second movie gets deeper in thought. The quote, "There is no fate but what we make for ourselves" was a theme, so to speak, and it worked well. The machines sent a Terminator through time to change what the future had brought. Apparently John Connor is supposed to be the leader of the human race, and the machines feel he is going to be there demise. Since he is such a powerful leader in the future, they feel it be best to go back in time to destroy him before he becomes such an influential and strong man. In each movie the Terminator fails, but the machines appear to become more advanced (since model 101 was replaced with 1000 from the first to the second). At the end of T2, we get the idea that it must be the end, and Judgment Day was no longer in the world's future.

Enter Terminator 3. The "theme" in this movie is almost a contradiction to T2's theme. (semi-spoiler) The Terminator explains to John that Judgment Day is inevitable, and that John's fate is to become the leader of the human race. Therefore no matter what they do Judgment Day is still going to happen. The one thing that confused me was the fact that there was still a Terminator sent back to try and destroy John Connor. If the future is inevitable, then why send a machine back when they know it's not going to work? Maybe the idea that the future happens only one way is not true, but rather just a speculation. Whatever the outcome may be, the machines do realize the importance of John Connor and will try almost anything to terminate him.

The end of the movie was great, and I was quite amazed and shocked at it. I wasn't expecting it at all, but loved it just the same. The movie is also great because it lives up to the Terminator name. The special effects are mind-blowing and the scenes are intense. If you liked T2, you should definitely not wait to see this one. Besides, you want to see the fourth one as well, don't you? You decide, is it fate or inevitability that Terminator 4 will be in our future?

title: Worth seeing on the big screen..
review: I heard some negative buzz about this film. Mainly due to the absence of Cameron and Hamilton. This movie does very well in pulling off a third installment. My only wish was to have more thought provoking plot. Not every movie can be the Matrix or Memento. But if it's action and suspense that you want this movie has it in spades. I found this quite enjoyable. 6.5/10

title: A worthy sequel to the most definitive series of the action genre
review:
"Actions speak louder than words"

I still can't believe they did it. Hollywood has actually produced something worth watching out of something that had a huge potential of being a major disaster of a film. Although this film lacked a worthwhile plot, it is nothing short of an absolute perfection in the action genre.

I was 11 years old when I watched Terminator 2 in VHS. After the first viewing of T2, Mr. Schwarzenegger became my hero/idol. In fact, this was true for most kids with a mullet and an imagination. After a decade, I thought Arnold would lose that cold hard edge he had. Well, after viewing T3, I must admit Arnold still has that edge and once again plays the role that made him famous perfectly.

Although they tried to cram in a moral and applied the usual Hollywood formula to it, it actually works as a story. This movie should have been made a long time ago. Lets hope that they don't wait another decade to bring the story of John Connor and the fight against the machines.

7.5/10

title: Awesome
review:
Absolutely awesome. Arnold was such a bad ass. Non-stop destruction and likewise, entertainment. The story too was better than I expected it to be. They really did a lot to enhance the previous stories, instead of regurgitating stuff we were already aware of. Overall it made it feel like a entirely new story instead of just a sequel.

I can only hope that there will be a fourth.

title: Terminator 3 "Ouch-What Happened?"
review:
This review does not contain any spoilers, please don't worry about my ruining the film for you. The Film itself is a spoiler!

I grew up loving the first and second films, high quality writing made up for the first film's lack of a budget, and with the second film the original author's came back and did themselves proud, by keeping it up. They knew the film would be a spectacular hit and decided to go for broke, on not just the effects, but they kept up the quality of the exposition. In 1991 we all went to the theater in our town and sat back for what was truly an enjoyable evening of Sci-Fi smash bang Fun. It truly was just that. James Cameron and William Wisher actually cared about keeping up the level of storytelling that the first film started. They are to be commended for this. The third (and by extension) the fourth installments are quite obviously the result of focus groups and Corporate decision making, they squeezed out the truly creative people behind the first films (except Arnold & Stan Winston) and what is left on the screen is truly sad, rehash rehash and more rehash. Once I had heard the news that Cameron and Wisher would not be involved, I started having doubts, but never the less I went to the theater with and open mind. It was less than an hour into the screening (Sneak Preview) 7-1-03 that I found myself looking at my watch to see how long the film had been so far. This is not a good sign. We all know that a good and inte resting "Movie" draws you in and makes you forget you are watching a film. Terminator 3 rise of the Machines fails to do that. This films constant reliance on humor and big budget effects don't make up for the fact that the writers wrote a scrictly formula flick here. I'm genuinly surprised that Arnold did not refuse to do this film without good creative support, but a 30 million dollar paycheck is hard to turn down. That brings up another question the studios were willing to spring for Arnold, so why not all of the other fine actors that should have been a part of this. Paramount made the same mistakes with its 5th (and worse) of the Star Trek flicks ("If you slap it together-They will come) Put a Big Name Star in front of us and we will mindlessly fork over our hard earned cash to see it. Hollywood needs to learn this lesson again folks, a true fan of the Terminator films will know what I'm talking about. If I bother to see the next Film, it will be when it gets broadcast on television, the commercials will probably be more entertaining. I was looking forward to this film just like the rest of you. My heavens what a shame.

title: Not as good as the others.
review: This movie could have been better, there were too many one liner gimmicks and too much comic relief.  T3 was VERY entertaining, the fight sequences are well done and the boring periods went by fast enough.  I was just looking for more but was pleasantly dissapointed.  7/10

title: Nothing we haven't seen before
review:
Possible spoilers - proceed at your peril.

Well, after twelve years of fits and starts, legal wrangling and a $30 million payday for Arnie, Terminator 3 has finally arrived. And it's unfortunate that during those twelve years very little creativity went in to crafting the story for this latest installment of the Terminator saga. Don't get me wrong - T3 is a perfectly serviceable summer action movie, full of the requisite stunts and "how'd they do that" effects we've come to expect. But you can't help getting a "same old, same old" vibe as you watch the movie unfold.

The movie is essentially a competently directed, paint-by-numbers and somewhat tighter-paced retelling of Terminator 2. All the elements are there - Arnie arriving naked and getting his leather clothes, check. The evil terminator also arriving naked and killing some people without mercy, check. Slow-motion shot of Arnie when he first meets young John Connor, check. Extended driving sequence in the desert, check. Massively destructive truck and bike chase through L.A., check. Against better judgment, going back into the heart of the beast to try and stop the rise of Skynet, check. The few new twists that are thrown into the mix, notably the Claire Danes character of Kate Brewster and the new Arnie's relationship with the new John Connor, attempt to shake things up but don't really succeed in lifting the veil of staleness. Notably absent is the emotion of the second film, as the pace never slows enough to allow the characters a moment to breathe, let alone relate to one another.

It seems that the story began with the creation of the newest nemesis in the saga, the T-X, and grew around that. She's basically a distaff version of Robert Patrick's T-1000 with a few new surprising powers (which aren't exploited nearly enough). Newcomer Kristanna Loken is appropriately menacing and relentless but does little to really distinguish herself in the role. She's certainly a sexy lady but it seems that any one of a hundred gorgeous blond actresses could have done the part with the same results. Some sharper writing, more dialogue and even a more emotive T-X could have created a more original and more memorable villainess, instead of a mere T-1000 retread (albeit a more curvaceous one). As she is, the character of the T-X mirrors the rest of the film, and it feels like a wasted opportunity. However, Hollywood always has trouble creating great female villains who aren't over-the-top campy, too mannish or overtly nymphomaniacal, so there are no surprises that this is another failure.

Overall, the best that can be said about Terminator 3 is that it is an adequate film. Some amusing moments, some entertainment, but nothing groundbreaking, nothing truly imaginative. Sticking to the formula for safety's sake. If there is a sequel (and without giving too much away, it can be said that the end of this one practically guarantees it) it would be nice to see a completely fresh take on the saga instead of going for the usual two-robots-come-back-through-time, one-to-destroy one-to-protect formula that has with this movie been drained of all its creative juice.

title: Excellent evolution of the Terminator series
review: It is a setup movie, but still stands alone as a great film. Watch for hints at another movie. The TX is ok, but Arnold is still awesome. We finally get to see Skynet!

title: Enjoyable, but not up to I or II
review:
I strongly suspect the prior commenter either has a specific financial stake or is otherwise tied to the "biz." Straight up, this is a light and entertaining film. I don't feel ripped off, but I won't give a strong recommendation to my friends.

On a plot level... To me, T1 was gripping. It generated fear. I would not use those terms for T2, but there was still some intrigue and uncertainty, and some angles to the plot. T3 didn't have any of that. No one in my theater feared the villain or expected it to succeed. In fact, even when the plot placed the bad guy in a close position to Terminate (within 10 feet SEVERAL times!), nonchalance followed, permitting escape. Obviously in T1 the villain was relentless and unwavering. Though I felt T2's villain was not as terrifying, I must give that he was relentless and if he got close he would execute immediately. Yet in T3 - I just have to call it nonchalance. Not scary at all!

Arnold holds up his end and if he's what floats your boat you'll be fine with this. But make no mistake - this is not James Cameron level material. It's not awful, but don't expect anyone to be swept off their feet by this.

One more technical note: if you don't instantly recognize the opening and closing theme music from T1, disregard this. I would say to the directors and producers of T3: shame on you. Brad Fiedel's composition would have lifted this whole affair - as great scores can, turning scenes into emotional experiences - but Brad and Cameron will do doubt share their quality in other projects down the road :)

title: THE ABSOLUTE BEST FILM OF 2003! IT'S GOT EVERYTHING, YOU'LL LOVE IT!
review: THE MOVIE OF THE YEAR HAS ARRIVED!  This was an absolute excellent movie and perfect new addition for the Terminator series.  The style and editing is kept in line with the previous' films design yet is expanded upon through action that is not-stop and unlike anything you've ever seen.  Besides that, THE SCRIPT IS BRILLANT.  It clears up ALL the plot holes you may have been wondering about from previous films such as "How the heck can a whiny civilian kid end up being the future leader of the human military resistance?" and "Does a 'terminator' being sent back to the past change the future timeline everytime one is sent back?".  The new characters perfectly fit the series and add incredible character development and archs to their personality.  T3 is an absolutely vital addition to the series and features SOME OF THE BEST ACTION SEQUENCES EVER CAPTURED ON FILM.  It also has a major emotional pull and some great dramatic scenes as characters live, die, and go through major changes before your eyes.  The acting is top-notch. Expect Loken and Stahl to become major stars after this one.  There are many twists and turns along the way too - THIS IS JUST ONE ROLLERCOASTER RIDE THAT NEVER LETS UP!  GO SEE IT AS MANY TIMES AS YOU CAN - YOU'LL LOVE IT!

title: Acceptable...
review: but leaves too many plot holes unfilled.  No shortage of action or Arnold one-liners.  The story is plausible, and is an interesting twist (especially the end) to the saga.  But what the film basically accomplishes is to set the stage and pave the way for T4, the post-apocalyptic story most fans probably want to see, and perhaps wanted to see in T3.

title: Rises to the occasion!
review: I had low expectations for this film. I thought Nick Stahl would fail as John Connor, Kristanna Loken would fail as a beleivable villian and the plot would be cheesier than the Hulk's, but I was mistaken about all of the above. The action was up to par with T2, and the plot did not disappoint. The T-X was not as imposing as the T-1000, but still a formidable foe. And although I did not forsee this as a possibility, a Terminator 4 would suit me just fine. It's good to see Arnold back in the saddle.

title: good flick, better than I expected
review:
I was a big fan of T1 and even a bigger fan of T2. I have to admit, I expected nothing from T3 at all; I was afraid of them ruining it.

After all was said and done, it was way better than I expected. Although it had a few technical problems here and there, over all it was a good movie with a non-hollywood ending. Give it a try!

title: Completely satisfied
review: As a big fan of the first two films, I was prepared to be disappointed. But T3 delivered everything you want a movie (or at least this movie) to do. Excellent story, characters, action, effects... it was all there and all good. You will holler at the screen. Go see this movie and enjoy it.

title: EXCELLENT!
review:
Terminator 3 deserves its place beside Terminator 1 and 2 as the great cinematic epic that it is.

I entered T3 with zero expectations. I left feeling relieved and overjoyed -- "they did it," was my only thought. "They made the sequel I would have made." And they really did.

Whatever the critics say, know this: even James Cameron approves of Terminator 3. It carries his vision forward perhaps as faithfully as he himself would have done. There is the landmark humor, action, and, above all -- story.

I have read complaints, from some critics, who seem to think T3 was meant to be a perpetually extended version of its predecessor, T2. No. T3 is in new hands; spawned entirely by new brains. The ideas are fresh, and the scope? -- Extraordinary.

It is perhaps the best Terminator movie yet.

title: Not bad but doesn't stand up to other 2
review:
I was able to see Terminator 3 in an early screening. I had been waiting 12 years to see this movie. This was the equivalent of a new Star Wars movie to me. Of course jumped at the chance to see it early.

I must say that I was disappointed. The movie was obviously not directed or written by the notoriously anal and creative James Cameron. The first two movies were very plot driven which made them fantastic science fiction/thriller/action movies. This was driven mostly by the goal of having large chase scenes and setting up the possibility of a sequel. The story didn't flow and felt forced at points. Some scenes were very cool, and the acting of Claire, Arnold, and the female terminator was very good. The new John Conner left something to be desired. Overall the movie was fun to watch because Arnold is always fun to watch as the terminator, however I didn't find it very thought provoking at all. And the ending surprised me. I won't give it away, but I didn't expect what happened to happen. But go see it for yourself. Maybe James Cameron will come back to do the fourth.

title: No Hamilton, Cameron or Furlong, who cares??
review: The film was great! Finally something happens in the trilogy, the only thing that bugged me is the length of this movie,... too short!!! They could of gone in details about what happens in the future but still it was great! Alot better than the first or second one.

title: An incredible addition to the Terminator legacy...
review:
It is plain and simple. Terminator 3 far exceeded my expectations...

Looking at the figures, the film was not directed by James Cameron, not composed by Brad Fidel, had hardly any of the same actors in it and yet...was amazing.

This film contained some of the greatest action sequences seen on screen, was well acted, and had enough plot twists to keep up both the physical and psychological attraction of the viewer.

Perhaps the greatest attribute of Terminator 3, is that the film pays tribute and recognizes its roots. Many of the situations in this film are similar, yet do not simply repeat the formula of the first two films. Yet, at the same time the plot recognizes and uses all of the elements of the Terminator story to create a realistic, exciting, and ultimately depressing film which will be sure to stand the test of time for many years to come.

title: Great ending
review:
***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** This movie was a great movie for me (a die hard terminator fan) with an AMAZING ending... I'm not gonna say anything to spoil it ;) It had a lot of comedy scenes though that kinda make fun of T2 but it was good nontheless... I guess they didn't wanna make it 2 serious because it would be dissapointing to people since nothing can be as good as T2 hahaha but yea... it sets up for what's to come later... nothing else will be said =) go watch the movie and read this and then you will get what I mean. Hope I didn't say 2 much :

THIS IS A SPOILER DO NOT READ PAST THIS!!

Why does the terminator (arnold) kill John? I didn't get the reason.

title: Good God I'm still laughing!
review: This movie is the epitome of how bad sequels can get and just how good James Cameron really is! The movie utterly spits in the face of T2 with carbon-copy sequences (opening scene, cemetery shootout, and the tanker chase) that reek of campy humour. Just take a look at Earl Boen's character who was given a rude awakening in T2, much to audiences' satisfaction, and in T3 is brought in for a quick cameo that completely mocks his role in Judgment Day! And for the biggest shame of all: the Terminator is no longer an unstoppable, ultra-violent, killing machine, but a one-liner spouting gentle giant! And the TX! Well if trying to imitate Robert Patrick's vicious T-1000 (and poorly, at that) and inflating one's bust while wearing tight leather is scary, than slap me senseless because I was too busy laughing! And let's not forget the complete lack of interesting characters and a story that at least concludes instead of opening up room for ANOTHER sequel! Maybe that sequel will be written and directed by James Cameron, star Linda Hamilton, and maybe even bring back the drama from T1 & 2.

title: Flawed but damn good !
review: I really liked this movie. I had low expectations but it was excellent. Great action, good time-line tie-ins, o.k. acting. It has some plot holes (or rather easy omissions) but they did not spoil my fun. It manages the time-line, alternate futures problems pretty well. You and your friends will have good "but does it fit with the other two ?" conversations.

title: talk to the hand!
review:
there was so little expectation for this film and a lot of negative press, all they kept saying was that this was an unneccesary sequel but you know what? these are the same idiots that praise charlies angels 2 and legally blonde 2---

THIS MOVIE WAS GOOD AND IT WAS MORE THAN JUST AN ALL OUT ACTION THRILLER!

It basically explained the whole concept of fate and nicely tied itself to the first 2 movies of the terminator series. I loved it and I can't wait til this comes out on DVD-- Although there might not be a Terminator 4, this movie was so dramatic and riviting that it makes you want to see another Terminator movie!

Two thumbs up...

title: Wow
review: There's bad history with 3rd movies in a series...Alien 3, The Godfather 3, Jaws 3, etc.  This one breaks the cycle.  Excellent story, great acting (especially the T-X), and an absolutely amazing ending.  Kristanna Loken builds upon Robert Patric's emotionless killer T1000, and makes the T-X one of the best evil nemesis's ever.  Arnie looks great.  Other than the story, the thing that really stands out is the effects.  Rather than relying on CG, the majority of the action scenes have the look and feel of reality, whether they're created by miniatures, or good old-fashioned stuntwork.  Jonathan Mostow has done the series proud, let's hope T4 isn't too far off.

title: HOLY SH*T!!!
review:
This has got to be the best action movie of the year, bar none. It was all action. Matrix Reloaded on the other hand had 14-minutes of action (i.e. the freeway chase), which wasn't even directed by the Wachowski brothers but by Second Unit Director David R. Ellis(Final Destination 2).

The CGI was amazing.

Arnold Schwarzenegger IS the Terminator.

Highlights of the movie: *POSSIBLE SPOILERS*

The crane chase & the bathroom brawl

T3: Rise of the Machines deserves 10/10.

title: Worth The Wait
review: Wow this movie was so awesome, Arnold can still kick butt and the New TX gives him a good challenge. The sound was the best for this picture it blew me away because it was non stop action. only thing i didnt like was the comic relief that didnt belong in this movie. But overall it was AWESOME. I think there will be a T4 because arnold does say "We'll Meet Again" but im worried he will not be in the next one because it took them 11 years since they had T2 and im afraid theres not going to be another for at least 10 years more by then Arnold will be too old and he will not star in it.

title: Ahhhnold's Back!
review:
T3 was a decent film despite the fact that I entered the theater with the false pretense that Mostow would be able to imitate Cameron's style in T1 and T2. The only reason I could see the need to have a Terminatrix was for the sex appeal. Had Robert Patrick (T- 1000) been brought back, the film would've been equally good, if not better. There were definitely some moments where Ahnold's one-liners were just hilarious. I would've liked to have seen a slightly stronger ending. You'll never forget Sarah Connor driving off into the desert, or Ahnold sticking up his thumb as he's getting submerged in the hot steal. But nukes being launched everywhere?

Not sure if this will conclude the Terminator legacy, but if they do make another one, I'll definitely go see it.

title: Great 3rd Movie!!! Go see it!!!
review:
I just got back from seeing T3 and it was all it was hyped up to be and then some. The action sequences in this movie are outstanding. It is great to see a movie that relies more on stunts (whenever possible) than special effects for a change.

The movie takes place from where the last movie left off and stays in context with the storyline from the previous movies.

T3 also provides more "comic relief" than the previous two. While some of the jokes were very cheesy, they were well placed and provided some humor to the film, similar to something out of the Indiana Jones' series.

The female terminator was a good villain (and hot). The action sequence where Arnold gets ripped through a building on a crane is one of the best "chase" scenes in recent memory. A bit of trivia is that the movie was overbudget and Arnold paid $1.4 million out of his own pocket to have the scene shot.

Finally, the best part of the movie, and the reason why I am giving this movie such a high score, is the ending. The ending is brilliant and I would encourage you to see the movie as quickly as possible before someone ruins the ending for you.

Placing this movie in the action genre, I would have to give it 10 stars since this movie certainly fits in the categorial rating of "excellent." The action is exciting and original, the plot is solid and the ending is outstanding. Alliteration: Another Amazing Arnold Action Adventure.

title: Better than expected, worse than it should have been.
review: Ok, I expected this movie to be a total flop, and I was wrong.  It had good action sequences, a tolerable plot, and decent acting.  Overall I enjoyed it.  Will I see it again, though?  Probably not.  The first Terminator movie was revolutionary because of its effects and its plot; I thought it was far ahead of its time.  The second movie, while nothing exceptional in the story department, had some great performances, and completely over the top action, simply because of the number of memorable sequences.  The visuals were amazing, and come on...the T1000 has to be one of the greatest "silent" villains ever seen on the screen.  Here, T3 lags far behind; in no way does it push the envelope compared to other current movies.  The action, while well done, is nothing new.  The characters are no longer memorable; the new Terminator is nowhere as cool in concept or on screen as the T1000.  The movie also lacks the grand scope of the first 2; it feels short.  In fact, it feels mostly like a set-up for another sequel, this time finally taking us into the actual war.

title: wonderful
review:
I've seen Matrix, X-men, the Hulk, and even Finding Nemo. I loved all these movies, but I think that T3 is the best movie of the summer. It had a better story than the Hulk, more action packed than X2 and more consistent(computer graphic wise) than Matrix.

It was exciting from the very begin. The first car chase seen was jaw dropping. I swear my mouth was opened the whole time from amazement. I was at the edge of my seat the whole time. Most of the computer graphics actually looked real. There are very few movies that have looked as good.

There are problems though. It is not as good as the first two. Allow there are better action scenes, the character development is lacking. In T2, you can sense a closeness between Arnold and John, but it just wasn't there in T3. Also there was little chemistry with John and lover interest Claire Danes. Danes is also suppose a close relationship with her father in the movie, but they don't develop it enough for you to care.

Despite that it is a well made movie. My advice, if you want a story as good as the first two, don't go. This movie is not going to win any oscars. If you love a good action movie, this is a must see.

title: Another solid chapter in a reliable franchise
review:
My hat is off to Mr. Jonathan Mostow, who does an admirable job in following up James Cameron in the newest addition to the Terminator franchise. Made twelve years after the the previous, which was made seven years after the original, The Terminator keeps coming back for more, this time in the form of a woman Terminatrix (played by Kristanna Loken). John Connor (Nick Stahl) must once again be protected, this time by not only the Terminatrix, but also from Judgement Day. Kate Brewster (Claire Danes) is also under the protection this time around by Ahnuld.

The action sequences in the movie are tremendous, showing us all what the reported $170 million budget was used for, especially the chase scene early on in the movie.

Without going into too many specifics, I found this movie to be especially enjoyable because it took risks. You will not understand what I mean until you see the movie, but the writers and director took some chances with this movie; something that is rare for a movie with such an enormous production budget. It all pays off in the end as we get another excellent Terminator movie.

9/10

title: a very good movie experience
review: for those who were disappointed, I say why don't you do a better job. I never had such a good movie experience in a long time. The special effects were absolutely awesome, the story was great (non-stop action) and so was the acting. The wait was defintely worth it. Can't wait for the next one. What more is there to say?

title: Awesome
review: Being an action freak I must say this movie is awesome. The action was fast paced and never dragged on for too long like Reloaded. You get the introduction of the characters in the first 10 minutes and from then on the movie kicks into high gear with gun battles and car chases with small breaks in between to develop the story. Oh, and by the way, the story was pretty good too with a little twist at the end. When I go into a movie I don't nitpick- I just want to have a good time. Only fairies nitpick.... If you want a movie that has loads of action with a decent story at the same time then this is it. Never a dull moment in the movie. This one definitely has my vote for the best action movie of the year.

title: The Terminator returns to the top of the sci-fi heap.
review:
My first impression of T3 was that it was going to be another retread of the same storyline established in the first two installments (evil robot sent back through time, good guy/bot is sent back to protect the target). The original trailers for this film didn't alter that impression. I had the feeling it was going to be lackluster.

Was I ever wrong.

The Story starts with ominous music by Marco Beltrami, quite a departure from the classic Terminator Score by Bad Fiedel, but it's fitting, after all this is a new story arc. We meet up with John Connor, now in hid mid 20's and living as a transient and keeping no records of his identity (no phone, no residence, nothing) as to prevent him being tracked by any assailants from the future, should they appear.

Two terminators appear from the future, one in the form of the female T-X, and one in the classic Ahnuld form. The T-x immediately starts killing it's targets in the present, each of which will have a significance with John Connor in the future.

John is hurt and breaks into a veterinary clinic to get meds to ease his pain as he mends his wounds when the T-X shows up for a target......and it's not John Connor... ...and that's all I will say...you should see this for yourself. The second half of the movie deals with the RISE OF THE MACHINES aspect and you won't be disappointed. Forget the convoluted, arrongant, cold Matrix Sequels and revisit the reigning king of sci-fi film series.

title: Absolutely awesome movie! But...
review:
Just came back from seeing Terminator 3 and I must say, this movie was fantastic. Great action, great story, great intensity, great acting and great ending. This movie is a must see and definitely worth the price of admission (or even if you're over charged). It definitely felt like a different Terminator movie. Overall very well done.

BUT. It was not as good as Terminator 2. The movie lacked a few things to make me say it was one of the best movies ever (as T2 is my favorite movie of all time). The biggest item it was missing was the depth of Terminator 1 and 2. It was missing a soul. The movie seemed REALLY fast, the first 30 minutes were paced very well and then it was sent into overdrive from there. Arnold's character of the T-101 was good, but come on, way too many funny lines and he's not as ruthless as he should be! My biggest complaint though is the music. PLEASE BRING BACK BRAD FIEDEL, I BEG YOU! Marco Beltrami's score, FLAT OUT SUCKED or WAS NON-EXISTENT! Who hired this goof?! The movie could have been EVEN BETTER if the score was good!

Mostow, you did a good job, but seriously you have to pace a movie a little better instead of one big rush like most of your movies are.

The car/crane chase was absolutely amazing... WOW. Bathroom fight was nuts. But I have to say the graveyard shoot out was WAY TOO SHORT.

Yes, it does seem like there are more cons then pros, but trust me, this is a great film and definitely worth the watch. If there is a Terminator 4, I can't wait for it.

Final Rating: 9/10

Again, PLEASE BRING BACK BRAD FIEDEL, I'M BEGGING YOU! I'M ON MY KNEES HERE!

title: They did it again - amazing!
review:
When I first saw the preview for this movie a couple of months ago I was very worried that it would just be a repeat of T2 with a cute chick thrown in the mix. Not the case at all! - The storyline was creative and 'realistic', the action was filmed beautifully, and there were no whining little 10 year olds for Arnie to babysit. And to top it all off, the couple of Arnie one-liners were actually funny. Kristanna LÃ¸ken, aka T-X Teminatrix, was absolutely awesome! She really nailed the part. The look, the eyes,the bod, and the vicious killings really worked for me. She's got a new fan. I just got back from the movie and I am already planning to go see it again. ASAP.

Go see this movie. You will not be disappointed.

-Demon420 Official rating: 2 bongs up!

title: Excellent action movie that is a little unique, not as good as the first two
review:
This movie surprised me, especially with the change of director. I thought it would not be good. However, i feel they did the series justice. I found the comical parts to be entertaining though sometimes hurt the mood of the movie. The chase scenes,

particularly the first one, were a little different and not as monotonous as they have become these days. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good time and that loves the terminator like myself.

title: AWESOME!
review: Ok, I read the first guy's review and everything that he is complaining about with Skynet etc. was explained in the movie - he must not have been paying attention because I didn't understand why he had all of those questions.  I thought this movie was superb!  Arnold has some really funny scenes and Nick Stahl is wonderful!  Soooo much better than Edward Furlong. I thought Edward did a terrible job in T2 - Nick portrays the character awesomely - Danes does a good job also.  I do miss Linda Hamilton and Michael Biehn though.  The stunts and effects are astounding - I actually saw stunts performed that haven't been done before in all other general action flicks.  Overall - I was very impressed with the cast - I thought it would have been more effective to have used Vin Diesal or someone else as the other terminater besides the female.  She just didn't scare me like Robert Patrick in T2.  Definately worth it and can't wait for a T4 - Arnold was born for this character!

title: I hope there's more to come!
review:
This movie if anything left me dying for more Terminator!! Okay, no, it's not art-house, it's not a brainy film, but is it entertaining! Many critics call it a B-Movie. Well, so what. It's fast, fun, and escapist to a hilt.

Most critics feel a need to view movies as "art" and critique it on that point. For me, movies are escapism and if they make me forget about the outside world for a couple of hours, they've done their job. Terminator 3 does it wonderfully!

The chase scene blows the much-lauded scene from Matrix Reloaded out of the water. Just awesome.

Arnold is back, baby!

title: Not bad at all
review:
After so good T2 one would not expect much from T3. I was surprised, it was much better then I expected. I would give it 7 out of 10.

Plot tries to be in accordance with T2. extends its final pretty seamlessly. Acting is not bad, Kristana Loken is interesting a lot. Arnie does his best.

overall, worth to see of course.

title: Not as good as the first two.
review: I didn't get to see the first 2 terminator movies until just a few years ago.  I became an instant fan of them immediatly, but when i heard there was a sequel coming out, i got really excited.  But then i got some terrible news.  James Cameron, the director of the first two Terminator movies was not going to direct this one, and the actress who was playing Sarah Connor said she didn't want to return.  I have to admit also that when the first T3 trailer came out i booed it(as did many other people who were there that night.)  But soon the trailers kept looking better and better and i thought maybe it wasn't going to be so bad.  Still though i kept low expectations(which i think every fan should have of cult movies). I saw it today, and it keeps getting better and better to me as time goes on. Although it repeats many things from the first two, i think it was well done, especially in SFX dept. Any fan of terminator should see this, and although it's not as good as the first two, it's worthy of the terminator name.

title: It's about time!
review: This movie is precariously balanced between being a hit and being a flop. Here's why; its a good story, with great special effects, however, it lacks significant new intrique.  The movie has also come on the scene late.  The Terminator audience may have lost contact.  Although, I didn't.  If you enjoyed the prior two movies, you should enjoy this one as well.  I don't know; however, if you need to see it more than once. I am debating on seeing it again.

title: a pretty good movie, but would have been better with James Cameron
review:
First of all, I would like to say that I enjoyed the movie...Arnold came back for the 3rd time and did an excellent job as the terminator yet again.However, there are a few things that I didn't understand. 1.If the terminator was a different machine in this movie and didn't remember anything about when he was with young john, then how did he know to find the car keys in the visor(young john taught him this)???? 2.Why do they keep on sending back terminators to protect him from the evil ones???Why couldn't they just send a terminator to destroy skynet and be done with it. 3.If they destroyed the skynet lab in T2, how did skynet magically reappear for the 3rd movie to destroy the world????

Besides the fact that most of the movie was confusing, I still enjoyed it but would prefer the wonderful direction of James Cameron over Jonathan Mostow any day!!!!

title: Fulfillment of Destiny
review:
In "Terminator", there is Kyle Reese protecting Sara Connor, and telling her everything she needs to know about the future. In "Terminator 2," there is Sara Connor protecting John Connor and making sure that he has a future. In "Terminator 3" we return to man protecting wife, and the essence of Kyle Reese is back.

This movie has many similarities to the first of this series, continuing the cycle of what is to come.

title: Don't listen to the critics
review: Ok, I expected a horrible disaster of a movie.  You're making a sequel where you kill off one of the main characters and use a different actor for another: crazy, right?  Boy was I wrong.  The car chase scene in this movie is breathtaking. I was completely stunned by the action in this film.  And the cool thing is, it's all action! Great summer movie.

title: I wasn't expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised.
review: I wasn't planning on going to see T3. I figured it would be a brain-dead, explosion-ridden summer flick. It wasn't. Granted, there were a (very) few moments where I wanted to mute the excessive explosions, and many more moments when I wanted to shout at the protagonists "Don't just stand there! Run!," but other parts make up for it. The unexpected and well-timed humor brought theater-filling laughs from the crowd. The movie managed to avoid the cliched ending one might expect and earned a deserved applause for that. All in all, worth seeing.

title: The best yet!
review: I saw Terminator 3 July 1st at the first sneak previewing near me.  This movie has a great story line, is action packed, explains why Judgement Day still happens really well, and the chase scene itself beats the entire Matrix Reloaded!  This movie is almost nonstop action from beginning to end. This movie also explains what happened to Sarah Conner.  Don't beleive critics who say this movie "sucks","has no story line", "Arnold Schwarzenegger won't do any more movie from how terrible this is", etc. etc. etc.  It is nothing but lies!  The best movie I have seen in a long time. This is a must see!!

title: More than I expected, but ...
review:
All together, T3 is not a bad movie. Comparing to other action films, I give it a 7. The minor problem with T3 is not much of logic but actions followed by actions. Well, what do I want?. The story line is kind of thin. Hey, what do I want?! Another issue is T3 reckons many T2 set ups, though with some interesting twist, which is not bad.

The movie is not very long, thus lucks some insight development of how and what is the future. Will that be a T4 to explain all this?

Recommending!

title: Better make the T4 sequel...
review: because this film left me wanting much more. Definately was a fun movie to watch, but it screams for a sequel! Arnold is finally back with a good film, and the great egoist James Cameron may finally realize that other people can make good with his old ideas. Hopefully this film and the positive reaction will cause Cameron to actually start making quality movies again along the lines of Aliens, T1 and T2 and True Lies.

title: Arnold brings it back towhat action films should be.
review: Can you compare this film to the other 2? You can but don't cause this is filmed and written very diffrently, but don't let that fool you this is a really good action film. The movie has some great action scenes and doesn't ruin it with special effects or anything along that. In T3 unlike other films action is not the film, action is part of the films. Along with this you have great comedy that Arnold carries some of his better one liners. I mean I can't recall a time in which Arnold has made me laugh out loud in a serious film. GO see thi film I won't spole it for yourself. 3 out of 4 stars!!

title: Brilliance is irrelevant; a serviceable action film.
review: Given all the impropitious factors that were stacked against this latest installment I think the film works reasonably well and has at least the visceral appeal that a 170 million dollar blockbuster should have. Yes it lacks the artistry and elan that Cameron brought to the first two installments and yes it does simply rehash and expand previous action sequences that made the first two films so enjoyable. However I found the acting to be serviceable and the human element was palpable enough to the point where it did not feel like a completely boneheaded action film. My main qualm with the characters was with the TX who was not fleshed out enough and not nearly as menacing as the T-1000 from the second film. The majority of the action sequences serve to simply entertain us and do so in spades. However they were also a way to mask the fact that the story was incredibly thin and the dialogue laconic and derivative of the popular catch phrases established in the first two films. But in conclusion it must be noted that outside of the context of the first two films this is a summer action movie that entertains and even makes fun of itself to the joy of the viewer. The action thankfully does not really too heavily on CGI effects and ends up boing much more entertaining than 'The Matrix Reloaded' or 'The Hulk' by action standards. Compared with the first two films it is no more than a road movie with action sequences and minimal sci-fi elements thrown in. Not entirely forgettable but the second one is still by far the finest of the three. 6 out of 10, worth a look for entertainment purposes.

title: "Rise of the Machines". Minor spoilers.
review:
I didn't really know what to expect from "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines". I hadn't hyped myself up for it, being that I loved "T1" and liked "T2". So I went to see it today and I was pretty blown away by it. Clearly James Cameron, who directed both "T1" and "T2", is not here to direct "T3". Jonathan Mostow, who I have never heard of until this film, really knows how to direct a "Terminator" film.

I should tell you all that there is definitely going to be a "Terminator 4". Do not let the films title "Rise of the Machines" mislead you in any way, since by films end, the machines have risen and the war has started. Arnold Schwarzenegger is good as always, as is Nick Stahl (filling in for Edward Furlong) as John Conner. Claire Danes, who I have never really paid much attention to (other than "Romeo & Juliet" in 1996), is also pretty convincing too. Of course, the real light here is Kristanna Loken as the T-X, who is even better than Robert Patrick's T-1000.

I give "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines" a 9/10.

title: It took 12 years to make this???
review:
OKay... I wasn't expecting Days of Heaven.

Terminator 3 is hollow and overblown and did not interest me from the opening shot. Too many characters and elements were missing from the story for this installment to be interesting. The script was contrived, weak and all over the place. There was nothing ground breaking about the film; although the action was consistent. The film lacked atmosphere. The direction was a let down and a cover up. At least, Cameron had a vision... Jonathan Mostow hardly has a clue. There was no story just mayhem. The story line was weak and uninspired... I can't believe it took five writers to come up with that script was an end product.

ACTUAL DIALOGUE: "There's my father's plane! I trained on it!"

The plot was just a bunch of contrivances to paste and thread together action scenes. I think more time should have been spent in the Animal Hospital -- the only original idea in the script. Granted it's inexplicable... but I admire the bold choice in a movie that made NO OTHERS. EVEN the FX in T2 were better.

The new characters were boring and uninspired. John Conner was hardly inspiring as the savior of mankind. The sending of a new Terminator should have been developed more. Why is the new Terminator sexy? I mean that's pointless. Do something with the sex appeal. The big problem is you can't take any of the Terminators seriously. Ah-nuld is too funny and the other is way too sexy. Robert Patric in T2 was vastly superior in so far as his performance.

The biggest let down was that Ah-nuld NEVER REALLY KICKED ANY ASS. He just made corny jokes. There were funny jokes but funny jokes do not a good film make. I wanted my money back. Unfortunately, Henny Youngman won't be around to make the eventual Terminator 4 as he would make a great Terminator to duel with Der Ah-Nuld.

As a whole, the film lacked so much that I saw no need to end it... it was phony from the start. 170 Million Dollar Opium for the mass-market masses (and the 1rst Terminator was a lo budget Cult Film and vastly superior).

Within a trilogy, this film is worse than Godfather III was; but more way funny.

MOSTOW NEEDS TO GO BACK TO MAKING LAME AND REPETITIVE SUBMARINE MOVIES!!!

title: Mindless fun - but disrespects T1 & T2
review:
It seems that this film is the victim of trying to stuff as many 'what if this happens' into the script to the degree that it is no longer a movie, but a 'puff' piece trying get your attention in any way possible. It's like all these reality shows trying to one-up each other (Who wants to Marry a Survivor Idol). Many sequels have turned into disappointing rehashes. Alien 3 destroyed the feeling of having emotionally vanquished the big bad bugs by killing the girl and tossing Ripley back in the fire. Godfather 3 should never be considered a legitimate successor to GF1 & 2. When a sequel feels the need to outdo it's predecessor, it begins to lose credibility. The most obvious problem is that, while the first film creates a successful 'formula', and the second film takes the formula and pushes the envelope, the third film can't do anything without feeling like a repeat.

Indeed, T3 turns into a comedy, because everything it does as a different take on the formula is a joke. This is too bad, since you are dealing with a mass murdering cyborg, nuclear armegeddon, and main characters fighting within inches of their lives. One scene, the 'new' John Connor pleads for Arnie to help stop Skynet, Arnie replies with a dumb one liner that takes all the air out of what could have been a tense and gripping moment. Same thing for any moment where we are supposed to take things seriously. You can't, so you don't feel the anxiety when lives are in danger.

T2 had this tenseness, you cared about their survival. In T3, you already know the score. When Arnie first runs into John, he is scared and asks "Are you going to kill me?". Of course not, we already know he is the good guy from T2. And so on.
