However, there is a major hole in this story.

One of the beginning lines is this: John Connor says that "when I was 13, another Terminator was sent to kill me as a teenager. I was protected by a Terminator." However this cannot be true because of the simple fact that in T1, it begins in May 1984 (dialogue between Reese and the cop says so) so therefore Sarah could not have given birth to John until 1985. In fact in T2, when Robert Patricks liquid terminator character looks John up in the police computer, it says John birthday is 2/10/85. So, when John was 13 that would make the year 1998. Wait just a minute though. Judgement Day, according to Arnold's character, occurs on August 27, 1997. Whoa, talk about not thinking through the entire story before you write it! Holy snap! Also, in T3, Sarah Connor dies in 1997. Believable, only except for the fact that John says in T3 that Sarah battled Leukeimia for 3 years after the doc gave her 6 months to live. So, if the T3 storyline is true, Sarah died when John was 16! In 2001! But she couldn't have died then because in T2 Judgement day was supposed to happen August 27, 1997. Yes, I know they stopped it and all that, but apparently, the writers in T3 had that happen in 1998. So apparently the writers could have done a lot better job. In fact, another thing is John is supposed to be 23 in this movie. That would make the year 2008. So if John was born in 1985 (according to information given in T1 and T2) that would make the information (age-wise) accurate. So why the heck couldn't they make everything else accurate? Let's just hope that for T4 (which is in production) that they think the script through a little bit better, and try to keep it true to the story that James Cameron developed. Let's face it, his was a lot better.

The SFX were incredible, especially the high speed chase scene about half an hour in. The story (except for the flaws mentioned above) was touching and remarkably well done. I loved the ending scene, where you see the nuclear warheads falling at various locations around the world. Overall this was not a terrible movie. I don't think it held up to the first two, but it is a good continuation.

My Rating: **1/2 out of ****

title: They couldn't leave well enough alone, could they?
review:
-Spoiler for T2 as well- You know why James Cameron wasn't directing, right? Good, we can get straight to the point then.

In the ending of T2, John Connor and Terminator eliminated all possibility of Skynet and Judgement Day happening. Thereby changing the future by altering the past, a popular SFI-FI time travail concept.

The series would have been fine if they left it, but they didn't, they had to go into the other time travail concept; You can't change the past. So they just HAD to bring back the Terminator, completely screwing up the canon of the series; "They sent back two terminators" (Opening lines of T2) and they also just HAD to have a female Terminator, which is fine, but with the whole "you've got to travail in the buff" thing, they also probably HAD to focus on TX's behind, I don't remember if they did or not though.

In fact, they only real good parts of T3 were the special effects, which were nothing special.

T3 is not my first choice.

title: Extremely Mediocre
review:
Above all, this movie even failed to create (for me) any real sense of urgency or excitement. Which is the essential point behind an action movie.

Some of the problems inherent in Terminator 3

1. Essentially, the plot is wrong. Terminator 3 negates the positive vision of the previous two movies (that Sarah and John Connor can prevent or at least seriously influence the future). T3 abandons that vision for a entirely fatalistic one (that, in fact, Judgement Day cannot be prevented or even really influenced).

2. The timing and pacing of the movie just seem off. The car cash sequence runs on too long, the battle in the bathroom runs on too long, the robo-tanks are boring, the Skynet "planes" are easily destroyed, etc.

3. The new Terminatrix is essentially the same as T-1000 in T2, so she's literally boring, whereas the T-1000 is really new and exciting in T2. You're frequently surprised by the T-1000 in T2 whereas you're just bored by the Terminatrix in T3. The acting by Robert Patrick was quite good (really effective in being scary and mechanical), whereas Kristana Loken is just.........well, I just wasn't scared or even impressed.

4. The plot was muddled so that it felt both boring (repeats in many aspects T2) and just messy, so you never really felt the suspense which was very pronounced in the first two movies.

5. Claire Danes was a poor substitute for Linda Hamilton. Again, Linda Hamilton brought an unusual range of depth of emotion for an action movie. Claire Danes was just your archetypal cardboard damsel in distress.

6. The action sequences were simply not that impressive. If you notice, while in T1 and T2, the characters were really fighting for their lives - they're wounded, bloody, covered in debris and sweat, really battered. In T3, the only thing the hero John Connor suffers is that the Terminatrix breaks his leg at the very end of the movie. Kate Brewster isn't even scratched. You never get the sense that their lives are truly in danger. In fact, the Terminatrix and John Connor only come face to face twice (both for extremely short segments) and she doesn't even wound him (until the very end of the movie).

Overall, this was a really mediocre movie.

title: Runs the entertainment spectrum; doofy to great!
review:
Hey, I really liked Terminator 3, but no historic milestones here. Kristanna Loken, now my favorite evil cyborg, is also easy on the eyes. Like Arnold, her acting leaves something to be desired but their characters are emotionless machines, after all...well almost. T-X departs from the standard set by Terminator 1 & 2 in that she IS equipped with RAGE. Previous Terminators were supposed to be unfeeling killing machines determined to carry out their directives, although Arnold's character does develop a degree of compassion starting in 2.

Great special effects, gratuitous cyber-violence, and even a surprise ending combine to make this one fun to watch. The prolonged fight scene in the restroom has comedy; the T-X instantly rolling back onto the moving truck is wicked cool, and Arnold hanging from the crane is both!

title: A great sequel
review: Don't believe all the negative comments about this movie. It's a great movie! Excellent action and a well written script. It's not a James Cameron movie. I think it's better than a Cameron movie. More interesting to watch and not as manipulative as his movies. I always feel a bit fooled the second time I watch one of his movies because they suddenly feel so empty. All the splendor is gone. T 3's main characters actually feel like humans - not like the caricatures that Cameron tend to rely on. The movie also has a nice Japanese feel to it. There's both drama, fun and serious action in a good combination. Excellent photo, effects and editing. I'll give it 4 of 5.

title: I just expected this!
review:
When I decided to go to the cinema and watch Terminator 3 I was afraid that this new sequel will be nothing but pop corn cinema. And I was unfortunately right.

Does anybody need this? The entire concept has a main fault. In Terminator 2, the robots failed to kill John Connor as a kid. Why are they sending a robot back into the past when he is grown up? He will probably be more prepared and ready for facing another terminator. I would have sent the new terminator into the past when Sarah Connor was a kid or even earlier when she was being born.

What I liked were the old terminators in the movie and Nick Stahl was really great.

What I did not like was the stupid sun glasses joke, the action scene in witch the T-101 is hanging on a vehicle which is just the equivalent of the truck chase in part 2, the scene when the T-101 has a malfunction and tries to eliminate John Connor and the entire movie... ... this is just pop corn cinema ignoring the higher needs concerning an intelligent plot for the real fans of the Terminator series. I was really disappointed. Will part 4 be an Alien clone?

title: OK movie but Danes must be Terminated
review: People are complaining about Jonathan Mostow.  I think he is a very good director. What people should be complaining about is the Clare Danes character.  I was rooting for the bad guy..girl all through this movie because of her.  Someone said she is in danger of becoming like Jennifer Jason Leigh.  Don't insult Jennifer, she takes chances with her roles and she has never annoyed me in the way Clare Danes does in this movie. SPOILERS!!!  Other then her the movie is pretty good as far as movies like this are concerned. We have Arnold returning again and again and again...he must of been offed in this movie about 400 times but he comes BACK.  The Terminatrix is pretty interesting,  she is a lean mean killing machine who Arnold says in indestructible but we know different.  This movie is basically a Fail Safe type movie.  Computer virus takes over the worldwide defense system (skynet). And it turns on itself so it can annihilate all humans.  So of course Clare Danes and John Conner are the only 2 people who can thwart this and Arnold has to save them so they can have children and lead the resistance. There is some anti war Dr Strangelove type ending pasted on.  All I have to say is if John Connor has to be stuck in a fall out shelter and spend the rest of my life with the Clare Danes character I would take my chances with the nuclear bombs if I was him.

title: lots of fun, though no T2
review:
If you go into this expecting a fun action picture that is not going to be at the level of the first two movies, you'll probably have a good time. There are some fun action scenes, a fair amount of amusing jokes referring to the previous movie and a really hot evil robot played by a model whose vacuous model stare works perfectly in the role.

But no, it's not as good as the first two. Those movies moved like lightning, offering a breakneck speed that kept you from catching your breath. T2 was a thrill ride from beginning to end, and T3 never works up that sort of momentum. Its holes are easier to pick at than the previous movies (although not terrible by action movie standards) and the ending is downright disappointing. But if rather than comparing it with two of the best action films ever made, you compare it with more typical action flicks, it's superior to many, a good but not great movie that is energetic fun most of the time with some terrific moments here and there. Yes, it would have been better directed by James Cameron rather than some director so obscure that I don't know how he finagled the job, but it's still effectively directed. Just lower your expectations a little bit and watch it.

title: Doesn't quite "bust" the "block".
review: To add a third installment to a very good film and it's even better sequel takes a lot of doing,particularly if you are going to press on with the project without the director that is responsible for the success of the first two.James Cameron is no where behind the camera for T3,and this will be obvious to anyone watching.Also absent is Linda Hamilton,another big reason for the success of the previous two films. Even Arnold Schwarzenegger,the man we have come to know and love as the T100,doesn't quite seem the same anymore.The computer generated special effects are just a little too obvious for my taste,and the entire film takes on the feel of a small,made for cable,or straight to video dud instead of a big screen blockbuster.I don't watch very many sequels, because they all too often disappoint me and ruin my memory of the previous film.I thought,in this case that since the second film surpassed the first in terms of quality viewing,that this third installment would at least measure up to one of those two.Much to my dismay,I was wrong.If this film could not have been directed by Cameron, it should have been given to someone on the same class as him,such as Ridley Scott.Perhaps it would have stood a better chance of being good.

title: How to pass Judgement on the Day I saw T3?
review:
********** Spoilers ********

Well, what can I say? It's still Terminator chasing Terminator and John, plus a host of new chracters. Mind blowing Action and FX and Arnold back in his Terminator boots is good enough for a funtime movie with popcorn.

However, that not what I expect from a T movie. I am a siccccckkk fan of T movies, and to speak the truth after watching T3, I was not sure whether I was dissappointed or satisfied.

I was very happy to see that it wasn't a complete dud like the Matrix Movies and also in the fact that making a Terminator sequel (especially after the emmensly successful T2), would be a very difficult proposition (especially with mentor Cameron not around), it doesn't fail to catch attention.

What makes it disappointing is that it tries to make a mirrior image of T2. Now it's impossible to make something similar to T2 and not get criticised. T2 was perfect. And one can't beat perfection. And after waiting for all these years and watching T2 for around 100 times, I really wasn't hoping to see another T2 look-alike.

Arnold's grown older in the years and he seems tired, but still delivers. What makes the film so weak is the script. It just looks like a concatenation of great action sequences one after the ohter. By the time you start comprehending it, lo! it's over.

The film should have had a much longer run-time with space given to character interactions, which is totally absent in the movie. Plus, there are no sub-plots which takes your attention away from the main theme as so cleverly applied in T2. what made T2 stand alone shining in spite of T1's brillance, was the fact that it ultimately showed a new aspect of the Terminator, which was not viewed in T1. So that given away, and the audience knowing more or less all about T800 thanks to the previous movies, there was not much that T 800 could bring new in this movie. Especially, what I hated most was the slap stick humor of the terminator which is not expected from him. I mean, c'mon he's a killing machine deviod of any human interaction, how can he have humor? The T's humor in T2 stood apart beacuse it was incorporated situations where his brutality and ignorance of humans made it look humorous, rather than making it crack ludicrous jokes like "Talk to the Hand". I mean, if someone asks a terminator for money, what do u expect from it? Either, it kills him or if he's a good terminator gives a stare such that the quails way from him! but not here.

Also, there are couple of situations in the movie which has been borrowed straight from Arnold's Commando. The car driving downhill amidst trees and the line "I lied". Not original at all! Again, some of Arnold's one liners are really inappropiate to the situation.Consider this: kate's father has just been hit by TX, T800 blast her off an elevator shaft, and while Kate's dad is in death thores what does he do? Does he go near him and tries to see what the injury is all about? No way- he stays there and says - "She will be back". I mean who gives a damn at that instant for that line!

Now coming to John Connor! well, if this idiot is to be the leader of human resistance, God save us! The John we witnessed in T2 shows a rebelious quality and self proficency that made the audience feel like that he could be a leader in the future. Even at that age he single handly escapes the T1000 in a bike initially and gives insights into what needs to done correctly at times even when the adults were faultering (one instance that stands apart is the sequnces of T800's chip destrcution by Sarah!). Well, the T3 John is a confused mess. Not only does he try to scare Kate with a phony Gun, but also gets locked up by kate in a Dog cell! now, if you know that JD will not happen , you should be happy about it and go on with your life as a normal person. Again, if you are apprehensive about JD you should be doubly cautious about your surroundings, rahter than being a mess as portrayed in T3. Even at the finale, it is Kate who tells him what they were actually doing in the shelter! the idiot couldn't derive it on it's own. Also, if the leader of human resistance gets killed by a Terminator during the war beacuse he had "weakness" towards it, maybe skynet should not have bothered to sent 3 terminators in the past to kill such a wreck!

Next: Sarah Conner is missing having died of Leukemia! kate tries to fill in as a proxy for that strong female lead, and to tell the truth she does much better than John. but of course, she's no Sarah conner! maybe, if the script had been a bit more strong it would have had a better potrayal of her, which once again bring us back to the script! Was it really necessary to make T3 after such a brilliant and conclusive ending in T2? For my money: No. but then, T3 does bring in some refreshment in terms of concepts (it adds to a lot of confusion and inconsistencies as well!). It does try to put in the humanity angle a bit more than have been shown in the earlier T movies (totally absent in T1, but then t1 wasn't about humanity, it was about T800). They could have tried to propound it more in the movie and cut out the humor. (T movies are not meant to be funny). The greatest zenith in the movie is of course the TX. i mean, when you are going ga ga on a killer over it's sexuality, it's really impossible to fear it , something that was inspired by the previous terminators. And to be very frank, I could not see how Tx was more efficient that T1000 in weapons department except for it's hand doing some funny things. The intrinsic superioirty (if any) of TX over T1000 can never be seen ( Maybe the script wrtier could not come up with something better, viz., a lump of energy as was previously thought to be done). when you watch T1000 you directly see how superior it is to the previous T800. Well, i could see much of TX being superior to T1000. If someone do see it pleadse let me know!

Finally, after all the bad pionts, the good point: the ending. Poetic, brilliant, but a comes a bit too late to repair the damage that has been done before, a saving grace one can say for the T series. It is totally open ended and gives a very good platform for anothet T movie. Now I know, that pulling it a bit, but if Mr. cameron can once again reprise his role as the captain of the terminator ship, and given due hard work, T4 will stand better than T3. And only then can the existence of T3 be justified.

title: Better than expected...
review:
...of course, my expectations were not that it was going to be better or even as good at T2. There was just no way that would happen. So I was expecting it to be as good as Demolition Man or something(which I thought was just ok).

Turns out, T3 was way better than Demolition Man! And I personally thought it was as good as the first Terminator movie.

We had awesome action sequences(especially the chase with the crane!), witty one-liners(which every Arnold movie MUST have!), and a decent plot that didn't seem as depressing as one would think it would be. Nick Stahl was great as John Conner. He's a better actor than Edward Furlong, although he doesn't look much like what Eddy looks like. Claire Daines' character was a good new character too. The T-X was the hottest robot I've ever seen, and she was one tough machine! But I'm glad they didn't make a big deal out of her, and focused more on the plot of judgement day.



And the twist of the T-800(Arnold) killing John Connor in the future, as well as judgement day actually happening sets us up for a great new kind of new Terminator movie for T4(if it gets made), because it could take place in a post-apocolyptic world with the human surviors battling against the machines. It wouldn't be the classic "good terminator gets sent back in time to protect Connor/bad terminator gets sent back in time to kill Connorz" scenario. It could be taken to a whole other level because of the plot of T3!

Good movie, great set up for T4!

[END SPOILER]

title: The machines rise anyway
review: Where to start? I tend to agree with other reviewers (and James Cameron) that there was no really compelling reason to make this film. This one, thematically, mirrors the previous one. And also, like, for instance, the third "Lethal Weapon" movie, this third "Terminator" film becomes partly a self-parody. But to give credit where credit is due, the action sequences were very impressive, and the crane chase will be a classic scene. (However, chases in inappropriate vehicles are sort of a trademark sinking into the self-parody mentioned earlier.) Schwarzenegger has found a character that certainly matches his acting ability. It's sort of too bad that he will be too old to ever make another "Terminator" film, although that probably wouldn't stop the studio if they thought the money was there. Claire Danes was pretty good here, as was Kristianna Loken. There is plenty of room to quibble about the various time travel paradoxes, and some other plot holes. I have to give the filmmakers some credit for the lack of a typical Hollywood feel-good ending. If you liked the other "Terminator films, you have to see this one, although it isn't quite the classic that those others are. Grade: B+

title: Definitely the Best Terminator Movie of them All
review:
I saw the entire trilogy back to back to back. This one was definitely the best. In the first, the music was like something out of a video game and it was more of a ridiculous love story than a science fiction action film. The second film was a little better than the first because it focused more on the time travel aspects and the war in the future. I liked the fact that John Connor was a bit of a motorcycle punk. That's the kind of guy I'd elect to be a military leader, but I didn't like the idea that Sarah Connors was in the insane asylum. In "Rise of the Machines", however, it made a terrific link to the war in the future. The terminator (Model # T-X), who was both more powerful and hotter than the other two, had multiple targets and most of them were killed. Therefore, its mission was mostly a success. The only down side to this movie is that the creators brought back THE Terminator, Arnold Scharzenegger. I don't think that Arnold really should be in any more of the Terminatory movies. Finally, after watching this movie, I felt that it could be a good ending, but it could also be added on to. For example, the fourth terminator movie, if there ever will be one, could deal with John not having all the generals he would have had for the war and how humankind can overcome its follies with machines.

I give this movie a 10 out of 10. For Terminator fans and general Sci-Fi fans, i would highly recommend this movie. Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend it to little kids, tho. Hence, the R rating.

title: Shockingly Brilliant
review:
By what right does the third installment of a series whose last entry wrapped ten years ago - a summer popcorn feature, centered around a "hot chick," and produced absent the writer/director who made the legendary originals - have any business being as objectively great as this film?

Take away the laugh lines - of which there were, admittedly, too many - and you have one of the darkest and most violent science fictions films ever made. From the brutal assassinations of teenagers in their fast food jobs and make-out parties, to John Connor jamming a loaded pistol into his own temple, to the rampage of the prototypical Skynet killbots, and the inevitable and unstoppable nuclear holocaust, this was far and away the bleakest of the Terminator series. Nowhere near the emotional weight of the second feature, but also nowhere near the obnoxious childishness it also displayed in parts - had anyone in the audience of T3 felt anywhere near as much loathing for the person of John Connor as they had in T2?

What action there was, was indeed brilliantly produced - the crane sequence is the best chase filmed in the series to date. The action, however, was secondary to the critical advancement of the base plotline - we now, at last, have had Judgement Day, and the only place the series could possibly go from here, is to the War of the Machines, for which we have all been waiting.

I had expected little from this film, and avoided it in the theatre. It's a prejudice I now regret.

title: We will meet again
review:
I would like to start off by saying to anyone who hasn't seen this movie watch it, it is the best movie ever(well next to blade runner and the truman show) anyway watch it it's awesome.

Now i went to see this 4 times at my local theatre, i was the first one to get the dvd at wal-mart the night it came out. This movie has had a profound effect upon my everyday life and it's the reason i started to love scfi again.

Because as of late there has been a shortage of great or even good scfi on tv and movies, with the exception of a couple movies here and there over the last 10 or so years it's gotten to be the forgotten genre of movies.

Well, T3 brings back that feeling of scfi and more. I mean i was blown away when i saw this movie it's the best movie of the year and the best scfi movie since well since T2 came out in 1991.

it brings everything full circle and rightly so. But, i do hope there is a T4.

I give it a 10/10 it's scfi pie. Way to go Mostow!

title: A few more short comments...
review:
Hi all,

After reading some of the other comments on this film, I have determined that most people feel that this film's overwhelming flaw was the absence of James Cameron from its production. I have already given my reasons for standing up for this GOOD film, and I'm not going to go over them again. However I would like to comment on Mr. Cameron's blind hero worship that most people seem to be guilty of.

James Cameron is a filmmaker, NOT GOD! Hell, I'll even go as far to say he's a good filmmaker (and that's pushing it). But lets all keep things in perspective. All three T-movies are nothing more then shoot em' up, car chase action fests. To imply that there is any serous drama injected into any of these films (even the first two) is just silly. All three films have the combined dramatic warmth of a monster truck rally. James Cameron brought no real "SOUL" to these films... for how can one bring something that does not exist? We all watch these movies for the same reasons, because we like to see people break really expensive things. Lets not try to legitimatize the fun of watching an car chase action film by implying that it is dramatic masterpiece. Every time that happens, I'm sure somewhere an English Lit. Professor is crying.

title: Doesn't live up to expectation
review:
When I first heard about Terminator 3, I was ecstatic. I have loved the first two films ever since I was a child (my older brother's watched them a lot). But when I heard that James Cameron was dropping out, and that John Connor wouldn't be played by Edward Furlong I was a little disapointed, but still excited. However, I was right to be disapointed. Terminator 3 is a good movie in general, but compared to the first two movies, it's crap. There are some OK moments, most movies have them, and even I thought the beginning part with the sunglasses was funny, but the movies aren't made to be funny. They aren't made to mock the first two. The only thing I really liked *****SPOILER***** was seeing the psychiatrist (Dr. Peter Silberman) from the first two films. The ending was also very depressing. If Judgment Day comes anyway, what were the first two films for?************

Anyways, I think that they should have left the Terminator franchise alone. Big budget movies, do not always make good films.

title: It´s like Terminator 2...minus the good plot, dialogue and brains
review: Terminator 3 is a good action movie but nothing more. Everyone knows that T3 obviously had alot to live up to being the sequel to one of the best movies ever made so the director decided to take no changes and just put together a story as simple as it gets and fill the gaps with action and humor. Which makes an entertainment movie but nothing you will remember, it´s one of those movies that you forget as soon as you walk out of the cinema. Terminator 2 was full of memorable quotes and scenes but T3 is a crap film with a clowninator that does not scare you.

title: Not what i waited for....
review: I waited this film many year and the conclusion did not reach for my standarts.The first 2 films were great with moments of suspence and terror, this film had many funny moments that shouldnt be in this film. I waited for more fighting scene with terminatrix and more suspence than humour. I was very dissapointed about this film, i gave 7.0/10 to this film only because it is terminator movie and not by the actually film.

title: Send back a Terminator to prevent the creation of this film!
review:
Okay, I'll admit, there were a few parts when I thought I'd like the movie, but those feelings passed quickly, replaced by depression and anger. Those of us who have awaited the release of this movie for so long, have been cheated.

I have no idea why they didn't stick to the idea of Chyna (Joanie Laurer) playing the "Terminatrix". If it has to be a female, I think it'd be better for it to be a muscular one.

I also haven't the slightest idea why they chose Claire Danes to be one of the movie's co-stars.

The comedy elements are bad, but somewhat tolerable. Unfortunately, the same can't be said for the rest of the movie.

The absence of most original characters also weakens the movie, as one doesn't feel like they're watching a Terminator flick, they feel as though they're watching a Cinemax 3 AM b-movie.

The few good elements it did have, weren't shown, weren't played out, enough. In the same sense, the bad elements were given ridiculously long time.

I Rate This: 0/10 (Don't watch: Even if you're a huge Terminator fan)

title: Surprisingly good! But in this movie John Connor is an impotent, indecisive, half-wit!
review:
I was prepared for the worst ... but hey it was pretty good! I'd give this movie about 7/10 ... it could have been 8/10 or better ... were it not for the badly scripted role of the John Connor character. In this movie John Conner is an impotent, indecisive, half-wit!

After the T2 you'd think this guy would be more clued in! Yet in here he seems pretty confused by the whole scenario. He even goes and has a little hissy fit in the mausoleum "why me? why me?" ... idiot your mom's been telling you this your whole life ... now's not the time to act like a pathetic twit! This is the guy who's going to lead the human race? He was supposed to be trained to be a soldier and a leader ... yet he's reduced to the role of a spectator in most of the action scenes! In some of the most climactic scenes Connor is portrayed to have no sense of urgency! There are several scenes where, in the face of danger, he hesitates and stares dumbly at the approaching menace before running away rather impotently. There's even a scene where he and his 'future wife' are frozen in shock as the TX approaches ... and all the while a gun is lying on the ground in front of them. Guess who picks up the gun? The girl! By the end of this movie I want John Conner to die! I don't care if the whole human race will die with him.

If this is the best leader we can come up with its about time we're all replaced by machines.

title: T2 was better than T3
review:
T3 was just not so deep as T2. The difference is that in T3 a female plays Terminatrix and believe me that's really all. What I liked therefore were the special effects, the sounds and the wonderful picture. But I missed the cool soundtrack from T2. What I didn't like was the art of her arms that Terminatrix used in the action scenes and the dialog from Arnie "She will be back"; oh yes she was every time back without any wounds. Nick Stahl as John Connor delivered an amazing performance and he should have won the Oscar!

Again I have unfortunately to say that sequels of nowadays are better not to be done and if then, please with much more creative ideas. I have terminated.

My wife gave 5/10 and I 7/10 = Average rate: 6/10. TERMINATED.......

title: T2 remains the best movie...
review:
T3 is still a great movie, and there is a lot to like about it, and I still really enjoyed watching it, however there are some problems with it that make it disappointing for me. Reading some other reviews from people, I can see I am not the only one who had problems with it, and perhaps if James Cameron was on board with this film, it would have been much better.

First, Edward Furlong should have been back for John Connor. I'm not trying to take away anything from Nick Stahl, because he did a great job. In fact, he looked somewhat like a younger Kyle Reese, and at times, even looked like Furlong himself, but why didn't they just get Ed back for the 3rd - it would have been that much better if they had.

Next, was the fact that the T-101 was still trying to be like the T-101 from the second film, despite the fact that it was a different cyborg. Why was it still copying the behaviour that it's predecessor had been taught then, such as not killing humans and looking for the keys under the sun visor?

Finally, the movie didn't seem to go for long enough, and the story was quite shallow. Elements of a fantastic story were there, but were only brushed over. The whole thing seemed very rushed and actually I was disappointed when the credits began to roll because I thought there needed to be more to the story.

Having said that, T3 is still a good movie, by all means, I would recommend you see it, especially if you are a fan of the previous 2 films, or love Arnie. However T2 still remains the best film.

title: Mixed Bag.
review:
This movie gave me the impression that it was made mechanically (by Terminators??), with no real thought put into it; a rushed production.

The timing/pacing was average, but was probably limited by a weak script to begin with. Despite plenty of action scenes, I nearly found this movie to be. . . boring". Although there were some novel action scenes, they were nothing really spectacular, and the people scenes lacked interest due to the weak plot. I was struggling to retain interest by the end.

Kristanna was miscast for the role of T-X, as her performance was not convincing as a Terminator.

The remaining principle character performances (including Arnold) were not entirely convincing at times either. Again, this was probably due to the weak script.

Technically competent. Artistically, this movie was limited.

Overall rating of 6/10.

title: Please, Don't Come Back!
review:
"Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines" is depressing and loaded with flaws.

@@@@@@@@@@POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD!!!@@@@@@@@@@

Many points in the film did not pan out: John's "death" by The Terminator in the future, Sarah's Death (How could The Terminator possibly know about the details?) None of which is explored, only mentioned and died out. The 2 bright spots of the film is The T-X (Loken), who looks hot and deadly at the same time, and the return of Dr Silberman (Boen), even though it was brief (And he being in a state of denial over what happened in T2). Other than that, this is not a good way to end a series (They should have left it alone with the 2nd film, but that's Hollywood for you), and I hope to God that they will end it here!

title: Put your hand in the hand of the machine that talks to the hand!
review: I give it a "10" (you James Cameron crybabies, you) for no other reason than "SPOILER ALERT!" "SPOILER ALERT!" "SPOILER ALERT!" Nick Stahl's uncanny Alexander Haig imitation at the end.  Just one teensy, weensy bit of advice for our boys at the Department of Defense.  The next time you spend hundreds of billions of dollars for a nuclear winter mountain retreat for the prez and his posse:  Cough up some extra bucks and invest in valet helicopter parking!

title: this movie rlz
review:
this is the best movie i have seen this summer.i am a very big Terminator fan and i think the casting was excellent i dont think there would be a better TX and Arnold was the best pick.I am so sad that they both got terminated though.i was like "what the..."when it happened.but still i think this was a really good movie and i cannot wait to get it on DVD.and for ppl who dont want to pay cuz their cheap asses u can download it off kazaa.i dloaded after i saw it in theatres and i was amazed it actually worked.In conclusion i think this was the best out of all 3 and i really recomend for u ppl to watch it

Peace Out LOL

title: Amazing sheer class
review: This is exactly what movies are about. Going to the cinema to enjoy a top quality blockbuster. This movie has it all, smart acting, food for the eyes and the ultimate ending. This has truly been one of the greatest years for movies I have witnessed to date. Arnie comes back and does exactly what he should have, a good rock steady performance. Everything about this movie is spot on, from the chase scenes to the humour. When I go to see a movie in the cinema I want to be entertained from start to finish, so that I can forget about the fact that my leg is cramping up because my seat is poor quality. This does it for me. I'm one of the biggest fans going when it comes to the Terminator series, yet I have not been prejudiced against this movie from the beginning just because James 'Titanic' Cameron wasn't involved. Its his loss not being a part of the 3rd and hopefully 4th movie in some small way. Why do people frown at the thought of a sequel coming out. It extends the emotion that was had in the first movie, which if only small can't be a bad thing. After all it costs about £4 to go see the damn movie, how can that not be money well spent when the package is this good. So in final if you don't like this movie, you can 'talk to the hand', because this is top quality entertainment. What more needs to be said.

title: What a joke
review:
A let's-make-another-million-bucks-sequel.

Plot: The world is about to blow up. One man, his robot (a fat Arnold) and "the girl" (Danes) tries to save the day. However another robot, much more advanced (and definitely more sexy) than the old, first-generation-demo-robot, are sent to kill the heroes.

I liked T1 and T2. T3 is another story. The plot is absolutely ridiculous. The acting is a joke. I can't even decide if Claire Danes or supermodel Kristina Loken is the worst actor in the movie. Arnold is just a tired cliche. If you like action, go and see Matrix reloaded instead. T3 is a commercial ripoff. Of course there will be yet another sequel. Beware. 2/10

title: Great Sci-Fi action movie, better than I expected.
review: I thought this one would be pretty good, but the previews did not really convey how good it turned out to be.  I also thought it would be that good thanks to its relatively short running time.  It turns out this helps the movie flow really fast and you never find yourself wondering how much time is left.  At least it didn't for me.  This one has Arnold as the Terminator once again being sent back in time to save Conner from an evil Terminator. Well I guess it isn't evil as it is a machine.  Well anyway this time the Terminator doesn't have to long to protect John as the war to end the world, as we know it is really close.  This one is just a great action movie, probably the best one I have seen this entire summer of 2003.  There is a great car chase, one that is even better than the Matrix Reloaded, mainly cause it looks more real, like it is actually happening in a city rather than a road Hollywood built (don't get me wrong though, that one was cool too) and there are other numerous scenes in this one that just keep your attention to the screen.  The T-X is rather cool, but I just don't see her being superior to the T-1000, as it seemed a lot harder to destroy.  Though I thought Kristen did a rather good job similar to Robert Patrick (I think that was his name).  The movie explains some of the plot points I was wondering about too, all in all this movie was very enjoyable and had quite a few humorous moments as well.

title: Please... Don't come back!!!
review:
**SPOILERS** **SPOILERS**

when I came out from the theatre I was praying that there will be no T4 because the ending suggests that there might be. I don't know what Arnold was thinking!! even if there was a 30 MM$ involved, he should not agree to the destruction of the legendary character of The Terminator as they did with this script. the movie should have Comedy in it's genre.

when i went to see the movie, i was not expecting much. i knew that Arnold's performance will not compare to T1 and T2. the movie didn't say anything about an emotional chip being added to the machines. if there was one that will explain most of the stupid jokes that T-800 was making. the moment that i saw the star-shaped sunglasses i knew that it's gonna be a Scary Movie type of film... and it was. the film was filled with stupid lines that were supposed to be funny. i laughed... but i was laughing on myself for believing that this movie was worth watching.

there was no story line...no plot...no nothing! just a bunch of action sequences and a darn lame ending. the only positive thing about this movie was the arrival scene of the T-X. Calire Danes was good, i'd like to see more of her in the future.

if you are a Terminator fan (who isn't) don't see the movie. read about it or yet better to ignore it. the ending of T2 was a better way to remember this icon.

I give it 3/10 (for the car chases and the nude scene)

title: Hope that red light is out for good
review: Greetings again from the darkness.  I absolutely loved the first Terminator and thought the sequel was one of the best sequels ever made (outside of "Godfather II").  Arnold was born to play this role and seems to enjoy it. However, the act is a bit tired now - and Arnold is looking a little wrinkled for a robot.  Anyway, decent story with Nick Stahl ("In the Bedroom") as a 20 something John Conner and the always wonderful Claire Danes as the female fill in for the not present Linda Hamilton.  I am really glad Danes is acting full time again.  Although it has been almost 10 years since her TV breakout, she is just now coming in to her own as an actress. "The Hours" and "Igby Goes Down", along with this performance show she is trying to find her niche.  Very skilled and not bad to look at, the next few roles are crucial to her career as either a star or character actress.  I just hope she continues to produce quality turns.  Model Kristanna Loken is the T-X, or Terminatrix (get it?) who is after John Conner.  A far more powerful and efficient killing machine than Arnold, but somehow she continually falls just short.  Not sure how director Johnathan Mostow ("U-571") lucked into this gig, but at least he doesn't muck it up.  This is just a story that has had its day and should be appreciated for what it gave us.  Let Arnold run for office and let Hollywood move on.

title: Derivative, Stupid.... but somehow good
review: Leave your brain at the door, T3 is little more than T2 redux, but with less plot and more explosions.  There are many "cringe moments" but ultimately it is a lot of fun with some great action scenes.  I liked it in spite of myself. Nick Stahl as John Connor was better than Eddie Furlong, Claire Danes was believable as expected and Kristana Loken was eerie.  The worst perfomance came from Arnold-whose character was poorly and cheesily written. The ending was terrific though and redeemed the film alot.  The car chase was probably the most pointlessly obnoxious action scene ever...needless to say, I loved it.  Anticipating a sequel. 7/10  Oh yeah..."Superman 2" is terrible and a shadow of the brilliant "Superman: The Movie"- watch them both again and you'll see what I mean.

title: Terminator1+2=3 surprisingly unimaginative retread of 1st two
review: Little story and one too many explosion/car chase that should have killed our heroes make this movie unintentionally ridiculous. Even more ridiculous is the featherweight female terminator who never smudges her makeup, and can run 60 mph in high heels. She never seems threatening, perhaps because she's never shown killing anyone; her catty expression always accompanied with ominous music (lifted from Mr Liquid Plumber, or a whomever was the 2nd Terminator) just doesn't cut it. Some say this is a good no-brainer flick, but I suspect a full lobotomy is required to actually enjoy it.

title: 5/10 an ok movie
review: T3 had it's moments. Action wise it was very good, as for the story well in my opinion it was average. The film misses cameron, had he been a part of it i think it would have been a classic like the previous two. Arnie was boring in this film, didn't have the same spark as in T2, i guess though in this film he is a different cyborg. But either way arnie is one of my fav actors. An average film, good action but could have done much better with the story.

title: please terminate me before T4
review: (Spoiler) Take the plot, the jokes, the explosions from T2, get a hot blonde, get some low budget actors with the money left over after hiring Arnold and hey, never overestimate the intelligence of the movie going public. The crane scene was good, that's why I gave it 2 stars, but the whole rest of the mess surrounding it kept me squirming in my seat. I care about as much for the fate of John Conner as I do for the fate of John Rocker. So all the terminators of Arnold's vintage speak with an Austrian accent and age like a human? Maybe after all the humans are killed off the machines can come up with a plot. I can only hope.

title: Liked it better when it was called T-2
review:
This movie blew chunks, wanna know why? Cause until the very end, it was practically identical to T-2. The chase scene was nothing but destructive, other than alot of buildings and vehicles getting demolished it was ho hum.....I wasn't sitting on the edge of my seat or anything. Basically, a more sophisticated terminator, T-X, comes from the future to kill people, namely John Connor and his future wife. Arnold, comes back as the "has been" terminator (same model as in the other 2 movies) to try to stop the "faster, stronger, more advanced T-X". Ooooooh the drama.....wait this sounds familiar. The only difference was that this time the "bad" terminator was a female. Haven't we seen this plot line already in T-2???

Let me just say that I loved the original Terminator, and I really thought that T-2 was ahead of its time back in the day, and I enjoyed it almost as much as the 1st one because of that. But Cameron directed those two, not the 3rd one. These guys look like they couldn't come up with a new way of filming, so just followed the same basic principles that T-2 had. Trust me when I say that if you've seen T-2, then you've seen T-3 already.

*******************Spoilers*********************

The only difference is that in T-2, judgement day was averted, in this one judgement still happened, basically nukes were set off all around the world thanks to the machines. So while judgement day was avoided in T-2, it is learned in this movie that judgement day was only postponed. I swear that is the only "new" idea in T-3 that they used. It "could" have been really cool had the nukes gone off in say the middle of the movie and then we got to see John Connor and his mate still trying to survive the aftermath with a terminator after them....but no. They didn't even show the nukes going off!!!! All they did was in the final 2 minutes of the movie, show some mickey mouse grid with lines going across it representing the path of all the nukes so you could get a sense of just how many were set off. Great job Hollywood. The best aspect of the movie that you could have used, you decided to not even show.

Basically, it boils down to this. The future of the humans comes down to the hands of John Connor and his future wife. After 2 failed attempts to kill Connor in the first two movies, they try again. Like the 2nd movie, Arnold is sent back from the future to stop the more advanced T-X before she kills her targets. Like the 2nd movie, it is a "struggle" and she is always right behind them just "ever so close" but yet not ever close enough to finish the job. By the end of the movie, just as they "want" you to think that the T-X is about to kill her targets (ya as if), Arnold, our hero, saves the day. Oh ya, and he spouts out yet another dumb one liner like "you are terminated" to the other terminator.

There was one part where the T-X, who can control machines, got to Arnold and was controlling him against Connor and his future wife. This could have been a cool twist, like a blast from the past from Terminator the original, but no. This only lasted like a minute or two as Arnold shut himself down so he wouldn't "fail" his mission. So there went that little twist, yet another missed opportunity to make this movie unique.

God I hope they don't release a 4th one because this is starting to get as predictable as the "Rocky" series. There were attempts at humor in this movie, but they were "few and far between" and not very funny even when you saw them. Anyone who pays to see this movie once can be forgiven, but if you pay to see it twice, then you should seek a CAT scan to see what is wrong with your head.

Macc

title: 2 words
review:
God awful.

Ok. more than 2 words.

What the hell were they thinking? I knew it was gonna be poor, but this is just taking the mick. I cannot believe people are actually enjoying this rubbish. It is a insult to have this drivel put next to Camerons hard work and attention to detail. You are all nuts. "Did IQ's just suddenly drop overnight?"

title: Check your brains and your eardrums at the door.
review: T3 is a sad comment on the state of movies today.  I learned from the manager of the theater that I attended that the volume control in the auditorium is dictated by the studio.  If you walked out of T3 with your ears ringing and your senses scrambled, and, perhaps, even noticed the befuddled state of your brain and the distinctive wobble of your walk then there may be hope for you.  The first 30 minutes of this film had nothing but violence and noise, and the most ridiculous unnecessary chase scene ever filmed. I recall a friend's comment after listening to a particularly poor rock group, "If you can't play good, play loud." Terminator 3 played loud. You say you thought it was exciting, thrilling, mind-blowing, and the last word in action movies!? I say, B.S.! This film was garbage.  To compare it with either of the previous Terminator movies says much about the rapidly dimming intelligence of today's movie audience. James Cameron is certainly laughing at this atrocity. If you liked this movie, you like leaf-blowers.

title: "This commercial fluff was nothing but a money-maker to bridge Cameron's work with the hanging Terminator 4."
review:
If you're looking for mindless, repetitive, and hardly groundbreaking CG action sequences, T3 should give you underwhelming entertainment, and leave you with absolutely nothing, except how the script was approved, to reflect upon. Cameron would be rolling over in his grave (if he were dead) at this piece of marketing garbage. The previous movies' ability to stand on their own, and Judgment Day's excellent departures from the original to make a fresh experience. This commercial fluff was nothing but a money-maker to bridge Cameron's work with the hanging Terminator 4. Not to mention interesting and suspenseful storylines, character's that are a little thicker than cardboard cutouts, and flat out BRILLIANT action sequences, even without the capabilities of today's computer animation.

The reversal's presented in the earlier films (Arnold, the traditional hero, becoming the relentless killing machine in the former, and then turning the tables to become an always-there dependable father figure) were not here. And while you can basically predict the ending's of Cameron's films, you don't see (SPOILERS) Reese or the Terminator's death at the end of each picture. The hack's responsible for this mess could have at least thought about throwing us a curve _somewhere_.

As far as I'm concerned, this is nothing but an expensive and quality piece of mediocre "fan fiction," not part of the actual Terminator continuity. They stopped Judgment Day in movie two, this is just a side story.

Remember: Just because Peter Jackson and the Wachowskis did it, doesn't mean you can.

title: Very impressive
review:
Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines

***1/2 stars

Look, I don't mind the first two Terminator movies, I really have nothing against them. Terminator was cool with Schwarzenegger playing the bad guy. Terminator 2: Judgment Day was getting a lot cooler though, with the better special effects, but Rise Of The Machines was just so much better than the other two.

Brilliantly written by Cameron and directed by Mostow, this proved to be a lot better than your average sequel. The new Terminatrix or 'TX' was awesome with weapons she can forge out of her hands.

Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines is about John Connor who is now in his 20's and being chased after by the new Terminatrix. But a new T - 800 is sent back in time to protect John Connor and Kate Brewster who are said to be the key to the future and what they need to protect humans from the rise of the machines.

One thing I can say that I really didn't like is the fact that towards the end of the movie it was getting too soft. But the acting in this movie is really good from pretty much everyone and there are so many special effects throughout the movie that it must have taken some hard work, and it really payed off.

title: Let's send a robot back in time to prevent them from making this movie
review:
There is absolutely nothing interesting in this movie. It is a lazily assembled amalgam of plot points from T2 and lines from The Terminator. It's as though they were too lazy to think up anything interesting and instead defaulted to trying to lamely remind you of bits you liked from the first two.

Yeah, there's lots of destruction in this one, but who cares? The filmmakers completely fail to create any suspense. There's no character development, there's no plot, so there's nothing to invite the audience into giving a crap about any of the "characters". Claire Danes's character shows some promise at the beginning of the film, but her character quickly becomes a simp. Even Arnold gives lame line deliveries, as though he learned his lines right before they rolled camera. Not the good kind of Arnold lame that worked so perfectly in the first two movies, it's just authentically poor

***possible mild spoiler ***

The police psychologist who talks to Claire Danes in the graveyard makes reference to having witnessed the Terminator assault on the police station in the original movie. But in that movie, he leaves just as Arnold enters the station. He's not even there when it all goes down! This blunder epitomizes the whole mess that T3 is - they were too lazy to get it right, they were more interested in coming up with a gag than doing anything dramatically interesting.

By the way, in the "flash forward" scenes at the beginning of the movie I thought the guy was the doctor from Star Trek: Deep Space 9. But it's really Nick Stahl.

BTW, Nick Stahl does look like he could be the child of Michael Biehn and Linda Hamilton. That's about the only detail of this move that looks like it had any thought given to it. The special effects look fine, but that only matters if they're used in service of a good story. But T3 has never been within two miles of a good story.

Boring! See the first one again instead. I gave this one a 2 out of 10, and that was being generous.

title: If you are a fan, you will be disappointed! Want a parody of the previous two movies, you will love it!
review: I just want to warn people for this movie. If you are a big fan of the previous Terminator movies, I'm sorry but you will get disappointed. This is a bad movie! This is not a third Terminator movie with all the thrills, action and story telling that the last two movies offered. It is an action comedy with the typical Hollywood explosions and a bombard of bad jokes that totally "terminate" the seriousness of the movie. it's very easy to get Star Wars 1 flashbacks. with other words it's not worth the money!!

title: Good to great action, but has issues
review:
The huge car chase scene probably makes this movie, with everything else paling in comparison. The sheer scale of the destruction is amazing. I haven't enjoyed a chase this much since Pierce Brosnan took that tank for a joyride in Goldeneye.

My main complaint is that with the change from Edward Furlong to Nick Stahl, John Connor went from being a whiny snot to a brooding snot, but remained a snot nonetheless. If Nick Stahl's John Connor tried to give me an order, I'd push him down and stand on his head.

If they do a T4, let's see John Connor be a bit more heroic, a bit more confident and in charge of himself. In T2, Connor was a marshmallow. In T3, they added a graham cracker's worth of hardness. But to lead like his character eventually must, you need to be a sword, not a s'more.

And let's forget the comparisons to Michael Biehn I've been seeing in the user comments here. The only thing Stahl's John Connor has in common with his "dad" is stubble and ragged wardrobe.

  • G

title: T3 Blew me away....COMPLETELY!
review:
DAMN! I thought it was going to be a pile of junk with cool effects and bad acting, BOY was i wrong... It was almost better than T1 and T2....Geez!

I was sincerely impressed with the acting, casting, effects, story, music etc...Just loved it...Cant wait to get it on DVD.

Ill be waiting for T4 with passion!

GG Jonathan Mostow!

title: The sequel that breaks the trilogy curse!
review:
I've been waiting 12 years for a new Terminator movie. Having watched T-1 and T-2 roughly 50 times each, I would consider myself a huge Terminator fan.

This movie delivers the best movie of the year, and its doubtful very many movies could top this (aside from possibly ROTK, should it be good).

John Mostow provides an interesting, new perspective on the franchise. Having been dissapointed with most of Camerons recent work, I am very glad he did this movie.



The acting in the movie is pure gold, some of the best active I've seen. Arnold, Nick, Kristanna and Claire prove to be equal to any of the actors in the previous versious of the franchise.

Action scenes are equal to both T-1 and T-2 in terms of intensity, possibly surpasing both.

The pacing of the movie is very well done. Having been saddened by the poor job on Matrix : Reloaded, this movie (aside from a 5 second scene) has excellent pacing. DO NOT expect to get a chance to get up and goto the bathroom.

I've read that some film critics claim that this Terminator doesn't have a story, nor a heart (compared to either of the earlier movies) is rather wrong. The theme of the movie is different from T-1 and T-2.



Unlike T-1 and T-2, which have messages of hope during horrible circumstances, T-3 heart lies in inevitability, fate and destiny. John's portrayl of hopelessness is excellent.

*Possible Spoilers*





The movie does take about 15 minutes to start up, but after that, is excellent. The direction of how the machines take over is brilliant. I was stunned at the portrayl of the actual rise of the machines. Even though there is a lack of future war scenes, the movie makes up in the beginning of the war. I doubt that any director could do a better job.

The only complaints I could have in the movie is the 5 second scene where Arnold puts on his glasses for the first time, which was humorous, but not needed. As well as the fact the movie didn't quite have the B-rated sheen that the first 2 had.

I was suprised at 2 things which pleased me, the suspence and violence. Mostow did a better job with these 2 things than either Terminator.

*End possible Spoilers*

Having said all that, I'd look at it this way, on a scale of 1-10

T-1 = 9.75 T-2 = 9.30 T-3 = 8.75-9.00

Go see this movie, and if you've seen it, see it again!

title: No sense of pacing
review: Terminator 3 was average at best. This film had no sense of pacing in my opinion and spent no time at all letting us get to know the characters. Cameron's absence was very obvious. Instead of taking time to build up to each climax terminator 3 just threw it all at us in the beginning and then went down hill from there, throwing chase seen after chase seen and battle after battle until the very predictable ending. The TX that was supposed to be all powerful got her ass kicked all the time and didn't fare half as well as the T-1000 did in T2. I felt like i had hardly seen Arnold in the movie and they spent practically no time on the TX at all other than a few stupid scenes where she said "hey..i like ur bike" and "hey i like ur car". At the end of terminator 2 i felt like i knew the all the character better, terminators and all. This movie didn't allow us to get to know anyone and i felt like the director didn't really care about that aspect of movie making. This movie is a disgrace to the terminator series and has ruined the greatness the series had. If i had never seen the other terminator movies i may have given this movie a 6, but since i have and i love the other two this movie gets a big 4 and a warning to all who love the terminator series and have yet to see this movie.Only watch this movie if u don't care about the other movies or ur really into special effects and explosions and you just want a action movie where no brain activity is required. I only can pray they don't make terminator 4. God help us if they do.

title: A script that James Cameron would have shot, but not with film
review:
All I can say is that I was disappointed with this film. I loved the first Terminator, a wonderful apocalyptic film with an excellent tight script, which built tension with dark sets and dark characters, and was shot with a small budget. I really enjoyed the second film, a wonderful apocalyptic action-packed film shot on a huge budget (once again a tight script). I hated the third film because it was and action-packed film but not much else...besides the big budget of course. Eventually the car chases just become more of "been there, done that."

How many times can you watch cyborgs throw one another into a wall (just like in the second film)?

How many times can you watch the a big rig chasing our heroes down the street (just like the first and second)?

The only difference with this film over the others is that in this one the terminators attack one another with every form of plumbing fixture known to man.

During a pivotal scene, John Connor, our hero, threatens to shoot himself in the head unless the Arnold terminator does what John asks. I was praying that John would have pulled the trigger just so that I would be able to leave the theater that much sooner.

Save yourself the money you would waste on this one and go rent the first two in this series. It will afford a better evening and it will you save you the trouble of driving to the movie theater.

title: what is SHOULD have been
review:
They should have set it in the totally in the 'Future war" showing all the events that led to what we already saw, but that they only hinted at before.

Finding the Time Machine, realizing the Terminator was sent back (a tense moment). Sending Reese back, then realizing it didn't work, because nothing changes.

Lots of good action and battles, as well as tense sneaking around the Terminator Factory and Skynet. The we'd see them find the Rows of Terminators and reprogramming the one we saw in T2. As they work, and get the time machine started again, all the T-101's (Arnold and the Exo-skeletons) wake up and start closing in on John Conner and his group.

Just as the terminators move in, the reprogrammed T 101 disappears in time (the point where we see him appear in T2), and the corner of the 18 wheeler trailer appears in the bubble. (cool) Nothing changes again, and John and his group, battle worn, sigh and give one last yell and unload weapons on the approaching terminators. With John still yelling,the terminators pounce. As they do, though, time catches up, and a blinding flash of light appears. The flash then fades to the scene originally shot for T2, with John and Sarah in the park with John's daughter. All is well....

End

title: A big let down for true fans
review: Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines did not do justice to the series at all. There were more plot holes and mistakes within this movie then I've ever seen in a movie with a budget of 170 million dollars. The problems are consistent throughout. First of all, and the biggest shortcoming, is the fact that James Cameron did not direct this film. This new director who calls himself a true "fan" of the series knows nothing about it and nothing about a good movie. The terminator is seen as a running gag, something to laugh at and not something to fear or respect. As far as the TX, she was not acceptable as a killing machine. She inspires no fear and creates no suspense as she chases the main characters. Although she is referred to as the ultimate killing machine, she is inferior to the less advanced T-1000. Nick Stahl, the actor who played John Connor, is not fit to be the future leader in the fight against the machines. He is scared and pretty much just a figure head within the film offering no real development in his role. In fact, no character is developed well in this film and the terminators are much too humanlike. My advice for the true fans of the series is to not bother going to see it. In fact, I am going to pretend this movie never happened. It is not a part of the series to me. After watching the film one thought went through my head, "What was the point of that movie?" The answer is to make a quick buck off a big actor and a big title.

title: Who said this guy could direct?
review: Why did this director take all of the things that had been done in the first 2 movies and try to put them into this movie?  I'll tell you why, because he didn't have a CLUE as to how to direct.  Arnold is really stretching now for a hit and this is just not it.  It was more like a video game than a movie. All of the scenes at the middle and end of the movie looked JUST like a video game first person shooter.  Long hallways that go on for ever for no real purpose, and action that was there just for the sake of action, what happened to a plot?

title: Best movie so far this summer!
review:
Spoilers!!

The original is a classic that I have seen one too many times, which made Arnold. The second film, left its science fiction roots, and became a special effects film, without much of a story. A lot of films have plot holes, but how could John Conners exist without the first film happening. No bratty kid, social cause and effects(ie the security guard why don't I kill, the science guy change of mind), Linda Hamilton giving a PC social lecture, and effects with no need like the truck scene. T3 had to change from the first 2, and this makes it a strong film. The over the top action scenes add humor for the film. Arnold acts more like a machine, and becomes a strong secondary character; smart move for Arnold. It shows he can step back for the good of the film. Arnold's computer behavior is comical! Most science fiction has philosophy, and this film deals with fatalism. This film answers the question why does John Conner exist. As a result of fate, the second film only delayed the inevitable. One must deal with their fate. Chaos theory with free will creates order to chaos and events unfold. The strongest part of this film is the believability with the science fiction. In 1984, Sky Net takes over, was science fiction, but with the net, and the grid cyber war, it is possible. This would damage the financial, power, communications system etc. I watched a show about cyber war on the Learning Channel, with what the NSC could do and with Sky net and the virus it is plausible. Add the sci-fi, time travel and anything is possible. The ending is mind blowing with fatalism. 7 or 8 out 10.

title: Underhyped but over-rated
review:
Terminator 3 is a prime example of what I'd call underhype/over-rate syndrome. We all saw the awful trailers, we all heard about the troubled production history, and we all knew that James Cameron & Linda Hamilton wouldn't be involved. Suffice it to say, no one I knew thought this movie was going to be very good. I held out hope that I'd see a reasonably entertaining action movie.

That's exactly what I saw, . . . barely. However, I think that the fact that the movie came with such low expectations, has somehow raised a lot of people's opinions of a very mediocre film (73% fresh on Rotten Tomatoes).

But enough about other people's opinions, lets get to mine. I watched Terminator 3 with a smile throughout most of it. It wasn't a big goofy smile, or a wide-eyed look of awe or shock, but a pleasant, mildly amused smile. I left the theater entertained, but I almost immediately began to forget the movie I just saw.

I started to think about why my reaction was so luke warm. I think I can boil it down to this: There wasn't one moment in the movie that thrilled or surprised me. For a Sci-Fi action movie, let alone the 3rd installment in a series, that's a fatal flaw in my book. Where did it go wrong? Here's my breakdown:

CHARACTERS: - T101 - Great to see Arnold back as the T-101, I actually liked him better here than I did in T2. He has a couple of funny lines, but like the rest of the film they are mildly amusing and instantly forgettable. - John Connor - Nick Stahl is less annoying than Edward Furlong but not anymore interesting. He's actually quite bland and didn't generate empathy for his character. - Kate Brewster - Claire Danes manages to make her more empathetic and engaging than John Connor, but the two characters have zero chemistry together. Any human drama that might have made the movie more interesting is lost by this fact. - TX - A sorry substitute for Arnold in the 1st film and Robert Patrick as the T-1000 in the 2nd. She doesn't pull out any awe-inspiringly cool tricks like the T-1000 did, and her stone-cold-menace factor pales in comparison to the T-1000 as well as Arnold in the original. Granted she had two pretty tough acts to follow, but if the film makers insisted on telling basically the same story for the 3rd time, they had to make up in style and cool effects what they sacrificed in lack of originality and predictability.

Which brings us to STORY: I liked the 1st 2 terminator films, I didn't need to see them AGAIN during the 1st hour of this film. The first hour had no tension or suspense because I'd seen it all before, and we knew none of the main characters would be killed by the TX anyway. Had there been any spark of originality here it may have sustained my interest more than it did. During the last half hour, the story finally goes somewhere new, but by that time even these late developments are utterly predictable.

DIRECTING: Serviceable job by Jonathan Mostow, the action scenes are well structured, and the character scenes are watchable enough. However the framing of the images doesn't compare with the stylistic touch James Cameron displayed in T2.

WRITING: The dialog was succinct and to the point. No groan inducing lines, but nothing I'd call witty either.

ACTION: A lot of people have apparently been wowed by the chase scene involving a crane driven at high speed while ripping up half the city. I'll say this for this scene, it's loud, and it certainly must've been expensive. Again, there is absolutely no tension in this scene, and visually it is not as impressive as say the highway chase in Matrix Reloaded. I've seen plenty of chase scenes in my time, and a great many of them were better than this one. A fight scene between the two terminators towards the end of the film fares much better, mostly because (gasp!) I didn't know how it was going to end, and because the film makers wisely avoided the use of CGI stuntmen for the most part. You could really feel the weight of the metal crashing against the environment in this scene.

EFFECTS: Like I said before, this film has basically nothing original story, character, or action-wise, putting a great burden on the effects to offer something to keep us interested. The result is ho-hum, although I must commend the restrained use of CGI during action scenes (a practice that has cost many other movies the suspension of disbelief from their audiences).

So to summarize, T3 is a mildly fun action flick. If that's all your looking for, by all means T3 will do the job. Just don't be suckered by the under-hyping into thinking this a great film that's come to rescue the summer. As a fan of the series I liked where the story ended up, but the journey there was at times an exercise in mind numbing predictability.

My Rating 6/10

title: As good as the first sequel?
review:
I have been waiting to see this movie for 10 years... Imagine the amount of expectations I have had time to build up during this time! ;) So, did Terminator 3 deliver what I was hoping for? The answer is YES, and then some!!! I am very impressed! I won't give away anything, but even the most hardcore Terminator fan will be proud to see the end result! And if you haven't seen the first two, you probably will after watching this one...

You simply HAVE to see this movie, and you cannot wait until you can find it at blockbuster!

title: Rock'em sock'em robots
review:
"Terminator 3" is a worthy successor because it continues the series in exactly the same way that, say, "Alien3" did not. Whereas "A3" basically said "forget those earlier two movies" and did something disastrously different, "T3" follows through on situations set up in the first two installations, neither contradicting anything we were told earlier, nor pulling any crucial but previously unknown info out of a hat. (Think "Halloween II": "Gee, we forgot to tell you that Laurie Strode is Michael Myers' sister." Never have bought that. None of that nonsense here.) "T3" sets up familiar scenes--e.g., Arnold arrives naked from the future and has to find some clothes--then plays against expectations, often humorously, to resolve them.

Linda Hamilton's Sarah Connor is absent, but still has her own contribution to make. "T1" was about Sarah; "T2" was about Sarah and her son John; "T3" is about reluctant hero John. But since the tuff-heroine aspect is so important to this series, that baton is passed to former teenager Claire Danes, who's surprisingly capable as a pi$$ed-off action chick.

Arnold's Terminator--hostile in "T1", helpful in "T2"--is still helpful here, if a bit chattier. His matter-of-fact transmission of useful info, and his timely observations of human nature as he's been programmed to understand it ("Anger is more useful than despair"), make use of Arnold's gift of deadpan comedy. And the terminatrix, the TX, played by 23-year-old Kristanna Loken, is an absolute icepick. Combining the deadliest aspects of the earlier models' hardened skeleton AND liquid-metal body, this one adds built-in weapons systems and the ability to remote-control other machines. Loken has only two facial expressions here: a total blank, and a go-to-hell version of a Mona Lisa smirk. Both expressions are chillingly unblinking. Brrr!

Ignore the whiners who are going on about how bad a movie they think this is; they're the equivalent of Comic Book Guy on "The Simpsons" saying, "Worst episode EVER!" Killer robots, nuclear peril, over-the-top vehicle chases, and a two-fisted action heroine: what more could you ask? Surprisingly downbeat ending, all but guaranteeing a "T4." Bring it on.

title: Corrections & Review
review:
A few corrections to the IMDB summaries: Arnold is the T-101 model, not the T-800, and I believe John is supposed to be 25, not 18. (He makes reference in the movie to being 13 during the time of T:2 and then also makes reference to that being more than 10 years ago. Also, it's been 12 years between films, and it would make decently logical sense for John to be 12 years older since both films take place in the current time. And finally, if your local theater has an online summary of the movie, chances are they state John's age as 25 - check AMC Theaters, their summary says he's 25.)

The film itself was excellent. It was a perfect balance between a story driven drama and an action packed sci-fi. Nick Stahl did a wonderful job, fully exceeding my expectations. Schwarzenegger was as terrific as always. He somehow takes an unfeeling cybernetic organism and manages to make him loveable. The TX is dutifully frightening and full of surprises. The effects are stupendous! All in all, a real treat. It was a wonderful movie.

My only disappointment was the absence of the Terminator theme throughout the film (although it did play during the closing credits).

Also, I don't know how reliable this information is, but I've heard that Schwarzenegger has already expressed interest in returning for a third Terminator sequel (which would be excellent because the way this film ends leaves you clamoring for a fourth installment).

title: Great fun
review: I just saw this movie, and had a great time.  Once again, The Terminator is back, along with an extremely hot T-X, played by Kristanna Loken.  Great action scenes, raw violence, and more than adequate acting carry it very well.  Not as original as the first two, but still comes up with creative fight scenes.  A fair amount of amusing dialogue is also present.  Overall, very enjoyable, and quite well made.  I would recommend it to most people, and give it an 8.6 out of 10, or 9 out of 10.

title: Excellent
review:
While the effects might seem a bit rushed the entire film rocks and rolls though some familiar Terminator territory. The film thankfully ends on time, any more would have been flogging.

The scary thing is when it dawns on you that Arnold, without much formal education but with the smarts to learn a lot of lines, wants to govern the people of California.

If it happens lets get SkyNet up and running FAST!

title: "I'm getting too old for this s***"
review:
That line muttered by Glover's character in Lethal Weapon popped in my head when I saw Ah-nuld's naked body slowly rises from the fire of space travel. I could imagined the Terminator saying "Ohhhh boy, here I go again.....I'm getting to old for this s***"."

This film is jammed pack with action - they threw everything into it, a crane, police cars, some helicoptors, some eerie Robocop-looking droids, - everything and anything. So for those who like action - you got a free run of the buffet table here.

***POSSBILE SPOILERS ******

But here's my list of problems I have with this flick.

1) T-X is boring for the fact that she brings nothing to it. With Robert Patrick you could feel the "evil" ooze off him. With her, it ain't nothing. She's like a mannequin - ho-hum...oh she can inflate her bust - yeeeahhh - okay.

2) Story is getting harder to take seriously - yes I know it's a sci-fi action flick and it don't always have to make sense but I like my films to entertain me and get my brain kicking.
