Too many plot holes...heck, big enough to drive that huge crane through - though it's nice to see parts of industrial downtown Los Angeles get trash to pieces with the chase sequences. So weak story, flimsy excuse of a plot.

3) The Terminator doesn't do anything. Ok, yes, he does a lot of mindless damage but we don't learn anything new about him. The first one you could see the terminator thinking, processing new thoughts and ideas, he's evolving in a way - learning that life is a valuable thing. In this one he pretty much fights and fights and fights. There's a scene where John Conor says something to the line of "What, I have to re-teach you everything ?".

I want to like this film - I'm a big fan of the first two but like the Aliens series, it's getting stale. If you gotta go see it, see it druing the day and save some dough.

title: A real letdown (possible spoilers)
review:
I adored the first two Terminator movies. I saw the first one 10 years ago, and the second one a little while later. I was excited at first, but had a couple misgivings. I knew from the beginning that Linda Hamilton wouldn't be in T3, and that John Connor would be played by someone else. I should have followed my gut and not seen this.

Nothing is explained in this movie, like what the T-X was made of, exactly. There was, I guess, a need for a sequel, because the first two movies created a paradox. If they really had stopped Judgment Day, they couldn't have done it. That is, if in T2 they stopped it, there would be no terminators, no reason to send Kyle Reese through time in the first movie, no John Connor, no damaged CPU to build Skynet on--you get the idea. If they had really stopped the future, John Connor couldn't exist and Sarah Connor would still be working as a waitress. What I don't get is why the terminators got sent back in the first place. Obviously, the reason they got sent back was because John Connor was there. Since he was there, didn't that mean they failed in the first place, so sending back machines was useless? Anyway...

Back to the movie. Yes, there were some great action sequences, but all it really did was illustrate (badly) what had to happen anyway, if you just thought about it. It's a great movie franchise, but it's built on absolute impossibilities, not just pretend A.I.

I'd give this movie a 4 out of 10. IF YOU LIKED THE FIRST TWO, STAY AWAY FROM THIS ONE!!!!

title: Not bad
review:
This wasn't a bad movie at all...I went in with very low expectations. I thought it was going to suck and I expected it to be garbage. But it wasn't. In fact I was quite surprised at how good it was. This doesn't even come close to the caliber of Terminator 2, and there is just not enough character or plot development to make it the way T2 did. There are't enough characters in the film and the movie seems to drown in action with a light focus on plot.

Despite this, the movie IS good. The action is intense, the effects are outstanding and its an overall decent movie. There are shocking twists and a surprise ending that will literally blow you away. Don't pass this up if you're a terminator fan.

title: The T800 is back
review:
It was great seeing the T800 back and his relationship with John Connor. "Hasta La Vista, remember? No that was a different model." I also liked the cameo from the doctor from the first 2 films. I like this movie for the nostalgia. I went into the theater not knowing what to expect, so i was pleasantly suprised. The new TX is hot and plays a good villian. This is a different film than the first 2 but remember that the first 2 films were also different from each other. I can't compare it to the first 2 because i was a kid when i saw them. I actually saw T2 at the theater when it first came out. Theres no way to compare the feeling i had when i saw that to this, it was a different feel. Without giving anything away i really liked the ending.

t3 - 8/10

title: Been there, done that.
review: I guess as we see Arnold's film career spiral further down, we will have to indulge him a little more. We will have to endure his publicity stunt involving him being Governor of California and we will have to see him try to go back to something that worked for him before. So, here goes Terminator 3. Sadly, the third installment is by far the weakest of the trilogy. The character and the story has been played out. Oh sure, Arnold's character is much more hero-friendly than the the first installment and even second installment. However, as I watched this standard paint by the numbers sci-fi thriller play itself out, I just felt depressed. You are seeing Arnold try to recreate a character that he was close to twenty years ago. Oh sure, it does not take great range to do so, but still. Perhaps it is naive to expect Arnold to have matured a little bit in his acting career. However, I guess we will not see that Clint Eastwood maturation. Oh well, what is next, Total Recall 2 or Eraser II? Certainly not Last Action Hero 2, Oh Lord, please NO! * out of ****.

title: Almost a deception
review:
First, let me tell you that i'm a big fan of the Terminator movie. So i had great expectation about the third installment. What a deception ! Here's a movie that offer bad acting, a incomplete and incoherent plot and finally a lot of «deja vu» action sequence. We can only ask ourselves if this movie is not in fact a big budget pilot for a TV serie ? There's only one great thing in this movie: the ending. So,if you want to see a very good Terminator story here some suggestion:

  • Rent (again) Terminator and Terminator 2 - Read the great comics books published by Dark Horse Comics

title: Unfortunately, not the termination of the series
review:
Unless it loses lots of money, which would be a fitting termination. Fortunately I didn't have to pay to see it. No one should.

2 of 10.

Obviously made to capitalize on the Matrix/cyber world popularity that movie companies no doubt see as an opportunity for a quick buck. Besides computers (machines) taking over being an obvious rip off of the Matrix/Animatrix, T3 steals from the Hulk (rebuilding nano-technology) and Men in Black II (sexy woman villain).

You know you're in trouble when a movie starts out ranting about armageddon. When the movie has the technology transforming into the demon-faces from horror 101, it's time to find the exit.

Acting is tolerable, but the scenes and characters are so predictable and cliche that the acting seems the same.

It tries to be funny, but the only people laughing are the people laughing loud at anything, probably paid to attend early movie showings in an attempt to try to excite the audience. If you saw the first 2, you might find some funny spots. More than likely, you'll find the spots that are intended to be serious as funny.

Video FX is nothing new. If you've seen the previous Terminator movies, you've already seen what you're going to see.

Soundtrack is nothing new. If you want the same old Terminator stuff, that's what you'll get. That and some really bad christian pop music.

title: This movie deals a blow to newbie directors...
review:
I'd almost say ignore the previous poster's comments. This movie was a low blow to film directors who are starting out. Not only does its storyline override the work that James Cameron created, the movie was so full of cliches and lame jokes that.. well... I want my money back.

Skynet's concept was totally redone. The history of the Terminator as well as John Connor's future was re-written. And my god, the last 5 minutes.... it was as if all of the cheese in Hollywood was crammed into the last 5 minutes of this movie.

My opinion is that they're gearing up for a LOVE movie in T4... something remeniscent of Romeo+Juliet.

For the love of God, don't see this movie. See something else.

title: It's Not Arnolds fault
review: Spoiler Terminator 3 is horrible.  The dialogue is awful.  The acting lacks motivation.  There are too many catch lines.  In the beginning, the visual metaphor with the deer and the motorcycle insulted my intelligence.  And of course Arnold's exploding chest battery, established in the beginning, is going to kill "Terminatrix" in the end. It's all Hollywood, and nothing else.  Its not Arnold's FAULT; just Jonathan Mostow's.  The directing leaves everything to be desired.   And can you believe it, the movie ends when the machines BEGIN their "rise."  Why? Cause their going to make terminator 4.  The marketing ploy is sadly obvious.  If there is a bronze lining, it would be 1 of the action scenes; mediocre.

title: most disappointing film in the history of cinema...
review: ...or at least in my moviegoing history.  I absolutely love the first two terminator films, but this one is just absolute BS.  It starts off well and goes downhill from there.  Whoever gave this piece of crap good reviews must've been from the studio, probably trying to push this $170,000,000 waste of celluloid.  This film should've been, and with the right talent could've been, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly of the series.  Instead it is the Rocky 5 of the series.  Jonathan Mostow should not be allowed to make films for at least 5 years or until he 1)  SEES the first two terminator films before making any other sequels and 2) Grows up.  The die-hard fans of the terminator series are better off pretending this movie doesn't exist.

title: A fast paced action classic
review: Just got back from seeing Terminator 3 and I have to say this was a fantastic movie.  The chase scenes are spectacular, the CG are awesome and the story is classic.  I am so happy to comeback with this feeling and I am sure that this will be a true summer blockbuster.  Arnold was awesome plain and simple.  He reprises the role so perfect, the one-liners , the robotic movement it was fantastic.  Danes and Stahl have great chemistry and the T-X was a nice change.  Cant wait till T-4, remember " We will meet again"

title: A Cinematic Travesty...
review:
How terribly disappointing. I should have expected that, after Terminator 2, that there was no way to better the series. But I couldn't help but be optimistic, so when I heard about T3's impending release, I was ridiculously excited.

What a mistake. The only thing T3 has going for it is its adept special effects, but these are USELESS when the script is abysmal. Terminator 1 was a brilliant action movie, followed by Terminator 2, one of the few sequels in history to surpass its predecessor in quality. And now, eleven years later we receive a tepid, boring and laughable sequel to an action masterpiece.

If you valued the first two movies, avoid this one like the plague. Unless of course you prefer your movies as boring and lifeless as a neutered cow.

title: Excellent...brilliant...fantastic
review: firstly, ill say that this film gets 5/5. it is exceptional. The film oozes coolness and the almost constant action never lets the audience get bored. To those who bang on about it not being as good becuase Cameron didnt do it, i say to them that cameron is over rated. this film is the 2nd best terminator film (T1 being the best) and Terminator 2 being last (mainly cos of the boring bits in it i.e. the dessert scenes). My only critisism of the film is the significantly increased use of humour, this is out of place in a terminator film. However, the rest was good (although the script could have been better), the action was relentless (particlualy the crane scene) and the actors all did a fine job, of particular interest is the end, which is excellent. this is much better than X men 2, Hulk, Matrix reloaded, best film of 2003!!!

title: "Back" in business!
review: TERMINATOR 3: RISE OF THE MACHINES (2003) *** Arnold Schwarzenegger, Nick Stahl, Claire Danes, Kristanna Loken, David Andrews, Mark Famiglietti, Earl Boen. He's Back! And this time the Terminator is against a highly advanced model Terminatrix T-X (Loken, who comes across as a Swiss Army knife meets Sharon Stone out of Midol) sent back from the future to kill rebel leader-in-the-making John Connor (Stahl, replacing Edward Furlong, and for my money actually resembling the adult version shown in the last sequel's preamble) and his spouse-to-be (Danes, seemingly miscast and borderline a Screaming Mimi ala Kate Capshaw in 'Indiana Jones and The Temple of Doom' ), by any means necessary, prior to their attempt to stop SkyNet, the nefarious weapons defense system from beginning a nuclear war. Director Jonathan Mostow (who fills in for James Cameron, who has absolutely nothing to do with this latest chapter in the lucrative franchise) skillfully handles the jaw-dropping action sequences and high tech visuals with deft aplomb (including a hairy chase sequence that rivals 'Matrix Reloaded' ) but the logy screenplay by John D. Brancato, Michael Ferris and Tedi Sarafian) hinders the pyrotechniques on display.
